story:
Food security is important for the survival of our world. Join in the movement for development!

I am a final year student at the Norman Manley Law School in Jamaica, and a graduate student in the Department of Government at the University of the West Indies, Mona. Before I entered law, I had completed the courses for my postgraduate studies. Now that I am on the brink of graduating from law school, I am in the process of completing my thesis for the postgraduate programme. My thesis entails examining Jamaica’s  maritime waters, including the Exclusive Economic Zone and how the area has been affected by illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing.

In an effort to do research for my thesis, whilst at the same time doing research on Jamaica and Colombia’s Joint Regime Area, and how fishing rights within the regime operate, which  will contribute to legislative and policy development in Jamaica and by extension the Caribbean region, I applied for an internship at the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS). The tribunal is located in Hamburg, Germany and the internship goes from July 1 to September 26, 2014. I have been accepted for the internship and the tribunal’s Fund will be giving me some assistance with my living and travelling expenses in Germany. I am therefore seeking US$2,500 to assist with my airfare, the cost of mandatory insurance and for part of my living expenses for the three months in Hamburg.  

So far I have tried various foundations, however they have stated that they either do not have the funds in their budget or that they do not fund research of this nature and that I should try other entities. I am currently trying ministries of government, family members and fishing businesses, however time is running out on me. 

By going to ITLOS this will serve as an opportunity to complete research in an area that vastly affects Jamaica, the Caribbean region and areas worldwide with semi-enclosed seas which are prone to disputes. As it currently stands, there are some reports and articles, including from the Caribbean Regional Fisheries Mechanism which infer that Jamaica and the Caribbean region are greatly affected by illegal fishing from third states.  In addition to research, the experience at ITLOS will also provide knowledge on methods to resolve sea arbitration disputes which have previously occurred in the Caribbean and all over the world. This research has the ability to assist all countries worldwide in the preservation of species as well as by providing information in relation to fishing rights in joint zones of jurisdiction.

I kindly ask you to support me, as a Caribbean representative in a bid to go to ITLOS to conduct further research in theses areas and also to be able to gain knowledge from others so we can work to boost the economies of our respective countries. You can contribute any amount or you can spread the word. Let us protect our world!! "One, one cocoa fill basket"

story:
** We have reopened our campaign for an additional two weeks so that anyone wishing to support us could have the opportunity to do so.**


The Youth Walkout For Climate Justice

Climate change is one of the most pressing issues facing our generation, and youth across the nation are rising up to the challenge to create a better world for ourselves and for future generations.


Students For a Just and Stable Future (SJSF) is a youth-led climate action group. Alongside 350MA and the Better Future Project, we are calling on Governor Patrick to fulfill the promises he made in the Global Warming Solutions Act. Join us as we create support for the Governor to create a policy of building only the best- clean, renewable energy sources- in Massachusetts. We want to commit to building only clean, renewable energy infrastructure in our state. On March 31st, college and high school students from across Massachusetts will walk out of their classes and converge at the State House at 10:30 AM to call on Governor Patrick to live up to his promises. Together, we are calling on the Governor to meet us outside of the Statehouse for a public rally to address this goal. You can help us make this walkout as powerful as possible by donating any amount, no matter how small.

Where does this money go?

To bring in students from all across the state, we will need to provide transport from Western Mass to Boston. Your money will also go to art, stage/sound equipment, and general rally costs.

Our Impact

Under the Global Warming Solutions Act, Massachusetts has committed to reducing our carbon emissions  80% by the year 2050. In order to achieve such significant cuts by that time, all major energy infrastructure investments should be directed solely towards renewable energy, and a ban on coal and fracking infrastructure should be put in place.To read more about the Climate Legacy Campaign, click here.

Can't donate? You can still help! Share this page with your family, friends, supporters, and on social media.

story:
Bonjour, je m'appelle Marc Desgagné et je suis technicien agricole, spécialisé en environnement.

J'ai 48 ans, marié, trois enfants et J'habite un petit village en banlieue de ville de Saguenay, au Québec, Canada.

Je fais appel à vous afin d'amasser la mise de fonds nécessaire au démarrage d'un projet qui me tient vraiment à cœur. J'y travail depuis plus d'un ans, partant de la plus petite partie possible, un bout de tissus vivant, dans un vase de Pétrie. 

Mon projet consiste à utiliser des bâtiments désaffectés ( ancien séchoir à bois industriel, chambres froides désaffectées, ou autres),　afin de　produire 500 kg/semaine de champignons de spécialité, certifiés Biologique (Pleurote, Shiitake et autres) et ainsi créer des emplois.

À　partir de sous produits locaux, tel que de la pâte thermo mécanique de feuillus,  de granules d'avoine (sous produit de la fabrication de flocons d'avoine　pour consommation humaine) et de paille de céréales biologique, je prépare un substrat qui est novateur et qui favorise une croissance plus rapide des champignons.　　

　Le projet repose sur les prémisses suivantes:

  • 　-　La consommation de champignons de spécialité est en croissance au Québec.
  •      - Les produits présents sur le marché proviennent de l'importation 　(Asie, États Unis, Ontario) et sont fatigués par le long voyage et les intermédiaires.
  • 　-Les matières premières sont disponibles localement et à un coût abordable.
  • 　-Des locaux sont disponibles et inutilisés.


L'appareil de productions sera constitué d'équipements industriels récupérés et adaptés.

La forme juridique sera une compagnie privé et sera incorporée au Canada.

Les sources d'énergie disponibles localement sont: Le gaz naturel, l'hydroélectricité　ou la bio masse.　　

Pour l'éclairage des chambres de production, je compte utiliser un système d'éclairage à DEL. (Très peu énergivore.)

Une partie du chauffage se fera à partir d'un système à l'énergie solaire.

À　partir du financement amassé, je vais récupérer des équipements industriels en fin de vie utile, pour monter mes équipements de production. (Laboratoire, étuves, Autoclave, mélangeur, étagères, climatisation, ventilation, filtration, etc.)

Ces équipements sont disponibles localement, via des récupérateurs et à une fraction du prix des équipements neufs.

Le bâtiment que je veux utiliser est composé de 3 sections  indépendantes pouvant être subdivisé en trois chambres plus petites, offrant un potentiel de 9 chambres de production.

Le bâtiment est équipé d'un système de chauffage au gaz naturel et d'un système de ventilation de très grande capacité qui devront être adapter. Le climat des chambre sera contrôler par un système intelligent et des unités de contrôle indépendantes pour chaque chambre.

Dans un premier temps, en collaboration avec le département de biologie d'un établissement d'enseignement locale, je compte faire la multiplication de　tissue qui me serviront　à maîtriser la technique de production en substrat liquide.

Dans un deuxième temps, je compte mettre en production une chambre de production et 　desservir un marché de proximité régional. (Hôtel, restaurant et vente directe)　

Dans un troisième temps, je vise le marché de Québec. (1 million d'habitants à 200 km de la région)

À chaque étape, des objectifs de connaissance et de performance seront fixés et devront être atteints avant de passer à l'étape suivante.

Ce projet est important pour moi, car j'ai travaillé dans différents secteurs d'activité (agriculture, enseignement, industrie du transport, en pâte et papier et depuis 4 ans, dans la fonction publique)　et je crois que chacun doit s'impliquer, dans sa collectivité afin de stimuler l'économie régionale et créer des emploies locaux.

J'ai la fibre entrepreneuriale et le goût de contribuer à l'essor économique de ma région. J'ai des idées et peu de moyens, c'est pourquoi je fais appel à vous qui croyez que de petits gestes peuvent faire une différence.

Les fonds recueillis, serviront à l'achat des équipements, à la mise à niveau des systèmes présents dans le bâtiment et au fond de roulement pour le démarrage de l'entreprise.


L’impact.

L’impacte de votre contribution, est majeure, la force du nombre et le montant recueillit permettra d’établir une base solide pour le démarrage de mon entreprise. Vous qui croyez qu’avec plusieurs petits gestes, on peu changer les choses, c’est à vous que je m’adresse.

2,  5, 10, 15, 20 dollars suffisent à créer trois ou quatre emplois dans une région qui en a grand besoin.

Les quantités de matières premières que j’utiliserai seront autant de matières détournées de l’enfouissement et les équipements restaurés auront une deuxième vie.

Le substrat post production sera valorisé comme amendement, chez des producteurs agricoles pratiquant une agriculture biologiques.

Je compte sur vous.

Hello, my name is  Marc Desgagné me and I am an agricultural technician specializing in environment.

I am 48 years old, married, three children and I live in a small village in the suburban town of Saguenay, Quebec, Canada.

My plan is to use abandoned buildings (old dryer industrial wood) to produce 500 kg / week of specialty mushrooms, Certified Organic (Oyster, Shiitake and others) and thus create jobs.

From under local products, such as thermo mechanical pulp hardwood, oat granules (by-product of the manufacture of oatmeal for human consumption) and organic cereal straw, I prepare a substrate that is innovative and promotes faster growth of fungi.

The project is based on the following premises:

- The specialty mushroom consumption is growing in Quebec.

  - The products on the market come from import (Asia, US, Ontario) and are tired from the long trip and intermediaries.

-The Raw materials are locally available and affordable.

Local -Of are available and unused.




The production unit will consist of industrial equipment recovered and adapted.

The legal form will be a private company and is incorporated in Canada.

Energy sources available locally are: natural gas, hydro or bio mass.

For illumination of production rooms, I intend to use an LED lighting system. (Very little energy.)

Part of the heating will be from one system to solar energy.

From the raised funding, I'll get industrial equipment at end of useful life, to mount my production equipment. (Laboratory, ovens, Autoclave, mixer, shelves, air conditioning, ventilation, filtration, etc.)

These facilities are available locally, via recovery and at a fraction of the price of new equipment.

The building I want to use is composed of 3 independent sections that can be divided into three smaller rooms, providing a potential 9 bedrooms of production.

The building is equipped with a heating system to natural gas and a very high capacity ventilation system that will have to be adapted. The room climate is controlled by an intelligent and independent control units for each room.

First, in collaboration with the Department of Biology of a local school, I intend to do the multiplication of tissue that will serve me to master liquid substrate production technology.

Secondly, I intend to put into production a production room and serve a regional market close. (Hotel, restaurant and direct sales)

Thirdly, I aim the Québec market. (1 million inhabitants 200 km from the region)

At each step, knowledge and performance targets will be set and must be achieved before moving on to the next step.

This project is important for me because I worked in various sectors (agriculture, education, transport industry, pulp and paper and for 4 years in the public service) and I think everyone should get involved in the community to stimulate the local economy and create local emploies.

I have the entrepreneurial spirit and taste to contribute to the economic development of my region. I have ideas and little money, that's why I appeal to you who believe that small actions can make a difference.

The funds will be used to purchase equipment to upgrade the systems in the building and working capital for the start of the company.


The impact.

The impact of your contribution, is an adult, strength in numbers and the amount collected will establish a solid foundation for starting my business. You who believe with several small steps, one little change, it is to you that I address. 5, 10, 15, 20 dollars enough to create three or four jobs in a region that is in great need.

The quantities of raw material that I will use will all be diverted from landfill materials and equipment have restored a second life.

The post production will be valued as a substrate amendment, among farmers practicing organic farming.

I count on you.

story:
WHY?

Conservation International considers South East Asia as one of the most biologically diverse regions in the world. Seemingly endless varieties of flora and fauna inhabit the forest, river, mountain, marine and wetland ecosystems of this unique corner of our planet.

Many individuals, organizations and communites are already engaged in environmental education, conservation and preservation of this critical area. However, most work in isolation and their innovative work and inspiring ideas are not well known.

We would like that to change, and invite you to help make it happen!


HOW?

In June 2012, we will begin our journey; exploring Southeast AsiaÊ¼s biodiversity while riding bamboo bicycles from Thailand to Bali to shed a light on the creative and exciting work of individuals, organizations and communities that will inspire others into action for conservation!

Using YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, our blog, website and other media we will bring these crucial issues to the forefront for a network of concerned educators, students and citizens around the globe.

By becoming part of the GREEN Riders: Southeast Asia community you will be an active participant in the protection of these critically important natural resources on which we all depend.

How you can help:

  1. Make a donation and claim a perk on this page!
  2. Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook
  3. Subscribe to our Blog and YouTube Channel
  4. Share this campaign and spread the word!
Hear what GREEN Riders is all about on BFM 89.9 radio.

 

WHO?

Who is KENNY PEAVY?

Kenny grew up in rural Georgia, USA running around in the woods flipping over logs looking for creepy crawlies and catching crawdads and minnows in the creeks in his back yard. He always wondered what those things were and how nature connected them all together to do their work.

After 10 years in Malaysia he suddenly finds himself getting ready to jump on a bicycle with fellow adventurer Jamie and traipse around South East Asia in a quest to find beauty, biodiversity and cool people doing groovy stuff for environmental conservation and sustainable living.

‘Til this day he is still trying to unravel nature’s mysteries and find answers to the questions he asked back in rural Georgia nearly three decades ago! 

Check out Kenny’s ongoing environmental education work at: As If The Earth Matters

 

Who is JAMIE RASKIN?

Considered in Toronto, but conceived in Marrakech, Jamie found himself getting messy in remote corners of the world very early on.

After years in filmmaking and media arts, he felt the need to get off the phone and way out of town. He began the educator chapter of his career pedalling on long-distance bicycle treks for teens.

With a long interest in outdoor education, Jamie attended a series of related workshops. The first was led by Kenny. The second wasn’t, which meant they had time to go for a beer.

And, as with so many great ideas, this one was conceived at a pub. It was there that the whole bike-filmakingly-across-spectacular-and-ridiculous-places idea was floated. The rest, is yet to come...

In the meantime, check out Jamie’s blog!


WHAT?

Unfortunately, dreams don't come cheap. The gear required to make this trip happen, is reasonable, but has a price tag. We need support to cover some of the costs of this sustainable transport oddyssey:

  • CARBON OFFSET for flights to Thailand and from Bali: $100
  • Two BAMBOO BICYCLES at cost: $2500
  • SOLAR and BIKE-POWERED systems for electricity on the road: $400
  • FILMMAKING GEAR to share the stories with you: $2000 
GREEN Riders is a project of the Environmental Education Alliance of South East Asia.
 
Your support will enable this project, but also contribute to building connections between environmental organizations and educators, and developing and promoting environmental curriculum for regional K-12 schools.

 

      We are inspired into action! Are you?

      Your involvement and support is vital. 

 

So please...

  1. Make a donation and claim a perk on this page!
  2. Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook
  3. Subscribe to our Blog and YouTube Channel
  4. Share this campaign and spread the word!
  5. But most of all get outside... and keep pedalling!

HOW?
In June 2012, we will begin our journey; exploring Southeast AsiaÊ¼s biodiversity while riding bamboo bicycles from Thailand to Bali to shed a light on the creative and exciting work of individuals, organizations and communities that will inspire others into action for conservation!
Using YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, our blog, website and other media we will bring these crucial issues to the forefront for a network of concerned educators, students and citizens around the globe.
By becoming part of the GREEN Riders: Southeast Asia community you will be an active participant in the protection of these critically important natural resources on which we all depend.
How you can help:

Make a donation and claim a perk on this page!
Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook

Subscribe to our Blog and YouTube Channel

Share this campaign and spread the word!

Hear what GREEN Riders is all about on BFM 89.9 radio.

 
WHO?
Who is KENNY PEAVY?

Kenny grew up in rural Georgia, USA running around in the woods flipping over logs looking for creepy crawlies and catching crawdads and minnows in the creeks in his back yard. He always wondered what those things were and how nature connected them all together to do their work.


After 10 years in Malaysia he suddenly finds himself getting ready to jump on a bicycle with fellow adventurer Jamie and traipse around South East Asia in a quest to find beauty, biodiversity and cool people doing groovy stuff for environmental conservation and sustainable living.

‘Til this day he is still trying to unravel nature’s mysteries and find answers to the questions he asked back in rural Georgia nearly three decades ago! 
Check out Kenny’s ongoing environmental education work at: As If The Earth Matters
 
Who is JAMIE RASKIN?

Considered in Toronto, but conceived in Marrakech, Jamie found himself getting messy in remote corners of the world very early on.
After years in filmmaking and media arts, he felt the need to get off the phone and way out of town. He began the educator chapter of his career pedalling on long-distance bicycle treks for teens.


With a long interest in outdoor education, Jamie attended a series of related workshops. The first was led by Kenny. The second wasn’t, which meant they had time to go for a beer.

And, as with so many great ideas, this one was conceived at a pub. It was there that the whole bike-filmakingly-across-spectacular-and-ridiculous-places idea was floated. The rest, is yet to come...
In the meantime, check out Jamie’s blog!

WHAT?
Unfortunately, dreams don't come cheap. The gear required to make this trip happen, is reasonable, but has a price tag. We need support to cover some of the costs of this sustainable transport oddyssey:

CARBON OFFSET for flights to Thailand and from Bali: $100
Two BAMBOO BICYCLES at cost: $2500
SOLAR and BIKE-POWERED systems for electricity on the road: $400
FILMMAKING GEAR to share the stories with you: $2000 

GREEN Riders is a project of the Environmental Education Alliance of South East Asia.
 
Your support will enable this project, but also contribute to building connections between environmental organizations and educators, and developing and promoting environmental curriculum for regional K-12 schools.
 
      We are inspired into action! Are you? 
      Your involvement and support is vital. 


 

So please...

Make a donation and claim a perk on this page!
Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook

Subscribe to our Blog and YouTube Channel

Share this campaign and spread the word!
But most of all get outside... and keep pedalling!

story:
What is this Outdoor Afro Thing All About?

My name is Rue Mapp -- I am the founder of Outdoor Afro, and I am passionate about the great outdoors for everyone to enjoy.

Inspired by my family, I started Outdoor Afro in 2009 to share this passion using social media. The message quickly resonated with thousands of others from around the country who shared their own images and stories that affirmed African Americans do have a positive and historic relationship to nature.

In May of this year, we launched the Outdoor Afro Leadership Team that went to work connecting folks of all ages to nature right in their own backyards. Since then, team members from nearly every region in the US have altogether connected nearly 500 people to the outdoors through recreation and conservation activities.

In 2013 we want to significantly increase the number of people we connect to nature, and to accomplish this goal we need to provide greater professional development for the leadership team to enhance their outdoor skills (hiking, camping, birding, etc). 

Why is this important?

In the face of alarming rates of obesity in the African American community, and the need for more people to care for our fragile planet to support its sustainability and local community health, we all need to get out and build a relationship with nature and the outdoors like never before.

Please help us reach our goal of $15,000

The Impact

Outdoor Afro is about connecting more people to the natural world through fun and relevant outdoor experiences. And we know that people respond positively to leadership that reflects their community.

People need nature like never before. More people getting outside now means healthier people, communities, and greater stewardship for our precious natural resources our futures depend on.

With a start-up of volunteers and monthly training calls this year, we have successfully been able to organize nearly 500 people, from all around the country to be tomorrow’s Outdoor Afro leaders.

Your support today means a significant increase in the number of people getting outside through a strong leadership team!

Please support the Outdoor Afro Leadership Team today!

Other Ways You Can Help

Make some noise about the Outdoor Afro community wherever you go!

  • Co-create the conversation on our Facebook and Twitter pages
  • Use the Indiegogo tools to share this campaign with your networks!

Every action makes a difference!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Wetlands are incredibly diverse and important ecosystems, providing habitat for species, improving water quality, and protecting coasts from natural storms. However, because of various human activities, these valuable ecosystems are in decline across the world. As a graduate student at Yale University,  I have proposed to conduct a large-scale research effort to determine the best ways to restore these important and valuable habitats.


In New England, coastal wetlands are being substantially impacted by the loss of top predator species, such as striped bass and blue crabs. In their absence, a number of herbivorous prey species have been over-consuming marsh vegetation, leading to rapid die-offs.

This research will investigate the importance of restoring a viable predator population and the impacts that these interactions may have on wetland functioning and restoration. By selecting six tidal wetlands along the New England coast, I will establish enclosure cages in which combinations of different predator and prey species will be added. The hope is that by evaluating how changes in species composition effect ecosystem functioning, these results can then be used to help inform large-scale restoration projects.


With the results of this work, I will travel to the Society for Ecological Restoration World Conference in Manchester, UK and give a presentation conveying the best practices for restoring tidal wetlands and engaging with the local communities that depend on these natural resources. Sharing the findings of this type of research is essential for putting it to good use - the nature of this work requires that the science is not only done well, but disseminated to those who can use the information to make informed decisions about restoring natural ecosystems.


What We Need & What You Get

Here's the breakdown:

  • $2000 for travel expenses (London, roundtrip) and accommodations.
  • $500 for analyzing soil and vegetation samples in Yale laboratory facilities.

Tangible Perks!

  • Postcards and souvenirs from London and Manchester, UK.
  • Digital photographs of species found within New England salt marshes.

Intangible Perk:

  • Your contribution will play a large role not only in influencing the restoration of natural ecosystems, but also in engaging with larger scientific and non-scientific communities about the importance of natural habitats and the services and benefits that they provide.

The Impact

From pollution to habitat loss, climate change to sea-level rise, natural habitats are being rapidly degraded and lost across the world. The research proposed here has the potential to substantially impact the ways in which ecological restoration projects are initiated, with a focus on giving back to the communities and engaging them with the work being done. Humans rely on natural ecosystems for a number of services and benefits, including improving water quality, food production, and protection. This proposed work will be one of many steps towards restoring natural ecosystems and the functions and services upon which humans rely.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this project far and wide with your family, friends and work colleagues. Although donations are greatly appreciated, spreading the word is an invaluable component in connecting people with research efforts. Your contributions, both monetary and social, will lend a great hand in lifting this project off the ground and help to restore natural habitats both at home and afar.

story:
As part of my senior project at Maharishi University of Management, while pursuing my B.S. in Sustainable Living, I will be creating an online guide to modifying RVs to be off the grid and I hope to find a Class C rig that I can implement all these super grand ideas!!!!!!! I will:


*Buy an older model RV.


*MAKE solar panels for the RV.


*BUILD an RV-sized wind turbine.


*Create a water catchment system.


*Install a portable compost toilet.


*Build portable garden beds.


*Convert the engine to straight vegetable oil, if that is an option.'


*I hear rumors of a photovoltaic paint....really, paint that works like a solar panel, could this be real?


*Sustainable flooring...I wonder if bamboo floors, which are super sustainable, would work in an RV...hmmmm


*Any other natural resource modifications I discover along the way!


*Oh, if anyone wanted to DONATE a ready-to-drive RV that you are inspired to see be modified, well, I'd have to say I'd love ya forever!


When this project is complete and I am happily graduated, I will travel the U.S., visiting and working at sustainable communities/ecovillages to continue learning and teaching what I have learned through this project. The knowledge just keeps on flowin! The thought of seeing the world, meeting and talking to amazing people throughout the U.S., all while tiptoeing for my ecological footprint brings me so much joy and hope. There are so many possibilities and new technologies that can be embraced in order to live a healthy and happy life that leaves the planet not only the same as how we left it, but in even better shape. This core idea is what inspires me the most.


If you would like see what I have learned and done so far, then I'd be tickled pink for you to look at my blog: http://getagirloffthegrid.wordpress.com/
This is where I will keep an active online journal of the work I do on the RV as well as document my travels and future projects that come along the way. Isn't this an exciting journey?????

story:
We would like to send the Principal Speaker for ECOXIA International to the United Nations Climate Change Conference. Melanie Mullen has attended the past 4 UN Climate Change conferences and has the experience needed to be effective on the ground and effeciently work towards facillitating change.

Although there has been incredible progress within the programs established at the United Nations Climate Change Conferences, this year is particularily sensitive. Canada has been leading the dismissal of a a policy described as "common but differentiated responsibility", wherein developed countries have a moral obligation to share their green technologies and sustainable development research/knowledge/resources with developing countries. This policy enables development and lifestyle improvements for developing nations, while also supporting the new green economy. 

Without this principal we will lose all the traction we have made over the years, and climate justice will never be attained.

 

 

ECOXIA Blog http://ecoloj2007.wix.com/ecoxia/apps/blog/page/2

Principal Speaker Melanie Mullen's Blog  www.melaniemullen.com 

United Nations Climate Change Conference COP 18 http://unfccc.int/meetings/doha_nov_2012/meeting/6815.php 

http://www.cop18.qa/en-us/homepage.aspx

The 18th session of the Conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC and the 8th session of the Conference of the Parties serving as the Meeting of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol will take place from Monday, 26 November to Friday, 7 December 2012 at the Qatar National Convention Centre in Doha, Qatar.

story:
What the hell is going on?

Our names are Marc and Cassie. We are two chronically sleep-deprived university students from Chicago with shared passions for travel, design, and creating impact (and trees!). Despite only having met a year ago, we've hatched a few crazy plans in such short time. As two relative strangers, our first conversation included the usual courtesies... then quickly devolved into the mutual decision that driving a vehicle only describable as the bastard child between a Vespa and a wheelbarrow across the majority of the Indian subcontinent would be a superb idea. So we signed up with these people, emptied our bank accounts into some plane tickets, and disregarded our friends' warnings about traveling, let alone driving a rickshaw, across India.

And so here we are, in India, in a ridiculously slow internet cafe, backpacks loaded with zip ties, duct tape, pills of all sorts, a few cameras, and some clothes. To say that we are excited would be an understatement, to say we're shitting ourselves with anticipation is closer to the truth. Fittingly, some say we should anticipate shitting ourselves. Cassie says we packed the right pills to prevent that.


Cool Earth

We can't make much of an impact on the ground (we'll be too busy keeping our rickshaw out of a ditch), but we want to make a difference somewhere. Your contribution to Cool Earth can help turn this trip into a force for positive change.
Cool Earth is a kickass organization that works alongside indigenous communities to halt rainforest destruction. Cool Earth saves at-risk rainforest and shields millions of acres of neighbouring forest. They put local people back in control, giving them the resources they need to keep their forest intact. (For example, they help the local communities take legal control of their forest by securing the land tenure.)
Learn more at:
www.coolearth.org


What We Need & What You Get

We need more trees. You can save a tree for less than 5 dollars ($4.69 to be precise). What a steal! The goal we've set ($1,500) can save more than 16 acres of rainforests.

Everything we raise goes directly to Cool Earth (minus the tiny Indiegogo processing fee). We take none for ourselves.

At least 90% of each donation to Cool Earth goes directly to their projects.

In return for your generous support, you get to be a part of our adventure from the safety of your own home along with your pick of the perks on the side. AND you get the satisfaction of saving trees in an ethical, human-centered approach. 


Risks & Challenges

We'll try to meet our timeline. Internet and post offices may be few and far between. Assuming we survive the trip, you'll get what you pay for as soon as we can get it to you. :)


Follow Our Journey

We'll be posting when the internet gods allow. Keep up with us at: 
dontcurrybehappy.wordpress.com

story:
Hi, we are Provita, a conservation NGO in Venezuela (www.provita.org.ve).
Part of our team just got accepted to join the Climate Reality Leadership Corps Training in Brazil on November 4-6. The training is led by Al Gore and will help us create many projects to promote awareness and direct action on climate change at schools, communities and universities here in Venezuela. Furthermore, we’ll be able to train more volunteers and multiply this effort!

Your support will help us cover some of the travel costs; the training costs are entirely covered by Climate Reality. You can keep updated on our training and all our work for climate, endangered species and ecosystems through our web page or @provita_ong. Help us become Climate Leaders!

story:
A looming food crisis can be averted by supporting pollinators at this critical time. We can turn the tide on "Colony Collapse Disorder," the name given to the modern phenomenon of disappearing honeybees. It's a race against industry. We must prevail, because--let's face it-- our comfort depends upon it. 


We are Rorie and Raine of Abundant Harvest Apiary in western Massachusetts. 

http://abundantharvestapiary.com/


We take pride in raising healthy bees to meet todays challenging conditions. We all thrive when honeybees thrive. Our future is intricately tied to the future of the honeybee-- literally and collectively. 



Raine & Rorie with Zeke. (Raine Brown)


Synopsis:


Honeybee populations have been decimated in recent years by the introduction of systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides. 


Honeybees and other flying creatures have also been compromised by EMF radiation associated with cell phones, cell towers, and Wi-Fi.


These challenges are not going away. Even if systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides were banned outright today, much of our soil is contaminated with them from many years of use, and the half-life of these compounds can be twenty years or more.


The EMF radiation and Wi-Fi issues could perhaps be mitigated by using different frequencies, if we could get government and industry to acknowledge the issues and engage a national conversation to address them. Meanwhile, cell phone and Wi-Fi use are increasingly necessary components of our communications infrastructure--they're here to stay.


Therefore, honeybees and beekeepers need all the support and encouragement we can provide them in order for the bees to survive. Our health depends upon their health. Their ability to pollinate diverse food crops in a manner which keeps food prices stabilized supports our healthy eating habits. We can think of honeybees as today's canaries in the coal mines. Their air is our air, their toxins are our toxins. The quality of our food is indicated in the expression of their health.


It's about biodiversity and food security. (And cruelty, and hubris, and greed...)


Healthy replacement colonies, to replace honeybee hives lost to toxins and other environmental factors, are increasingly hard to come by. Many beekeepers are giving up. This dual trend of dying bees and declining numbers of beekeepers needs to be stabilized and reversed.

We raise healthy nucleus colonies to replace lost honeybee colonies, and we have a plan to expand our impact. 


1. Please support this plan by donating to our campaign. 


2. Lend your voice to other campaigns which address the effects of systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides upon pollinators: 


Friends of the Earth article and link to action page:

http://www.foe.org/news/archives/2014-02-more-than-a-half-million-people-demand-home-depot-an-2


Organic Consumers Association newsletter with link to action pages:

http://www.organicconsumers.org/bytes/ob413.html


3. Support campaigns calling for comprehensive studies on the effects of EMF radiation and Wi-Fi on honeybees, other flying creatures, and on human health. It would be foolhardy to mistake the telecom industry's successes at burying the problem as an indication that there is no problem.


The Electromagnetic Radiation Policy Institute has links to many studies:  http://emrpolicy.org/news/headlines/


Congressional Staff briefing on the Environmental and Human Health Effects of Radiofrequency Radiation, May 2007 (deferred/ignored/buried)  http://www.hese-project.org/hese-uk/en/papers/m...


Close-up of a  European honeybee, apis mellifera


A closer look:


One in three bites of food is pollinated by honeybees. Big agriculture has turned to mono crops--along with systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides--to make food production more profitable, at the expense of pollinators. Sick and dead populations of honeybees leads to sky rocketing food prices for consumers, and it's cruel. 


Rorie holding a frame of brood. (Raine Brown)


We've been studying so called "colony collapse disorder" intently for several years. Industry likes to suggest the reason for dying honeybees is a mystery, pointing to mites as the most likely culprit. 


Asian honeybees have been dealing with parasitic mites and associated viruses for over a century, and no doubt they will continue to co-evolve. The introduction of the varroa mite--along with their associated pathogens--to the Americas has dealt a crushing blow to our European honeybees.  


These populations are recovering, however, as they are interbred with their Asian, Russian and Carniolan counterparts. These foreign bees had already been introduced to the Americas because honeybee populations were decimated by modern agricultural methods, and the multi-billion-dollar California almond crop was at stake.


Russian honeybee, apis cerana. (Azman)


Although vibrant honeybee populations may die from mites alone, they also often learn to adapt--developing hygienic behaviors, such as regularly cleaning mites from themselves and each other. What's really killing them is the toxic soup of poisons designed to make crop production cheaper, at the expense of soil health, pollinator health, and human health. Weakened health compromises honeybee immunity, enabling opportunistic infections to take hold.


By breeding bees at organic farms and wild swamps, and by staying away from high fructose corn syrup (an industry standard for feeding bees, contaminated with residual pesticides) we are able to raise healthy, vigorous honeybees. 



Rorie with a thriving hive. (Raine Brown)


Our market is bee keepers in the New York and New England region in the United States, where the growing season is short and conditions often harsh. The Northeast Region is also the last stop on the commercial pollination circuit, so bees brought into the area come with toxins and pathogens from a variety of crops and thousands of miles of stress. Once here, they pass on their pathogens to existing hives. Honeybee hive losses have occurred at alarming rates in recent years--as high as 75%--with some beekeepers losing all of their hives. The trend is not abating.


EMF radiation from cell towers, cell phones, and WiFi also plays a role in the vigor of honeybee hives. Please visit our web site to read the various studies we have posted there:  http://abundantharvestapiary.com/bee-health-2/ 


Although many beekeepers report no trouble with hives in proximity to cell towers, others report obvious issues, suggesting perhaps a change in frequency can alter the balance for a hive. Honeybees have proven to be exceptionally adaptive, although we need comprehensive studies to investigate frequency thresholds, issues associated with changes in frequencies, proximity to cell towers, etc.


As with all stressors, we believe adaptation is possible, and is incumbent upon honeybee health.



Rorie with a "nuc."  (Raine Brown)


We sell nucleus colonies (five-frame starter hives, also known as "nucs") to backyard beekeepers. Healthy replacement and starter hives have been increasingly hard to come by. We make every effort to expose our bees exclusively to organic conditions, safeguarding their health, vitality, and survival. 



Rorie splitting/growing a hive. (Raine Brown)


Our bees are raised with diverse genetics to encourage survival through hybrid strength. We believe that by promoting survivor lines of honeybees, the bees have a better chance of adapting to the increasingly adverse conditions faced by pollinators. We employ integrated pest management techniques to assist our bees in challenges with parasitic mites. Honeybees reproduce quickly, raising several generations of bees within a single growing season. It is possible for healthy bees to adapt to survive in adverse conditions. Our methods help honeybees thrive.


Honeybee with sun flowers. (Alex Fisher)


Other bee suppliers sell nucleus colonies from hives that have already made the pollination circuit, from almonds to fruit trees to cranberries. They are often weakened by pesticides, fungicides and herbicides used to treat these crops.


A few of our nucs, raised exclusively for the backyard beekeeper-- the key to honeybee survival. (Rorie Woods)


Many of our competitors have collapsed along with their hives and pesticide treatment regimens. These days, the inherent risks of beekeeping as a business model translate into very high interest rates when doing business with banks. 


This is why we're looking to crowd-sourced investment to help us grow and maximize our current capacity in nucleus colony production. Every penny we make from nucleus colony sales will be re invested in the business, so that we may keep providing healthy, vibrant nucleus colonies in a sustainable manner for years to come.


Each new hive costs $200.-$300. to establish. We plan to expand our 4 current small apiaries to 6 medium sized apiaries, going from a few dozen hives to a few hundred hives. We'll be transporting breeding hives from New England in summer to Florida in winter. We economize where we can, making our own hive boxes when practical and trading pollination services for location rentals. Travel expenses are significant, though, at around $1500. per round trip, and we'll need to upgrade to a larger trailer to transport our hives and nucs, with our sights on a commercial flat bed truck.



One of our small bee yards. (Rorie Woods)


Please help us make the leap from a small scale apiary to a mid sized apiary capable of providing healthy nucs to many more beekeepers than we can service at our current capacity.


For every $10,000 we raise, we can produce another one hundred hives to distribute to backyard beekeepers. We'd like to raise $30,000 or more through this campaign. We set our campaign threshold much lower, because once we meet that goal indiegogo takes a smaller cut of the funds raised. All funds will enable us to establish more healthy hives and produce more nucleus colonies for distribution. 


A wild swarm, an indicator of honey bee health. Honey bees are inherently nonaggressive, and are least likely to sting when they are swarming.


No contribution is too small, and all will be gratefully appreciated. Although we're happy for large contributions, ANY amount will automatically enroll you for updates to our campaign, reminding you to spread the word to others who may be interested. This is a dual purpose campaign, to raise funds and to raise awareness.


Please help us foster robust honeybee populations.  Be sure to share this campaign with your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues. Thank you.
story_txt:
A looming food crisis can be averted by supporting pollinators at this critical time. We can turn the tide on "Colony Collapse Disorder," the name given to the modern phenomenon of disappearing honeybees. It's a race against industry. We must prevail, because--let's face it-- our comfort depends upon it. 

We are Rorie and Raine of Abundant Harvest Apiary in western Massachusetts. 
http://abundantharvestapiary.com/

We take pride in raising healthy bees to meet todays challenging conditions. We all thrive when honeybees thrive. Our future is intricately tied to the future of the honeybee-- literally and collectively. 

Raine & Rorie with Zeke. (Raine Brown)Synopsis:

Honeybee populations have been decimated in recent years by the introduction of systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides. 

Honeybees and other flying creatures have also been compromised by EMF radiation associated with cell phones, cell towers, and Wi-Fi.

These challenges are not going away. Even if systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides were banned outright today, much of our soil is contaminated with them from many years of use, and the half-life of these compounds can be twenty years or more.

The EMF radiation and Wi-Fi issues could perhaps be mitigated by using different frequencies, if we could get government and industry to acknowledge the issues and engage a national conversation to address them. Meanwhile, cell phone and Wi-Fi use are increasingly necessary components of our communications infrastructure--they're here to stay.
Therefore, honeybees and beekeepers need all the support and encouragement we can provide them in order for the bees to survive. Our health depends upon their health. Their ability to pollinate diverse food crops in a manner which keeps food prices stabilized supports our healthy eating habits. We can think of honeybees as today's canaries in the coal mines. Their air is our air, their toxins are our toxins. The quality of our food is indicated in the expression of their health.
It's about biodiversity and food security. (And cruelty, and hubris, and greed...)

Healthy replacement colonies, to replace honeybee hives lost to toxins and other environmental factors, are increasingly hard to come by. Many beekeepers are giving up. This dual trend of dying bees and declining numbers of beekeepers needs to be stabilized and reversed.
We raise healthy nucleus colonies to replace lost honeybee colonies, and we have a plan to expand our impact. 

1. Please support this plan by donating to our campaign. 

2. Lend your voice to other campaigns which address the effects of systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides upon pollinators: 

Friends of the Earth article and link to action page:
http://www.foe.org/news/archives/2014-02-more-than-a-half-million-people-demand-home-depot-an-2

Organic Consumers Association newsletter with link to action pages:
http://www.organicconsumers.org/bytes/ob413.html

3. Support campaigns calling for comprehensive studies on the effects of EMF radiation and Wi-Fi on honeybees, other flying creatures, and on human health. It would be foolhardy to mistake the telecom industry's successes at burying the problem as an indication that there is no problem.
The Electromagnetic Radiation Policy Institute has links to many studies:  http://emrpolicy.org/news/headlines/

Congressional Staff briefing on the Environmental and Human Health Effects of Radiofrequency Radiation, May 2007 (deferred/ignored/buried)  http://www.hese-project.org/hese-uk/en/papers/m...

Close-up of a  European honeybee, apis mellifera
A closer look:

One in three bites of food is pollinated by honeybees. Big agriculture has turned to mono crops--along with systemic pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides--to make food production more profitable, at the expense of pollinators. Sick and dead populations of honeybees leads to sky rocketing food prices for consumers, and it's cruel. 

Rorie holding a frame of brood. (Raine Brown)
We've been studying so called "colony collapse disorder" intently for several years. Industry likes to suggest the reason for dying honeybees is a mystery, pointing to mites as the most likely culprit. 

Asian honeybees have been dealing with parasitic mites and associated viruses for over a century, and no doubt they will continue to co-evolve. The introduction of the varroa mite--along with their associated pathogens--to the Americas has dealt a crushing blow to our European honeybees.  

These populations are recovering, however, as they are interbred with their Asian, Russian and Carniolan counterparts. These foreign bees had already been introduced to the Americas because honeybee populations were decimated by modern agricultural methods, and the multi-billion-dollar California almond crop was at stake.Russian honeybee, apis cerana. (Azman)Although vibrant honeybee populations may die from mites alone, they also often learn to adapt--developing hygienic behaviors, such as regularly cleaning mites from themselves and each other. What's really killing them is the toxic soup of poisons designed to make crop production cheaper, at the expense of soil health, pollinator health, and human health. Weakened health compromises honeybee immunity, enabling opportunistic infections to take hold.

By breeding bees at organic farms and wild swamps, and by staying away from high fructose corn syrup (an industry standard for feeding bees, contaminated with residual pesticides) we are able to raise healthy, vigorous honeybees. 

Rorie with a thriving hive. (Raine Brown)Our market is bee keepers in the New York and New England region in the United States, where the growing season is short and conditions often harsh. The Northeast Region is also the last stop on the commercial pollination circuit, so bees brought into the area come with toxins and pathogens from a variety of crops and thousands of miles of stress. Once here, they pass on their pathogens to existing hives. Honeybee hive losses have occurred at alarming rates in recent years--as high as 75%--with some beekeepers losing all of their hives. The trend is not abating.

Although many beekeepers report no trouble with hives in proximity to cell towers, others report obvious issues, suggesting perhaps a change in frequency can alter the balance for a hive. Honeybees have proven to be exceptionally adaptive, although we need comprehensive studies to investigate frequency thresholds, issues associated with changes in frequencies, proximity to cell towers, etc.
As with all stressors, we believe adaptation is possible, and is incumbent upon honeybee health.

Rorie with a "nuc."  (Raine Brown)

Rorie splitting/growing a hive. (Raine Brown)

We believe that by promoting survivor lines of honeybees, the bees have a better chance of adapting to the increasingly adverse conditions faced by pollinators. We employ integrated pest management techniques to assist our bees in challenges with parasitic mites. Honeybees reproduce quickly, raising several generations of bees within a single growing season. It is possible for healthy bees to adapt to survive in adverse conditions. Our methods help honeybees thrive.

Honeybee with sun flowers. (Alex Fisher)

This is why we're looking to crowd-sourced investment to help us grow and maximize our current capacity in nucleus colony production. One of our small bee yards. (Rorie Woods)

Please help us make the leap from a small scale apiary to a mid sized apiary capable of providing healthy nucs to many more beekeepers than we can service at our current capacity.

We'd like to raise $30,000 or more through this campaign. We set our campaign threshold much lower, because once we meet that goal indiegogo takes a smaller cut of the funds raised. All funds will enable us to establish more healthy hives and produce more nucleus colonies for distribution.

No contribution is too small, and all will be gratefully appreciated. Although we're happy for large contributions, ANY amount will automatically enroll you for updates to our campaign, reminding you to spread the word to others who may be interested. This is a dual purpose campaign, to raise funds and to raise awareness.

Please help us foster robust honeybee populations.  Be sure to share this campaign with your friends, family, neighbors, and colleagues. Thank you.

story:
DZANGA SANGHA

We run and own Sangha Lodge, a small eco-friendly Lodge in The Dzanga Sangha special reserve in CAR. For the last four years we have struggled to establish the lodge in an area of vital conservation importance, and had started to make a real contribution to the local economy, development and conservation.

We believe very strongly that our return to Sangha Lodge is vital to increasing local people’s confidence in the conservation efforts and will be a huge lift in Morale in the area, all this is vital to prevent a spiral in the relationship between the current conservation staff and the local population they police.

POACHING OF ELEPHANTS AND BUSH MEAT

Since having left the region after the coup d'état of March 23 this year Conservation has taken a second place in people’s lives. Apart from the big slaughter of 26 elephants in Dzanga bai on May 6 by Sudanese poachers, there is evidence that the local people have taken to poaching bush meat in a manner far worse than previously, and we believe that it’s a matter of time before they start to kill more elephants.

ELEPHANT CONSERVATION

The importance of a western presence in the area is vital for the morale of the local population and hence the conservation effort, and you can help us make this happen. This is a hugely important area for elephant conservation, as well as Gorillas and a host of other species.

Your contributions will go directly to:

  • Supporting the 20 families working for Sangha lodge therby discouraging them from exploiting the forest or poaching the wildlife.[$2000 per month]
  • Supporting our local community projects that were previously funded with profits and donations from tourism and tourists. [$1100 per month]
  • Independent monitoring of the area, the conservation efforts, the political issues and reporting on these.[$1000 per month for car rental and fuel]
  • Running and maintaining the lodge and improving tourist facilities for the return of tourism. [$1500 per month]
  • The cost of travel .[$3000]for Rod Cassidy and his subsistence[$500 per month] for the coming months

We need to get in $ 40 000, this will cover the expense of getting to Dzanga Sangha and all our expenses for the coming 6 months, by which time we hope to be functional again and be welcoming tourist for the new year, we are taking no salary or benefit for ourselves and working for love and passion for the time we are fully committed to the Dzanga Sangha region and to the survival of our eco-Tourism project.

Any money raised will be valued, and should we not reach our goal we will use whatever money raised to return to Dzanga Sangha and to and continue with our work until the money runs out.

We ask all of you who can help with a donation no matter how small to contribute, and if you cannot help us financially please share this with as many like-minded people as possible.

Anyone who knows us personally please feel free to vouch for us in your comments, we are sincere and dedicated, and totally committed to conservation

story:
CLICK > above video to understand why this expedition is important 

 

SAILING the North Atlantic Ocean on a Sea Voyage to Study PLASTIC POLLUTION

From June 6-17, 2013, I will be traveling to Bermuda to sail to Newport, RI, through the North Atlantic Ocean Gyre with 12 other individuals. The voyage is intended to collect and study plastic pollution that has made its way from land to the middle of the ocean. 

 

Did you Know?

Did you know that plastic is being consumed by fish AND making its way up the food chain to your dinner table?  HELP! This important global problem not only effects the health of marine ecosystems, but also all of our health and welfare as well.

That is why, I am headed out to sea for an expedition to study the impact of plastic pollution in the North Atlantic Ocean and to support in increasing our understanding and awareness. I will be guest crewing aboard the SeaDragon, a 72 ft research vessel run by Pangaea Explorations, with the 5 Gyres Institute acting as its scientific partner.

 
Together, we will travel out to the “North Atlantic Garbage Patch”. This is an area that traps man-made marine debris, aka plastic waste, in the ocean similar to the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch" in the North Pacific, as shown in the above video.

This image shows the type of work I will be preforming at sea 

So What's This All About, Anyway?

The purpose of this expedition is to bring together business leaders, filmmakers, scientists, ocean lovers, and activists to conduct scientific research and increase public awareness on issues related to plastic pollution in our oceans.

This voyage will allow me to explore first-hand the effects of plastic marine debris in the ocean and how waste collects in the ocean's gyres. Working with lead scientists, I will also learn how these areas are mapped and analyzed.

While at sea, I will be conducting research, writing, and capturing photos, video, and art inspired by ocean plastics to share the experience through future talks and presentations.

 

Why Help?

I have reserved a spot on SeaDragon, but cost is prohibitive. VANS is generously covering the cost for the voyage itself of $3000, and I am raising approximately $2500, for my travels and expenses to and from boarding SeaDragon. Any funding over the goal will be happily received and used to support working with NGO's and organizations to bridge the gap between activists, cause and company in creating win-win solutions that drive a sustainable resource rich economy forward. Any help is greatly appreciated and I will reward those who can help pitch in for a cleaner ocean!

Who is the 5 Gryes Insititute?

The 5 Gyres Institute is a 501 (c) 3, non-profit organization dedicated to conducting research on plastic pollution and building public awareness around plastic pollution issues. The expedition begins in Bermuda and travels to Newport RI, and then on to Woods Hole, MA.

http://5gyres.org

Okay, Okay So What are the Perks?

Great perks have been come up to offer the voyage's generous donors. Take a look at the list on the right side of your screen.

How Else Can You Help, You Ask?

A BIG way you can help is to SHARE THIS LINK:

igg.me/at/Karen-Expedition

So, post it to your Facebook wall, tweet about it, email your friends, send messangers on horseback, whatever your thing is.

story:
Short Summary

Hi everybody! Thanks for coming this far and actually reading what this is about. 

Well, it's about closing the loop for the mobile industry, in Africa (Ghana, to start with). Because the mobile phone we all love (OK, most of us) and that has given the world so much also has a downside, which you find at the end of its life cycle. Because on the entire African continent, recycling a phone is just not possible (due to the huge costs of a recycling plant). Considering the hazardous (but some of it also valuable) metals and components in a phone, the waste stream is really becoming a health and environmental problem. That's why created awareness campaigns and started collecting the scrap phones and bringing them to the world's best recyclers. 120.000 pieces so far. Now, we want to grow and reach the goal of 1 million phones. 

Care to help?

I worked at commercial and non-profit organizations, but found that the combination rocks for me: social business. I think we created a business model that only has benefits. It makes the mobile industry, that's so important for Africa, greener and cleaner. If we can it happen in Ghana, Africa is next, with around 150 million mobile phones being thrown away every year!

What We Need & What You Get

The 30.000 euro is needed to fill a container with scrap phones (around 100.000 of them). This quantity makes it worthwhile to ship the phones. My partner, a Ghanaian that I have worked with in the last two years, will collect the phones from phone shops, repair companies and people's homes. We are the first to offer a practical solution to this growing problem!

While collecting the end-of-life phone, we also set up awareness campaigns about the recycling of electronics, like we did in Uganda (see: http://bit.ly/PVaLvs). We were the first to do this in Africa as well! Our approach is bottom up; help people clean up their country and not wait for governments and multinationals to finish their endless conversations about possible measures.

So, if we get 30.000 euro; we can finance scrap collectors in Ghana to fill a container, and after that (with the revenues of the metals in the phones), another one, and another... (if we get less than 30.000 euro, the money will of course also be used to collect scrap and I will work to get the rest of the funds needed for a whole container, or ship a not fully loaded one).

We do not pay out employees of our foundation, or use this money for any of the costs we incur. Just to collect scrap and set up awareness campaigns. I hope this will lead to people and companies becoming involved in the electronic waste reduction and perhaps in 5 year lead to the first recycler to start recycling complete mobile phones in Africa!

The Impact

The mobile industry is delivering great value, both social and financial, around the world and is getting countries like Ghana connected to the world for the first time (fixed lines and internet cables did not have the same impact in Africa as in other places around the world). But with 600 million mobile users on the African continent, there should be some ways to safely get rid of a phone, when it can’t be used anymore. But there isn’t…

Awareness on recycling and the need and opportunities for mobile phone end-of-life processes need to become commonplace for people in Ghana and the rest of Africa. We need to expand the work that we have done and start a movement that changes the mobile industry for the better; bottom up, and with a benefit for everyone.   

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make sure to have your old phones re-used or recycled
  • Remind electronics producers that they have responsibilities, also in Africa
  • If you want; promote my campaign (the Indiegogo share tools are also great)

mobile phone end-of-life processes need to become commonplace for people in
Ghana and the rest of Africa. We need to expand the work that we have done and
start a movement that changes the mobile industry for the better; bottom up, and
with a benefit for everyone.    
Other Ways You Can Help

Make sure to have your old phones re-used or
     recycled
Remind electronics producers that they have
     responsibilities, also in Africa 
If you want; promote my campaign (the Indiegogo
     share tools are also great)

story:
Short Summary

We, at Orlando Green, have been working on this project for the last four years.  We have had the ups and downs of getting such a project off the ground.  This project, when up and running, will divert 200,000 tons of garbage away from landfill and recycle it, every year.  Every ton diverted saves 2.2 tons of carbon.  We will create electricity from the waste thus saving 200,000 tons of coal or oil from being used.  We will prevent 4,000,000 tons of Green House Gas emissions, every year, from landfill because of diverting that waste.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $15,000,000 to get this project started.  The total cost is $75,000,000 for the three full plant phases.  The recycling center is phase one and requires $15,000,000 in full to get it operational.  Permits are currently in the process of being applied for.  A site in Orlando identified.  Eager contractors, including the City of Orlando, looking for an alternative to landfill.
  • Phase two ($50,000,000) will be to manufacture the Synthesis Gas from Pyrolysis (cracking-like in a refinery) that will then be used as a fuel to power the generators that will produce the electricity.
  • Phase three ($10,000,000) will be a tire recycling plant that will turn the waste tires into electricity.
  • We will create Carbon Credits that are traded worldwide.  A ton of coal used to create electricity generates 2.2 tons of carbon.  1 ton of garbage used to make electricity creates 2.2 Carbon Credits because we avoid using coal.  Become a part of a project that will let you see your benefits in the credits you will help to create.
  • All funds received through this campaign will be used in this project.   You will help to reduce the amount we need to borrow.
  • See the benefits to you personally in our Perks section below.

The Impact

With the drive to reduce Green House Gases, our oil, our coal and other fossil fuels that are non replaceable, this project will be the first of many to show that our garbage is worth diverting from just dumping it in a landfill.

Benefits per site constructed:

  • 50 full time jobs created in a green industry
  • 200,000 tons of garbage a year turned into recyclables instead of being dumped in a landfill
  • 400,000+ Carbon Credits a year created instead of carbon pollution and Green House gases being created.
  • Provide Green Electricity to power 6,240 Floridian homes every year

Other Ways You Can Help

It is time to stop piling garbage into landfill mountains.  Let us cut down on fossil fuels by using this garbage instead, and recycling it into useful everyday needs like electricity. 

Get the word out.  Turn our Country Green.

story:
We are Lil Lotus CoFFee team: Lyla, Ryoma, Campbell, Jazz & Andreas. We follow the adolescent program at Montessori School Bali.

We represent the next generation , and as such, learning about sustainability & how we can improve the planet will be key for the future.

Business is part of our curriculum. We partnered up with su-re.co & their sustainable coffee, helping local farmers with clean energy & climate education.

The skills we have gained from this whole experience include organisation, marketing, communication, time management, research, science, mathematics & problem solving. Our learning is academic & authentic in nature.

We would like to thank su-re.co team so much for their help & support. Enabling us to visit directly farmers was an experience we will never forget.

 

 

In oRder to keep their important work going, please donate to su-re.co crowdfunding campaign. Money that is raised will go directly into educating farmers.

Lil Lotus CoFFee would like to donate $35 USD to the campaign.

 

 

30% of Indonesians - roughly the total population of Germany - are farmers  and impacted by climate change because of rising temperatures, decreasing rain precipitations, e.g. ca. 1°C hotter since 1990.


30% of Indonesians live off primary biomass energy such as firewood. Indonesia is now one of the biggest greenhouse gas emitting countries in the world, people are even suffering from unhealthy smoke!


Coffee farms are a great start for the use of biogas. The farmer can utilise organic fertiliser and use the clean gas, adapting to become ‘climate smart’.

 

Pak Cakra, coffee farmer in Jembrana, West Bali.

 

 

Sustainable coffee: Selling coffee beans bought at a fair price directly from farmers to raise funds.

 

Climate field school: Hosting farmers through the school at every village we buy coffee beans from, to teach climate-smart agriculture.

 

Biogas and organic agriculture: Installing biogas digesters to produce clean renewable energy and organic fertilisers for farmers.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2 million smallholders coffee farmers living in remote villages across the country.


1 million biogas digesters are needed in Indonesia, estimated by biogas experts, BIRU.

 

A conventional fixed biogas digester costs approximately $1000 USD including installation and training. Our easily transportable digester costs $300 USD including installation and training without subsidy.

 

 

When the price of our biogas digesters is fixed ($300USD), the total cost of climate field school depends on elements like location, audience etc. Hence the figures regarding climate field school are only estimations.

 

 

6 Climate Field Schools were hosted by su-re.co with BMKG (Indonesian Meteorological Climatology and Geophysics Agency) in 2018.


$300 USD biogas digesters were developed by su-re.co for 2 years and prototypes were installed to farmers. A conventional fixed biogas digester cost approximately $1000 USD including installation and training.

 

 

36% less rainfall in East Indonesia compared to the national average - this will only get worse.

 

su-re.coffee is a result of European Union's GreenWin & TRANSRisk projects, case study mixing science and policy-making for climate change mitigation and adaptation all around the world. Our project represented Indonesia.


120+ international experts, policy makers, and farmers engaged in 3 bioenergy & climate change workshops in Bali hosted by su-re.co, to formulate this strategy.


40+ international scientific journal publications by su-re.co members and collaboration with world renowned institutions.

 

Climate field school in Jembrana, West Bali, April 2018. 

 

 

Minimum target (100%) = $15.000 USD

25%: Biogas digesters installation & Climate field schools.

25%: Re-investment & Management fee.

50%: Sustainable coffee operations.

 

Pak Ketut, cocoa farmer in Bali using a biogas digester installed by su-re.co

su-re.coffee: sustainability from bean to cup

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Together su-re.co and Montessori School Bali's adolescent class have worked cooperatively to conduct the Café Project; development of a green business emphasising the importance of tackling climate change.


After a field trip directly at the farm in Jembrana, West Bali, visiting Pak Cakra, one of su-re.coffee farmers, Lil Lotus’ coFFee team developed their own business model and marketing strategy to promote sustainable coffee.


We are deeply humbled and empowered by what these students have already accomplished, and will continue to do in the future.

 

                                        

Rotary Club Canggu and su-re.co are working together to host local famers through climate field schools. The Rotary Club focuses on sustainability, education and growing the local economy. With raising awareness and fundraising, the club is directly facilitating farmers in their schooling to become climate smart, thus tackling climate change. We are thrilled to continuously expand the project in the future. 

 

 

 

 

su-re.coffee crowdfunding campaign already received a generous $5000 USD promise of backing from FOUR SEASONS RESORT Bali at Jimbaran Bay, awarded as the best resort in the world in 2018. This is equivalent to 3 more biogas digesters installed in 3 more Indonesian farms! We are over the moon with this good news and look forward for the customers of the resort to try our sustainable coffee. THANK YOU!

 

 

su-re.coffee is a result of European Union's GreenWin & TRANSRisk projects, without whose support su-re.coffee wouldn't have been possible at all. THANK YOU!

The Rotary Club focuses on sustainability, education and growing the local economy. With raising awareness and fundraising, the club is directly facilitating farmers in their schooling to become climate smart, thus tackling climate change. We are thrilled to continuously expand the project in the future.     su-re.coffee crowdfunding campaign already received a generous $5000 USD promise of backing from FOUR SEASONS RESORT Bali at Jimbaran Bay, awarded as the best resort in the world in 2018. This is equivalent to 3 more biogas digesters installed in 3 more Indonesian farms! We are over the moon with this good news and look forward for the customers of the resort to try our sustainable coffee. THANK YOU!  su-re.coffee is a result of European Union's GreenWin & TRANSRisk projects, without whose support su-re.coffee wouldn't have been possible at all.
