story:
Transfrontier Africa founded the Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit (APU) in 2013 to protect the Olifants West Region of Balule Nature Reserve. Within the first year of operation the Black Mambas were invited to expand into other regions and now protect all boundaries of Balule Nature Reserve.

Where We Operate

Balule Nature Reserve is part of the Associated Private Nature Reserves (APNR) that forms a contractual component of the Greater Kruger National Park. Our Western Region has been registered with the National and Provincial governments as a component of the national protected areas network.  This is an open system of about 186,000ha, which further joins the 2,800,000ha of the Kruger National Park, totaling roughly three million hectares of unfenced African savannah! We thus supply protection to all the wild animals that roam freely throughout Balule Private Nature Reserve, and safe-guard the most western region of Kruger Park.

Balule are the proud custodians of Black and White Rhinoceros which interact freely as part of the Greater Kruger National Park’s meta-population of rhino.

Poaching

Commercial poaching has become big business, thanks to the boom in populations and the “new wealth” in Asia. Consumption of products derived from endangered species is flourishing be it for ‘Medicinal’ purposes, trinkets and status symbols or just simply to be on the menu. Subsequently rhino poaching has escalated dramatically in recent years and is being driven by the demand for rhino horn in Asian countries, particularly Vietnam and China, due to its use as a status symbol to display someone’s success and wealth and in Traditional Chinese Medicine. Although there is no scientific proof of its medicinal value, rhino horn is still highly prized in traditional Asian medicine. It is ground into a fine powder or manufactured into tablets as a treatment for a variety of illnesses such as nosebleeds, strokes, convulsions, and fevers. Despite intensive conservation efforts, poaching of this iconic species is still increasing across South Africa and pushing the remaining rhinos closer and closer towards extinction. If the killing continues at the same rate, we could see rhino deaths overtaking births in 2016-2018, meaning rhinos will go extinct in the very near future.

The Bigger Picture

Transfrontier Africa’s anti-poaching initiative operates on the following 3 levels:

Level 1 - The Black Mamba Unarmed Unit: Routine procedures such as foot-patrols, observations, vehicle checks and road blocks allow this team to fulfill the visual policing component of this unit, making them the, “bobby’s on the beat”. The Black Mamba teams are comprised of well-trained women with excellent communication skills and a genuine passion for wildlife.

Level 2 - Armed Unit: A team of armed guards that protect the borders of Balule and operate off-reserve as a counter-insurgency measure. They also lend support to private rhino owners close to the borders of the Greater Kruger National Park and patrol the “buffer-zone” between these fences. In addition, we have the on-reserve team of well-trained and experienced armed rangers that are deployed in the high-risk areas. This team is split into smaller well-equipped foot patrols and ambush stations that move between strategically positioned picket stations.

Level 3. - Senior Management: Responsible for deployment strategies and networking. To better manage communications and information that is passed between the teams via the Operations Room. The movements of all Units and Rangers are monitored in real-time.

The success of this 3-tiered strategy has seen the following benefits:

1. Constant visual policing on all servitude roads and boundaries.

2. Low level of internal corruption.

3. High success rate with counter-insurgency measures (off-reserve).

4. Strong support from neighbouring rhino owners adjacent to the Greater Kruger.

Our Objectives

When you hear the words anti-poaching unit, what’s the first thing that comes into your mind? Poachers... Guns... Snares... War... Rhino Horn... Ivory? The Black Mambas is much more than just an anti-poaching unit. Whilst our main objective is the security of the reserve and the protection of wildlife, we also strive tocreate a strong bond and educate the communities that live on the boundaries of Balule and the Greater Kruger Park to the benefits of saving their natural heritage. It is our belief that the ‘war’ on poaching will not be won with guns and bullets, but through social upliftment and the education of local communities surrounding the reserves.

Social Upliftment

Transfrontier Africa acts in its capacity as a host agent on behalf of the Extended Public Works Program that aims to address unemployment and assist with skills development in South Africa.  SANParks administers and accommodates the salaries of all our rangers through this program. All Black Mamba recruits are from local, previously disadvantaged communities and go through a rigorous 6 week training programme prior to deployment with an existing unit to further their training through work experience.

Education

The Bushbabies Environmental Education Awareness Program

The Lesser bushbaby (Galago moholi) symbolises and defines the external environmental education awareness program, where learners are regarded as babies learning about the bush or environment. The Bushbabies Program is interlinked into the curriculum of local schools which should build on the children’s interests and should explore the subject matter in a multi-disciplinary manner; therefore we should enhance a child’s skills and build on their present ideas about conservation through a program that provides for a multitude of opportunities for the child’s growth and development. The objectives of this program are to bring knowledge to life, raise awareness of their surrounding environment, give a better understanding of conservation, lead to sustainable use of resources and install environmental problem-solving skills and ultimately installing an ethical ethos in our future generations.

Rhino Conservation

Transfrontier Africa in conjunction with Balule Nature Reserve, has an active rhino research program which is designed to investigate the effectiveness of the “Rhino range expansion program” and all other aspects of rhino management and protection based on scientific investigation. Transfrontier Africa's responsibilities have extended to cover the entire 50'000 hectares of Balule and includes the daily monitoring of the rhino to design a real-time locality map of rhinos in the hot-spots and high-risk areas in order to aid in deploying the anti-poaching units effectively. The location of rhinos is deduced from the rhino’s movements which the Black Mambas monitor daily through the use of VHF & GPS transmitters. All of this information is captured then collaborated on GIS and mapped for immediate dispersal to management and anti-poaching units prior to shift changes. This ensures that all anti-poaching units are deployed in the correct areas to protect the rhino.

Anti-Poaching

Our dedicated teams are constantly deployed and managed. Searching for and destroying poacher’s camps, wire-snares and bush meat kitchens every day. Aerial support, specialist dogs, early detection and rapid response is all that stands between the poachers and our wildlife and technology is our biggest ally.  The Black Mambas have assisted in 5 arrests, identified and destroyed over 19 poachers’ camps and three bush meat kitchens within the ‘Buffer-Zone’ bordering Balule Nature Reserve and reduced snaring and poisoning activities by 76% within our area of operation since their deployment in 2013. Furthermore, they have been responsible for the early detection of poaching insurgents during their daily patrols which have allowed our armed units to thwart attempts to poach rhino in our area. 

The Black Mamba APU relies heavily on donations. Whilst SANParks funds the Black Mambas salaries through the Extended Public Works Program, all other costs including their training, equipment, uniforms, transport and daily operational costs are funded through donations.

story:
This campaign will close at the end of the day on January 6. If you wish to donate after January 6, you can do so starting January 8 at: www.ecotippingpoints.org/mvdonate.

 

This little turtle...

And these tiny fish...

And these citizen-scientists...

have eliminated mosquito production in their community. They haven't seen a case of dengue fever, chikungunya, or Zika here in more than two years. 

With your help, they can take their life-saving knowledge to other communities in Honduras, while they can  to keep their own families healthy and their community mosquito-free. 

>Even $10 to $20+ donated can help provide supplies, support, and training for volunteers.<

What life is like when the tap only flows a few hours a week

Imagine that all the water you need in a month — all the water for everything except drinking —keeping your home clean, washing your dishes and clothes, showering, bathing your children — everything — only flowed out of the tap for a couple of hours each week.

You’d get really, really good at managing water. You’d treat every drop as though it were precious. On those days when the tap flowed, you’d fill every available vessel to have enough to last until it flowed again. 

Unfortunately, those storage vessels are the perfect breeding ground for mosquitoes and the diseases they bring. Chikungunya, which causes debilitating fever and excruciating joint pain. Dengue fever, which can be fatal to children. And Zika, which can lead to the heartbreak of microcephaly in babies. Chemical insecticides don’t seem to be effective, plus they have their own dangers.

This was the reality for the people of a humble village in Honduras called Monte Verde . But not anymore.

Monte Verde’s success is historic and game-changing

In three years, an international charity, a program developed by scientists, and community effort have eradicated mosquito production and mosquito-borne diseases in Monte Verde. It's the only instance we know of this happening anywhere in Latin America in decades. 

Instead of using expensive, ineffective, and dangerous pesticides, the Monte Verde Project developed a system of biological control to eradicate the mosquitoes. The system works with two strategies: 

  1. Introducing baby turtles, young tilapia, and tiny shrimp-like predators called copepods to each household’s stored water. These animals eat every mosquito larva. They’re very inexpensive and can do an excellent job if people know how to use them. 
  2. Developing a program to maintain these animals in the water storage containers. Community volunteers have become citizen-scientists for mosquito eradication. They visit every home at least once a month to make sure that all of their neighbors are doing it right. They offer advice and assistance wherever it’s needed.

The Monte Verde Project has been a stunning success. Mosquito production is zero. And Monte Verde has been completely free of mosquito-borne diseases for more than two years. In fact, there has not been a single case in Monte Verde despite a raging dengue fever epidemic in neighboring communities this year.

Now Monte Verde needs your help. 

The Monte Verde Project is moving into a new phase. Monte Verde’s mosquito eradication experts are starting to work as educators, facilitators, and trainers, not only to keep their own community protected, but also to extend the same success to other communities. 

However, the support from the nonprofit organization that got the Monte Verde Project started has now ended, so the Project needs a new source of support to move forward with its lifesaving work. 

Donate today to make a big difference. Your donation will literally and immediately save lives — not just in Monte Verde, but elsewhere in Honduras and Latin America. 

EcoTipping Points is an American 501c3 nonprofit organization that documents and shares environmental success stories from around the world (www.ecotippingpoints.org), so others can use lessons from the stories to deal effectively with their own environmental problems. The Monte Verde Project is one of those stories (http://ecotippingpoints.org/our-stories/indepth/honduras-community-eradication-aedes-aegypti-dengue-zika.html). EcoTipping Points is conducting a fundraising campaign to support the Monte Verde Project so it can equip and train other communities to achieve the same success. 100% of the tax-deductible donations to this campaign will go directly to the Monte Verde Project.

The best part about the Monte Verde Project is that every dollar you donate will magnify the lifesaving power of biological control to protect many more thousands of people. The amount that we’re seeking will get the Project’s new phase off the ground. It will enable Monte Verde’s citizen-scientists to extend biological control immediately to neighboring communities. And it will lay the foundation for expanding effective and sustainable mosquito eradication to other parts of Honduras and Latin America as well. 

How we will spend the money we raise.

A $10 donation will pay for ten baby turtles. A $30 donation will support a Project worker for several days, providing transportation to reach  other communities, supplies (e.g., flashlights, mosquito traps, and training materials), and additional support needed to do the job. A $250 donation will support the entire project for a day.

Any amount you can give will mean a great deal to the lives and health of many families. You’ll know that you’re making a lifesaving difference for hundreds or thousands of families — not just someday, but right now.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word among friends, family, and colleagues. Share this story of eco-success, and keep it growing.
  • Share this link on social media

Any amount you can give will mean a great deal to the lives and health of many families. You’ll know that you’re making a lifesaving difference for hundreds or thousands of families — not just someday, but right now.

story:
Bee the Change


What's the Buzz?

The American Honey Bee Protection Agency (AHBPA) is a non-profit organization dedicated to saving the honey bees. These amazing creatures are threatened with extinction, which is endangering the world's agricultural resources. Bees are responsible for pollinating roughly one-third of the crops grown in the United States. Without these critical pollinators, a vast portion of our edible plants would be lost.

Scientists are working diligently to identify the cause of colony collapse disorder, a phenomenon in which worker bees abruptly disappear. In the meantime, bees are being threatened by the widespread use of toxic pesticides, hazardous bee hive removal processes and a lack of dietary biodiversity. 

AHBPA strives to save the bees by rescuing and relocating unwanted hives (our donation-based bee removal service is being replicated by others across Central Texas and the nation) and creating widespread awareness about the perilous situation they currently are in. We partner with schools, community gardens, Texas landowners, farmers and the Travis County Correctional Complex to promote bee education and bee keeper certification. Finally, we work to affect change in the Texas legislature to ensure the honey bee is protected. We believe that our legislative efforts will serve as a much needed example for other states to follow. 

AHBPA is a very small non-profit with limited resources and huge goals. We are seeking funds to expand operations, which includes hiring additional bee wranglers to work in and around Austin, Houston, Dallas and Fort Worth. We also need funds to cover basic operational costs, such as office equipment and money to pay office employee salaries. This campaign focuses on these very basic needs; future campaigns will target larger goals. 

Existing Legislative Success

We are proud of the legislative success we have had in the past and look forward to helping enact further bee-friendly changes in the near future. With your help, we can allocate funds to help us move forward with efforts to make the honey bee the official pollinator of the state of Texas, create educational requirements for bee handlers and bee removal experts in Texas and create a higher level of protection for the honey bee in Texas. 
It is AHBPA's hope that our current and future legislative successes will serve as a template for other states to use to protect one of our most valuable pollinators.
The following outlines the legislative success we have already had:
http://www.austintexas.gov/edims/document.cfm?id=165868

ORDINANCE NO. 20120322-019

AN ORDINANCE AMENDING CITY CODE CHAPTER 3-6 TO PROVIDE FOR THE RELOCATION OF WILD OR ABANDONED BEES THAT DO NOT THREATEN HUMAN OR ANIMAL HEALTH OR INTERFERE WITH THE NORMAL USE OR ENJOYMENT OF PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.

BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF AUSTIN:

PART 1. Section 3-6-22 of the City Code (Destruction of Wild or Abandoned Bees) is amended to read as follows:

§ 3-6-22 DESTRUCTION OF WILD OR ABANDONED BEES.

(A) The health authority will order relocation of bees described in Subsection (B) (1H3) if the relocation of the bees can be done without threatening human or animal health or interfering with the normal use and enjoyment of public or private property.

What Makes us Special?
We are a very unique entity in the pest control service industry that targets a niche market of bee hive removal. We are also the only company in Texas that can say we do this on a non-profit structure which allows to be used as a public service for local communities that can't afford the cost of "professional" bee removal or extermination. Additionally we can clearly show where our rescued bees are safely relocated too. 

Hive Mentality

The future of the honey bee is not any individual's sole responsibility, but if we can make a collective effort toward protecting them, in the long run we are securing our own future as well. This cause is one that contributes to the greater good of our society by helping protect and save the bees.

story:
The Story! 

Through our combined 40 years in the Service Industry we absolutely understand what it takes to run it.  There is no time to worry about the waste, when you care so much about taking care of the customers. 

We have worked tirelessly the past 9 months on our off time to create this opportunity for our local establishments to become sustainable!  We still have full time jobs in the restaurant business and helping us fund this project would allow us to move faster across the city and get all of our restaurants on board!

We promise to not stop until we can be free of waste!

________________________________________________________

What's the Skinny on Project Green Plate?

OKAY....Here's the scoop.......

PHASE 1!!!

Project Green Plate's mission is to:

"Make OKC a Sustainable Place to Eat" by taking Small Steps to Sustainability!

Our FOCUS is on LOCAL food-service & alcohol establishments.

The Vision:  To help create avenues for our Oklahoma City restaurants to become more sustainable.  Through our long history in the Industry we understand how to conserve and save $'s through recycling, water usage, energy savings, composting, and overall conservation.

RECYCLING:

In collaboration with our transportation companies, PGP coordinates the pick-up of UNSORTED, SINGLE STREAM #1-7 plastics; steel/tin; aluminum; cardboard; glass, & paper on an agreed upon schedule basis. The goal of this isn’t only sustainability, but to decrease dumpster usage by at-least 70% depending on product usage, thus decreasing operating costs!  AND PGP will be moving to composting as well in the near future, with the goal of making partner venues Dumpster Free!

Every Pickup of your recyclables is logged,and then shown on the PGP website for all of OKC to see your progress in your very own sustainability report showing the reduction in usage of water and kilowatts, a reduction in air pollutants, landfill usage reduction, and the saving of trees due to your recycling prac­tices.


MARKETING ADVANTAGES:

This sustainability is recognized and marketed through multiple channels including the most important, which is having a community image of being a caring & sustainable venue:

●  Each partner venue will receive a "Project Green Plate Certified" Cling to adhere to their business front to alert the community and patrons to their sustainable practices & involvement in the project.


•  All partner venues are part of the “Green Card”Program.

•  GreenCards are available to the public for $10 and offer specials at each partner venue, determinable by the venue. The Green Cards are also available at www.projectgreenplate.com . If bought in the establishment, $5 of the $10 is kept by the establishment!

•  HINT: Sell 1 a day and your sustainability program is virtually paid for!

•  AND Green Cards Drive Customer Traffic.

•  Partner Venues are listed on the PGP website, as well as links to their websites & any social media sites.

•  All partner venues are marketed alongside PGP on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and other social media outlets.

•  Partner Venues have collaborative advertising opportunities in the PGP monthly media packages (example: OKC Gazette,etc....) as well as being mentioned in our write-ups and articles in other local media.

•  Establishments can get partner with PGP in zero-waste and other sustainability events in order to gain visibility. PGP encourages the collaboration to build a stronger, more sustainable community.

•  All Partner Venues have opportunities to have their announcements, events, & specials sent to the every growing PGP email database and social media platforms via special announcements and/or the monthly PGP Newsletter on OKC Venue Progress! All sustainability impact reports are released in that monthly newsletter.

CONTINUED EDUCATION & HELP:

•  PGP stays engaged with your venue, to help monitor your practices and educate staff when needed.

•  PGP provides certain signage & bins to help alert patrons to correct recycling practices within the venue and to help staff use practices that help the products get to the right places.

•  PGP is releasing a monthly blog to all PGP email & social media followers, which shows OKC your sustainability report, talks about the progress of OKC, info on future local events, tips from leading sustainability experts, recognition of new partner venues, etc…..

Let's Make this a Better, More Sustainable OKC to be available to our grandchildren and their friends in the future!

PHASE 2!!!

We now have begun reducing the carbon footprint by recycling and reusing service industry wastestream,  we now are going to keep the the landfills levels down by offering our new line of biodegradable products  hopefully we will see the day we are digging the resources back out of the ground!

________________________________________________________

What We Need

Phase 1 is the UNSORTED, SINGLE STREAM RECYCLABLES PHASE. To launch Phase 1, we need $33,960. This money is needed for many parts of the project, including:

  • Legal Fees needed for contract writing and setup between PGP & the Transportation Company, PGP & the Recycling Facility, LLC Setup, among a few others....
  • Recycle Bin & Signage Purchases
  • Green Cards and other marketing needs, such as T-shirts & Clings for the Partner Venues
  • Website Build-Out and other designer fees for logo-build, cling design, T-shirt design, etc.....
  • General Living expenses for 1st 2 months

HELP US REACH PHASE 1 and Let's KEEP GOING TO REACH PHASE 2!

Phase 2 is the POST-CONSUMER Food-service Biodegradable, Compostable Product Phase. To launch phase 2, we need an extra $75,983 and this is broke up into these various costs:

  • Inventory....this is over half of the funding needs. The large inventory is needed in order to bring down the cost of goods for the passed on to the establishments.
  • Marketing
  • Insurance costs of the warehousing space and the delivery truck
  • Various Pallet Jacks, Scales, etc...
  • A Box Truck for delivery to the establishments
  • Marketing Costs both tangible and intangible 

The Impact

The IMPACT is Simple to see! You'll be able to see how every Partner Venue is doing on the PGP Website. Here's an example below!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • PGP will be doing many zero waste and recycling projects at summer festivals, Large Art Events, & more..... Many people will be needed to collaborate in these and we'll ask for your help! You can start by helping us on here!
  • Help grow PGP's Social Media Pages by inviting your friends and colleagues! 

________________________________________________________


Backer Perks

story:
This campaign is about wildlife conservation and protecting our precious open green space

A developer wants to put 170 houses on the uplands of The Tides which is linked to the habitats of Millenium Park, the wetlands on the border of Pinellas County Aqautic Park and the surrounding neighborhoods of Oakhurst Shores, Canterbury Chase & Seminole Estates. Humans & wildlife have co-existed at The Tides in harmony for 40 years & this unique green open space could be lost for ever to generations to come.

The uplands act as a filtration system for the water that comes down into The Tides.  The wetlands & mangroves at the site are really important. These waters are the beginnings of life that is significant for our ecology.  

We have a myriad of wildlife at this site, ospreys, horned owls, pileated & red bellied woodpeckers, brazilian otters, red tailed hawks, great white egrets. roseate spoonbills, sandhill cranes, wood storks. Manatees nestle in the mangroves & bald eagles have also made this their home. These animals and others need these different habitats kept intact in order to survive.

There are traffic and saftey concerns for this area. It is in a flood zone & evacuation of local residents to safety is causing real concern to the nearly 1,000 existing homes that border The Tides.

We need experts in law, water, environment, traffic, emergency access, history, and archaeology to weigh in. We need your help & support to mount our legal defence at the first public hearing in September. Become a Friend of Save The Tides and donate to the cause of wildlife conservation and green open space preservation.

Sharing this link with your friends and family is really important.

This treasured area was protected by The Pinellas County Board of Commissioners in 1985 & we need to persuade The 2013 Commsioners to carry on this legacy.

It is our turn to step up and do what we can! The public meeting dates that we are raising funds for are September 12th at 9am & October 22nd at 6pm. We need as many people as possible to turn out to show The Commissioners that the citizens of Pinellas County do not want The Tides destroyed. 

Visit us at our facebook page for more information & how you can help. It is full of up to date current information, meeting dates & what you can do to defend the loss of this treasured open green space

You can also help by signing & commenting on our on line petition at

http://petitions.moveon.org/sign/pinellas-county-save
story_txt:
This campaign is about wildlife conservation and protecting our precious open green space
A developer wants to put 170 houses on the uplands of The Tides which is linked to the habitats of Millenium Park, the wetlands on the border of Pinellas County Aqautic Park and the surrounding neighborhoods of Oakhurst Shores, Canterbury Chase & Seminole Estates. Humans & wildlife have co-existed at The Tides in harmony for 40 years & this unique green open space could be lost for ever to generations to come.
The uplands act as a filtration system for the water that comes down into The Tides.  The wetlands & mangroves at the site are really important. These waters are the beginnings of life that is significant for our ecology.  
We have a myriad of wildlife at this site, ospreys, horned owls, pileated & red bellied woodpeckers, brazilian otters, red tailed hawks, great white egrets. roseate spoonbills, sandhill cranes, wood storks. Manatees nestle in the mangroves & bald eagles have also made this their home. These animals and others need these different habitats kept intact in order to survive.
There are traffic and saftey concerns for this area. It is in a flood zone & evacuation of local residents to safety is causing real concern to the nearly 1,000 existing homes that border The Tides.
We need experts in law, water, environment, traffic, emergency access, history, and archaeology to weigh in. We need your help & support to mount our legal defence at the first public hearing in September. Become a Friend of Save The Tides and donate to the cause of wildlife conservation and green open space preservation.
Sharing this link with your friends and family is really important.
This treasured area was protected by The Pinellas County Board of Commissioners in 1985 & we need to persuade The 2013 Commsioners to carry on this legacy.
It is our turn to step up and do what we can! The public meeting dates that we are raising funds for are September 12th at 9am & October 22nd at 6pm. We need as many people as possible to turn out to show The Commissioners that the citizens of Pinellas County do not want The Tides destroyed. 
Visit us at our facebook page for more information & how you can help. It is full of up to date current information, meeting dates & what you can do to defend the loss of this treasured open green space
You can also help by signing & commenting on our on line petition at
http://petitions.moveon.org/sign/pinellas-county-save

story:
Extreme Energy is the "bottom of the barrel" kind of oil and gas projects. Many of the last pristine areas on earth are within Indigenous lands. Extreme energy includes fracking, tar sands, and deep sea off-shore drilling. Indigenous Peoples bear the brunt of extreme energy development through loss of land, clean water, and clean air. Many still live sustainably off the land.

We are raising money to bring an Indigenous delegation of First Nations and Alaska Natives living at ground zero of Shells fracking, tar sands mining-the largest human development project on earth; and proposed off-shore drilling. Your donation to this campaign will help with airfare so four Indigenous People can attend the Royal Dutch Shell Annual General Meeting (AGM) of the shareholders in The Hague, Netherlands on May 21st, 2013.  

Our goals are for Indigenous leaders to speak for themselves, to hold the shareholders accountable and put a human face to the impacts of extreme energy development. With your help we will bring international attention and remind the world there are better options than extreme energy development that destroys Indigenous communities!

$8000 is our goal!!

  • We want to pay for travel for four Indigenous People to travel from Alaska, Northern British Columbia, southwestern Ontario and Northern Alberta. Because the areas people are traveling from are more remote and not major metropolitan areas the airfare will cost the most! We hope to raise $2000.00 per person. 
  • If we were to raise more than our goal? Which would be amazing! Those funds would go to additional travel costs such as food, lodging, and ground transportation. 
  • If we dont raise our goal? We wont be able to send as many delegation members. But with your help we are hopeful that that wont happen!

Fun Perks 

  • Special edition silk screen t-shirts made with love by local Alberta organizers
  • Tar Sands lino prints donated from Montreal, PQ
  • Limited edition lino prints 
  • Donated art piece

And of course our eternal gratitude for supporting some amazing leaders work to protect their homelands and way of life!

The Impact

First Nations and Alaska Natives are leading the way forward to a future free of fossil fuel development through protecting their lands, way of life and culture. This is super strategic because its not just for Indigenous communities but for all people. We all deserve to have clean air and water. To live free from sickness like cancer which is an epidemic in some communities due to their high level of exposure to development pollution. 

With support from partner non-profit organizations such as UK Tar Sands Network, the Indigenous Tar Sands Campaign, 

Delegation members include:

Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation- (ACFN) is a Denesuline community based in Fort Chipewyan, Alberta. Its territory spans and includes lands within the Regional Municipality of Wood Buffalo, the Lower Athabasca and North West Saskatchewan planning regions. Members of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation hold rights that are protected by section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982 and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

Since time immemorial and long before ACFN entered into Treaty, Denesuline Peoples of its region lived and continue to live and sustain themselves, their families and their community from Mother Earth and all that she provides. Industrialization of ACFN’s traditional territories has lead to the cumulative removal of lands, wildlife and fish habitat as well as the destruction of ecological, aesthetic and sensory systems. This will consequently affect Treaty promises, cultural and spiritual renewal, procurement of resources, and Denesuline Peoples connection and use of landscape that is integral to traditional use.

This industrialization has thrust the ACFN to the forefront of the tar sands controversy. Canada and Alberta’s elected leaders have been promoting tar sands development on ACFN traditional lands at a pace that appears irresponsible and irreparably destructive. The Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation (ACFN) filed suit against Shell Oil Canada in September of 2011. Papers were served to Shell executives in November.

Resisting Environmental Destruction on Indigenous Lands (REDOIL) is an Alaska Native Network of the Inupiat, Yupik, Aleut, Tlingit, Eyak, Gwich’in and Denaiana Athabascan Tribes. REDOIL is a movement of Alaska Natives who are challenging the fossil fuel and mining industry and demanding our rights to a safe and healthy environment conducive to subsistence. REDOIL aims to address the human and ecological health impacts brought on by unsustainable development practices of the fossil fuel and mining industry, and the ensuing effect of catastrophic climate change. REDOIL supports the self determination right of Tribes in Alaska, as well as a just transition from fossil fuel and mineral development to sustainable economies, and sustainable development.

1. Support and Promote Tribal Self Determination and Subsistence

2. Promote Human and Ecological Health

3. Address Global Warming and Climate Justice

4. Foster Sustainable Economic Solutions

5. Promote Protection of Indigenous Homelands for Future Generations

Fort Nelson First Nation- delegate to be confirmed

Aamjiwnaag First Nation -Surrounded by 63 petro chemical companies within a fifty km radius; Aamjiwnaag First Nation is one of the most polluted places to live according to National Geographic. The oldest petro chemical company in the local area is 130 years old. First Nations are seeing high rates of cancer, birth defects, and changes in live birth rates- one boy for every two girls. This is the community where Shell is proposing to build the biggest refinery in Canada for upgrading Tar sands for shipping to Portland, MI-USA. Line 9 starts in Aamjiwnaag and is a twin pipeline to the same pipeline- Kalamazoo;/ that ruptured, creating the largest pipeline spill in US history. 

Other Ways You Can Help

For more information please check-out the following web-sites:

http://acfnchallenge.wordpress.com

http://polarisinstitute.org/polaris/indigenous_tar_sands_campaign

http://www.no-tar-sands.org

story:
ItalianoDeutsch

Help SVAfrica.org to raise funds!

THE CHALLENGE

Social Venture Africa together with the NGO Village Exchange Ghana (VEG) and the charity Know Your Planet (KYP) wants to train young Ghanaian women to produce small, cheap and low-tech solar power devices. The pilot project focus on basic electrical training, the production of 200 solar-powered phone rechargers and the development of prototypes for other small devises such as lamps and radios. Using the crafting skills of young mothers employed by the local NGO VEG, we aim to produce stylish devices that are sold locally. In the medium run, we aim to transform the pilot project into an economically self-sustainable business.

SVAfrica together with VEG will organise a two week workshop in February 2014 to train a group of women. The workshop leader is from KYP and the training will take place in the premises of VEG in Ho, Ghana.

THE IMPACT

SVAfrica believes that the key for development and life-quality improvement is to create local opportunities that are economically sustainable rather than simply provide devices free of charge. With our project we bring training, employment and empowerment for vulnerable women. Moreover we support the local economy by sourcing part of the material from local producers and by creating a new market with a high potential demand.

Although electricity is available in Ghana across most areas, many households in the rural villages of the Volta region do not have access to electricity because it is too expensive. Nevertheless almost everybody owns a cell phone. Recharging the cell phone battery is, however, costly. Villagers need to walk to a recharging point, which is time-consuming and expensive. Recharging only twice a week costs up to $2 a month! Our estimate is that less than three months of recharging fees would pay for a solar-powered cell phone recharger! Last but not least, our project is environmental sustainable: the PV panels used to produce the devises are scrapped material that KYP recycles from European Producers.

More details on our project's impact can be found on www.svafrica.org.

WHO WE ARE & WHAT WE NEED

We are a group of economists in our early 30s with a special bound to Africa. We founded the non-profit initiative SVAfrica after a life changing trip to the Volta Region in Ghana where we volunteered for the NGO VEG. Once back home the warmth, enthusiasm and willingness to act for development we witnessed in Ho and in the surrounding areas prompted us to work further for the development of our project. The mission of SVAfrica is to promote women's empowerment and to develop local economies in Africa by introducing sustainable market-based solutions.

For this project we have joined forces with two highly experienced and successful partners: the Ghana-based NGO Village Exchange Ghana (VEG) and the charity Know Your Planet (KYP). VEG has been supporting the local communities of the Volta Region since 2003 with social micro-finance, health education and by creating a successful social enterprise called Lady Volta which gives work to young mothers. VEG will provide the base for our training and we will employ its local network as a distribution channel to sell solar-powered devices. KYP is an international provider of solar power solutions. It also invests in research and development of cheap solar power kits for developing countries which have already been successfully introduced in Kenya.

On our homepage www.svafrica.org you can learn more.

We need to raise 5500 € to jump-start the project! We will spend the money in the following way:

  • 700 € electrical material provided by KYP (PV panels, wires, connectors)
  • 300 € local material (wooden frames and glass sheets)
  • 3300€ transportation costs and local accommodation (flight from London, UK to Accra, Ghana and transport from Accra to Ho in the Volta region and accommodation in Ho for KYP workshop leader and SVAfrica responsible)
  • 300 € production, local marketing and distribution costs
  • 400 € follow-up
  • 500 € other costs (Indiegogo and credit card fees, perks) 

Our and our partners' work, time and expertise are fully donated. 

If we exceed our goal, we will use the additional funds to scale the project and run a second workshop next winter to introduce new product lines such as solar powered lamps and radios. In the unlucky event that we do not meet our target we will keep the donated money and use it to cover the project costs in the following order: material, production, flight for KYP workshop leader, flight for SVAfrica responsible, other expenditures.

WHAT YOU GET

As a thank you for your donation you can receive exclusive hand made African perks which vary with the amount donated. You will be part of this adventure no matter how big your contribution and receive timely updates on the state of the project. Be assured of our full commitment and devotion to the cause. We are accountable for any money donated and we promise you that every euro will have an impact!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US

  • Help us spread the word about our campaign with family, friends and colleagues
  • Visit our website www.svafrica.org and leave comments, suggestions and ideas in our forum 
  • Follow us on Facebook and Twitter
  • Use Indiego share tools

Thank you in advance for your support. You have our deepest gratitude!

Follow us on Facebook and Twitter

Thank you in advance for your support. You have our deepest gratitude!

story:
The Gist Of It

In order to empower the residents of the Slocan Valley to make our water clean again, we need help to bring two experts in community bioremediation, Anita Burke and Leila Darwish, 

On July 26, a tanker fell into a local creek emptying 32,000 litres of fuel into Lemon Creek and the Slocan River.

We'd like it cleaned up.

Thousands of us depend on this water for drinking, bathing, irrigation, providing water to farm animals, and swimming. Tens of thousands of feet of shoreline and the corresponding ecosystem has now been contaminated.

Remediation outfits have been brought in by the fuel transport company to remove the bulk of the fuel but, at the end of the day, they don't live here. The Do Not Use order on the river has been lifted, the cleanup companies are packing up to go home, and pools of jet fuel remain in logjams, back eddies and side pools.

Help empower us to do the job right. Help us to do it together. As a community.

Who Are These "Experts" Anyway?

Both Leila Darwish and Anita Burke have had many years of experience working with remediation companies and affected communities to help clean up environmental disasters. We think that their differing skill sets will be complementary, helping us to diversify our approach to cleaning these waterways.

Anita Burke

Anita has worked to help organizations design, develop and implement sustainable businesses for over twenty five years. Anita spent seventeen years working at Shell and its subsidiaries, focussing on increasing environmental health and safety in the refining industry. Her projects there included advising and designing implementation programs for the CEO and senior leadership team on issues such as climate change, sustainable development policy, and corporate social responsibility.

In 2003, Ms. Burke founded The Catalyst Institute, an organization that has provided strategic and tactical guidance on climate and sustainability programs to multinational corporations, governments, universities, and small to medium sized businesses. 

Ms. Burke currently is a board advisor to a number of start-up companies in Canada, United States, and in Mexico. Anita also advises several US based energy companies on building long term sustainable business practices.

Anita has been a lecturer at Beijing University, and the University of California Santa Barbara. She has also teamed with the Rocky Mountain Institute to design and implement a sustainable development program for Anglo American’s South African enterprises. Anita is a global traveler, and recently moved to Colorado from Vancouver. 

Leila Darwish

Leila is the author of the recently published Earth Repair, a book specifically designed as a handbook for grassroots bioremediation. Check it out here.

Leila Darwish is a community organizer,  permaculture practioner and rabble rouser with a deep commitment to environmental justice, food sovereignty, and to providing accessible and transformative tools for communities dealing with toxic contamination of their land and drinking water. She is the author of the upcoming book “Earth Repair: A Grassroots Guide to Healing Toxic and Damaged Landscapes”, which will be released by New Society Publishers in June 2013.

Over the last decade, she has worked as a community organizer for different environmental organizations and community groups in Alberta, BC and the USA on campaigns such as tar sands, fracking, nuclear energy, coal, climate justice, water protection, and more.  She has also given workshops on grassroots bioremediation and earth repair for a diversity of groups and organizations, such as Langara College, The Victoria Compost Education Centre, The Purple Thistle Youth Cooperative, The Radical Mycology Convergence, The Urban Farmer Field School, and The Cowichan Land Trust.

Where Does The Money Go?

Both Anita and Leila are going to try to make it our here to offer at least one workshop. No matter what.

That said, we think that they both deserve to be paid for their work. We also hope that we can offer them enough that they will be able to afford to stay longer and reach offer more workshops and to different demographics in the valley.

If money is left over after paying both Leila and Anita for all the time they've spent here teaching, advocating, researching and empowering, we hope to use the extra funds to pay for any equipment we need for the bioremediation process.

No matter what, all funders will receive a detailed report of how the money is spent.

How To Support The Cause

Just click the pick Contribute button at the top of the page and pick an amount that you would like to donate.

We've set the goal to $1500 but only because if we meet our goal, more of your money goes to the cause and less to Indiegogo. We'd love to raise double that -- or more. As mentioned earlier, if money is left over after paying both Leila and Anita for all the time they've spent here teaching, advocating, researching and empowering, we hope to use the extra funds to pay for any equipment we need for the bioremediation process.

It would have been nice to have the time to put together perks for donators, but this feels pretty time sensitive. We hope knowing that you've helped clean up one of the few places left in the world where people can still get their drinking water from the nearest creek or river is enough.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.

Head up to the Share This Campaign sections and help us make some noise! This valley is important to so many. We residents are only a few of them.

And that’s all there is to it.

How To Support The Cause

We've set the goal to $1500 but only because if we meet our goal, more of your money goes to the cause and less to Indiegogo. We'd love to raise double that -- or more. As mentioned earlier, if money is left over after paying both Leila and Anita for all the time they've spent here teaching, advocating, researching and empowering, we hope to use the extra funds to pay for any equipment we need for the bioremediation process.
It would have been nice to have the time to put together perks for donators, but this feels pretty time sensitive. We hope knowing that you've helped clean up one of the few places left in the world where people can still get their drinking water from the nearest creek or river is enough.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.
Head up to the Share This Campaign sections and help us make some noise! This valley is important to so many. We residents are only a few of them.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
We are a pair of Masters students from South Africa and the United States who met at the University of Oxford. We are completing our fiedlwork in rural Ghana studying   the relationship between forest elephants and people! We are asking for your help to fund our dissertation fieldwork!

Our original Indiegogo goal was $1,000 dollars, which we are humbled to have met. Our ultimate goal is full funding of the project. Our current best estimate is $4,000 for us both.

Short Summary

Our study site is in South Central Ghana on the outskirts of Kakum National Park in the villages on the northern boundary. Kakum is home to a variety of strange and wonderful creatures, the famous canopy walkway, some of the last intact rain forest in West Africa and importantly for us, the endangered forest elephant.

African forest elephants are highly endangered. Research published this year suggests that forest elephants in central Africa have suffered a 60% decline in number in the last ten years. This loss is fueled mainly by habitat loss, poaching for ivory, and retaliatory killing. Elephants have large range requirements and frequently venture outside of protected areas, in addition people who depend on forest resources for their livelihoods often go into protected areas. This means that people and elephants come into contact and this often results in conflict. Crop raids around Kakum can result in a family loosing and entire crop in one night, this can have devastating consequences for both communities of humans and communities of elephants.

But interactions between elephants and people shouldn’t be as conflict, which is where our research comes in. Lynsey will be exploring the possibility of using community-based conservation to reduce the costs of elephants on people and improve the conservation status of elephants in the region. Bethany will be investigating the role cocoa farming plays in human elephant conflict.

During our year on the MSc in Biodiversity, Conservation and Management at the University of Oxford, we have learnt so much from so many different people; we believe that we can make a real contribution to reducing human-elephant conflict in Ghana. We have conviction in the importance of our work, and we hope you agree. We are humbly asking you to please help fund our fieldwork.

 

What We Need & What You Get

On a student budget our 5 weeks of fieldwork is going to cost quite a bit. We need to finance flights ($800), visas ($150), accommodation, food, malaria medication ($50), transport from Accra to Kakum and to the rural villages each day, and a translator to help us with our interviews. The many uncertainties associated with this type of fieldwork mean we don’t know exactly how much it’s all going to cost at this point. We are estimating that it will amount to about $2,500 each. We both have some funding from Oxford ($450 each) and the rest of the trip will be paid for by our ever-increasing student loans, so any donation would help!

Our original Indiegogo goal was $1,000 dollars, which we are humbled to have met. Our ultimate goal is full funding of the project. Our current best estimate is four thousand dollars for us both. Our campaign will continue for the duration of our fieldwork and we will update with our costs.

To say thank you for your donations we will be sending you once-off original Ghana inspired art. Our friendship is not only bound by our love for conservation, we both enjoy photography and fine art and will be drawing and photo-documenting our journey.

 

For a $10 donation we will send you a digital photo taken in Ghana and thank you note

For $20 we will send you an A4 limited edition, high resolution photograph print on high quality photo paper

For $25 we will send an A4 limited edition print of one of our original drawings 

For $40 we will send you an A4 original drawing done by us in Ghana and thank you note

For $60 we will send you an A4 photograph and drawing collage and thank you note

For $100 we will send you an A3 photograph and drawing collage done by both of us together, a thank you note and maybe even some famous Ghanaian chocolate or some other little present!

Of course you are welcome to donate any amount without choosing a gift, and donations can be anonymous if you prefer. 

Samples of our work from other inspiring places are shown below to give you a taster of what your donation would get you. If you have a preference of whose artwork you receive, or if you would like to swap around gifts (ie. you would prefer to receive more photography rather than a drawing or collage) please let us know!

Bethany's Work Samples

I have both professional and academic experience in photography and the fine arts. My creativity was fostered at quite an early age and I have apprenticed under my mother (who is a long-time professional photographer) for my lifetime. 

I have also been incredibly blessed to have traveled and worked in some of the most beautiful and remote regions of the planet. After completing my undergraduate degree I spent five months living and working in Antarctica where I contributed my media skills extensively to a science-based outreach project. I have also worked as a publicist, taking photographs, writing stories and filming and editing short films for the Sitka Conservation Society in Southeast Alaska.

Please visit my website for more examples of my work. Please contact me for details or requests for exisiting photographs. The photographs and artwork you will receive as part of this crowdfunding deal will be taken or created while conducting fieldwork in Ghana unless otherwise other work is previously requested. If you would like to receive my photography or artwork please request so when making your donation. Thanks and much love!

www.bethanygoodrich.com

bethany.goodrich@ouce.ox.ac.uk

 

 Lynsey's Sample Art

As the daughter of a pottery teacher I started expressing my creativity in her studio when I was about two, and I haven't stopped. I have always been involved in art, whether it be relaxed classes in my free time, or formal classes at school. In my final year of high school I was honoured to receive an award for excellence in painting.

My favourite mediums are ceramics, acrylic and watercolour painting, and charcoal drawing. In for this project I will be using photography, water colours, and charcoal and pen drawing. I am so excited to capture the spirit of our fieldwork in Ghana on paper for you!

Below are some photographs taken in the Kruger National Park last year. The drawings were done here in Oxford and were inspired by my trips to Lesotho and Kruger in December. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people can’t contribute but would still like to help, if that’s the case please send our Indiegogo campaign to friends far and wide. Help us spread the message! 

Whether you donate or not we invite you to follow our fieldwork blog at www.bethanygoodrich.com for updates while we’re there. We will be updating with stories and photos to give you a taste of Ghanaian life and show you our World for the next month!

Contact us:

bethany.goodrich@ouce.ox.ac.uk

lynsey.rimbault@ouce.ox.ac.uk

'like' our campaign on facebook: https://www.facebook.com/BethanyandLynseyinGhana

follow along: http://bethanygoodrich.com/category/ghana/

story:
About Black and Green Press

Black and Green Press is an anarcho-primitivist... let's call it publishing house. We're not in the business of making money, we're interested in spreading ideas, in furthering discussion, showing the world what civilization is, what the domestication process does to us and to our world, and finding ways to resist it. 

     Black and Green Press goes back to the year 2000, after the worldwide anti-globalization and anarchist resistance scenes were making headlines through property destruction and riots in the wake of every global political/economic power meeting during the day with earth and animal liberation groups lighting the stage at night. While traditional activist tactics wore out, untraditional anarchist targets were being exposed by digging at the roots of civilization. As big as capitalism can be, it didn't create this world, it just became the current face of it. 
     So we pushed the envelope. First through zines, pamphlets, and Species Traitor, an insurrectionary anarchist primitivist journal, which grew to a book size and format within 4 issues. In 2010, B&G published Kevin Tucker's For Wildness and Anarchy and John Zerzan's Origins.

     And things are heating up again. 
     So far in 2014, we have our first novella, Natasha Alvarez's Liminal, press-bound. Quickly following on it's hells we have Kevin Tucker's Roots: A Field Guide to Anarcho-Primitivism and we've just announced our new bi-annual magazine, The Black and Green Review, with a decisively discussion/debate focus. 

What We Need & What You Get

The entirety of the funding we seek goes directly to publishing. We have no paid staff, we have no office expenses. Our goal is to get Black and Green Press self-sufficient to ensure that we can keep putting out publications. There are a lot of projects in the discussion phase right now and we want to see them happen. 

     The perks listed below include current and previous Black and Green Press titles. For the most part, we are using this campaign to get pre-orders (for individuals and wholesale) as well as get subscriptions for The Black and Green Review. Other perks might come along, but the main goal is to cover our primary printing costs so that we can keep things rolling without having to spend years trying to come up with the funds. 

     The Indie Go Go campaign that we ran for Liminal was hugely successful. We greatly appreciate everyone that helped make that happen. This current campaign directly includes two different B&G projects, Roots and Black and Green Review, since we hope to run them pretty much side by side. Your contribution here isn't just helping us get these titles into a physical format, it's to help ensure that Black and Green can keep titles like this coming. 

     The goal we've set is high, but these projects aren't cheap. Not hitting our goal won't keep us from getting these projects out, but it will certainly help us get to where we need to be and getting there faster. The less time we spend working on fund raising, the more time we can spend writing, editing, and preparing these kinds of titles. 

     A direct benefit of hitting our goals is that if we can substantially cover our costs through donations, we can greatly reduce the cover price on our books and get them in more hands. Generous donations made it possible to drop the cover price of Liminal $2. Donations in any amount directly impact our ability to spread these ideas. 

About Roots:  A Field Guide to Anarcho-Primitivism

Roots is a long overdue introduction and overview of the anarcho-primitivist critique. Part primer, part FAQ, and part discussion about the implications of the critique, Roots is a much needed piece of the puzzle. 

196 pages, anticipated release in August/September.

About the Black and Green Review

Black and Green Review is a new, bi-annual magazine from Black and Green Press. BAGR is an anarcho-primitivist magazine meant to create a format for debate and discussion within the AP and green anarchist milieu. 
The format is a handful of essays, a moderated debate, essays "for discussion", action review, reviews, letters, and more, all with the intention of driving the discussion of civilization, wildness, and the struggle against domestication. 
For more information, click here.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We are running this campaign for 60 days, which is the maximum amount of time allotted. The goal here is lower than the amount we will actually need to ensure that we hit it and Indie Go Go takes a smaller amount of that total. 
         Put simply, everything helps, and the more money we raise through this, the more we can get out in the long haul. 

         Knowing that money isn't always the easiest way to help, our hope is that if you don't have funds and are interested in pushing these debates and titles, you can at least help us spread the word as far and wide as possible. The more successful these campaigns are, the more we can put out for the world to see and the more accessible we can make it. 

         If you wish to contact us outside of Indie Go Go, you can email us at blackandgreenpress (at) gmail [dot] com. 
        Thank you! 
        For wildness and anarchy, 

         Kevin Tucker for Black and Green Press

    International Contributors

    Please note that I'm trying to figure out what realistic rates will be for postage. Hang tight, I'll get other options up here for you very soon.

story:
My name is Oludare Ogunde, a resident of Richmond, Virginia. I was born and raised in West Africa, and I immigrated to the United States almost three decades ago. I am the Vice President of Sandrog International Commerce, LLC (www.sandrogintlcommerce.com) and an advocate for human rights and criminal justice reform. I am the manager and coordinator of this campaign to help the victims of the ongoing Ebola virus crisis in West Africa-- a crisis that has claimed many lives and continues to claim more lives with every passing moment. The most affected countries are Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Guinea. My native country, Nigeria, has also reported Ebola-virus-related deaths, and the situation, if not arrested, may get worse and claim the lives of millions in that country of more than 160 million people

How can we help? We have focused our campaign on providing protective equipment like masks, gloves, etc., to health care providers who are tasked with the dangerous responsibility of caring for those who are infected with the virus. As accurately reported by the media, many of the health care providers have been victims of the virus due to their contact with infected patients. Consequently, in some countries it is the case today that some hospitals are closed and many health care providers are refusing to work due to lack of protective gear. This campaign is to help remedy that problem. We are raising funds to buy thousands of masks and gloves that will be donated through non-governmental organizations (NGO) and some governmental entities in that region.

Your donation will make a big difference in the fight against this virus and help save millions of lives from this terrible disease. If you cannot donate, please contribute by getting the word out to your family, friends, and colleagues and by helping to spread this campaign.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread this campaign. We thank you for caring and for your donation or contribution to this campaign.

story:
We seek $20,000.00 total funding so that we may purchase the last pieces of equipment needed ($4000) and use the remainder ($16000) for working capital. THe product is in great demand by producers of biodiesel. Our investment so far exceeds $30,000.00 and we have no debt to third parties. The spent fryer oil is currently purchased from restaurants for less than $0.10/lb and resold as processed yellow grease for about $0.30/lb. We seek the funds as a loan payable within one year at 5 points above LIBOR.

Our web site is: www.nearllc.com

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS (FAQ’s)

 

What does NEAR, LLC do?

Only one thing (and we do it well)…we collect, transport and further process used fryer oil from restaurants and institutions.

How do you get the used fryer oil?

We purchase waste vegetable oil (WVO) from the various food establishments that generate WVO in the course of their business. NEAR pays top dollar for this valuable bi-product, and then turns it into “yellow grease” for sale in the market place.

What is “yellow grease”? http://www.facebook.com/emilio.bruna.3

Yellow grease is a world traded commodity that is typically composed of used cooking oils, but could also contain animal fats such as tallow, lard and poultry fat. Superior processing methods can result in better quality material and higher market prices, when specific product features are tighter than the standard specifications.

Who buys yellow grease?

NEAR, LLC sells yellow grease to biodiesel plants, animal feed producers, bunker and boiler fuel distributors, and others. We do not directly export this valuable commodity that we consider of vital importance to our national energy and agricultural independence.

Is NEAR a green company?

We do our best to be. Our product is often used as a substitute for nonrenewable petroleum based feed stocks. Our process is clean, does not use water for producing the yellow grease and generates no hazardous waste or toxic air emissions. We promote reuse and recycling as much as possible at the plant and the office. We employ sustainable best management practices in the daily course of our business

Is NEAR a socially responsible company?

The company is a member of the Gainesville Buy Local organization. We actively support local businesses. Our headquarters are in Gainesville and all of our team members live here and participate in local activities with their families. Our plant is located in NE Gainesville, within the Gainesville Enterprise zone, and hires its employees from the nearby high unemployment neighborhoods. Our lowest starting wage is about 40% above the minimum established by law.

What is your relationship with DoorstepDelivery.com?

We are proud to share a strategic alliance with the premier restaurant meal delivery service in Florida. DoorstepDelivery.com is a fast growing organization, now franchising its novel concept throughout the southeastern states. They help us market our services to their many restaurant customers by making them aware of our presence in the local Gainesville area. We look forward to their guidance and support in penetrating the Gainesville market and it is our aim to help boost their already great service reputation.

How can I get in touch with NEAR, LLC?

We are here in Gainesville 24/7. Call our toll free number (888) 958-3619 to request a visit. Our phone lines are always open. You mail email us at chedreed@nearllc.com. We respond to service calls in 24 hours or less. Or tell your DoorstepDelivery.com delivery person or sales rep that you want to talk to us. Like our slogan says… Are you NEAR?  Yes we are!
