Only one thing (and we do it well)…we collect, transport and further process used fryer oil from restaurants and institutions.
How do you get the used fryer oil?
We purchase waste vegetable oil (WVO) from the various food establishments that generate WVO in the course of their business. NEAR pays top dollar for this valuable bi-product, and then turns it into “yellow grease” for sale in the market place.
What is “yellow grease”? http://www.facebook.com/emilio.bruna.3
Yellow grease is a world traded commodity that is typically composed of used cooking oils, but could also contain animal fats such as tallow, lard and poultry fat. Superior processing methods can result in better quality material and higher market prices, when specific product features are tighter than the standard specifications.
Who buys yellow grease?
NEAR, LLC sells yellow grease to biodiesel plants, animal feed producers, bunker and boiler fuel distributors, and others. We do not directly export this valuable commodity that we consider of vital importance to our national energy and agricultural independence.
Is NEAR a green company?
We do our best to be. Our product is often used as a substitute for nonrenewable petroleum based feed stocks. Our process is clean, does not use water for producing the yellow grease and generates no hazardous waste or toxic air emissions. We promote reuse and recycling as much as possible at the plant and the office. We employ sustainable best management practices in the daily course of our business
Is NEAR a socially responsible company?
The company is a member of the Gainesville Buy Local organization. We actively support local businesses. Our headquarters are in Gainesville and all of our team members live here and participate in local activities with their families. Our plant is located in NE Gainesville, within the Gainesville Enterprise zone, and hires its employees from the nearby high unemployment neighborhoods. Our lowest starting wage is about 40% above the minimum established by law.
What is your relationship with DoorstepDelivery.com?
We are proud to share a strategic alliance with the premier restaurant meal delivery service in Florida. DoorstepDelivery.com is a fast growing organization, now franchising its novel concept throughout the southeastern states. They help us market our services to their many restaurant customers by making them aware of our presence in the local Gainesville area. We look forward to their guidance and support in penetrating the Gainesville market and it is our aim to help boost their already great service reputation.
How can I get in touch with NEAR, LLC?
We are here in Gainesville 24/7. Call our toll free number (888) 958-3619 to request a visit. Our phone lines are always open. You mail email us at chedreed@nearllc.com. We respond to service calls in 24 hours or less. Or tell your DoorstepDelivery.com delivery person or sales rep that you want to talk to us. Like our slogan says… Are you NEAR?  Yes we are!

story:
Join us as we delve into the secret lives of the bottlenose dolphins of Bocas del Toro, Panama through science while promoting sustainable dolphins tourism, community-based conservation and education!

                                                

Who are we?

We’re a team of conservation scientists with the Bocas Dolphin Project, a research initiative of Panacetacea, a non-profit organization dedicated to the study and conservation of whales and dolphins of Panama. We study bottlenose dolphin behavioral ecology, bioacoustics, genetics and human impacts in Dolphin Bay, Bocas del Toro, Panama to inform long-term sustainable tourism practices and conservation of the resident bottlenose dolphin population.  

We have been studying this population of bottlenose dolphins since 2004. In 2007, our research team and the Bocas del Toro community joined efforts with several NGOs in a campaign to protect the Bocas dolphin population from capture by an international company who planned to harvest individual animals for display in captive aquaria and dolphinariums. The data collected by our research team provided strong evidence that the Bocas population is small and that removing individuals would have been detrimental to its long-term health . Now the dolphins are facing other conservation challenges and we are enlisting YOUR generous support to help us protect them once again.


A brief summary of what we plan to do:

We will be traveling to Bocas del Toro, Panama in the summer of 2014 to investigate the impacts of boat-based dolphin tourism on the bottlenose dolphin population of Dolphin Bay, an important ecological habitat and mother-calf nursery for dolphins and a tourism hotspot. Our research is interdisciplinary, community-oriented and aimed at long-term conservation of dolphins in Dolphin Bay through the integration of science and community action.

Our Project Goals (in a nutshell):
  • To continue our behavioral, acoustic and genetic research into the Bocas dolphins to further our scientific understanding of this unique coastal population's behavioral ecology and the long-term impacts of dolphin-tour boat interactions.
  • To enhance and expand our dolphin surveys through the use of Conservation Drones.
  • To bridge the gap between science and the Bocas del Toro community through partcipatory research, environmental education and community-based conservation initatives.
  • To implement a long-term conservation management plan for dolphins and develop sustainable dolphin watching practices in partnership with the local tourism industry and other community stakeholders.
As an international research team with Latin American origins and heritage (we are collectively from Costa Rica, Puerto Rico, Colombia, Panama, and the United States), we are committed to helping conserve the Bocas dolphins in partnership with local stakeholders including the local tourism industry, indigenous communities and local NGOs through scientific research, community-based conservation planning, outreach and education. 

Click on our names to learn more about us!
  • Laura May-Collado, Ph.D.
  • Shakira Quinones-Lebron, M.Sc.
  • Ayshah Kassamali-Fox, M.Sc. candidate
  • Dalia Barrera Barragan, Ph.D. candidate
  • Susana Caballero, Ph.D.
  • Mónica Gamboa, M.Sc.
  • Lissette Trejos Lasso, M.V.

Get updates and learn more about our work at  http://www.bocasdolphins.com/!

What is the Bocas Dolphin Project about?

The island archipelago of Bocas del Toro, located on the northwestern Caribbean coast of Panama, is a biodiversity hotspot boasting turquoise waters, coral reefs, mangrove swamps and tropical rainforests. Sound a bit like paradise? That’s because it sort of is! For humans AND dolphins alike. The mangrove-fringed waters of Dolphin Bay are home to a small population of bottlenose dolphins, many of which are year round residents of this ecologically productive, sheltered bay. Playful and social, the Bocas dolphins attract boatloads of tourists to Dolphin Bay each year. This place was nicknamed Dolphin Bay for a reason—because tourists are pretty much guaranteed dolphin sightings year round in this pristine habitat. But tourists aren't the only ones who love these dolphins. The various adjacent indigenous communities of the archipelago have co-existed with the dolphin community of Bocas del Toro for hundreds of years, sharing marine resources and scenery with these amazing marine mammals.

Come join us as we explore the ecology of the Bocas dolphins through science AND nurture the ancient connection between local communities and their dolphin neighbors through community-based conservation and education!   

Our project represents an interdisciplinary approach to the study of dolphin ecology and conservation, thus our goals are both scientific and community-oriented. As scientists, we will investigate the behavioral ecology of the Bocas dolphin population through studying their acoustic and behavioral communication, habitat use, movement patterns and genetics to build a strong case for their conservation. As community organizers, we will help bridge the gap between science and community by educating local school children about the importance of marine conservation, involving the local community in our research and decision-making processes, integrating traditional ecological knowledge into management planning and collaborating with the local tourism industry on development of sustainable tourism practices. 

By contributing to our project, you will have the exciting opportunity to support conservation science within a community context and experience firsthand the rewards of community-based conservation in action. Essentially, YOU will be empowering US to help preserve both the biological and cultural diversity of the Bocas del Toro archipelago for future generations by promoting community connections to science, stewardship of marine resources and a socially and ecologically responsible wildlife tourism economy.

Why Bocas del Toro?

Because there is trouble in paradise. What the indigenous people of the region have known for centuries, international tourists are now only beginning to understand. The Bocas dolphins captivate the human imagination… and they keep the tourists coming back year after year. This frequent exposure to dolphin watching boats might actually be contributing to a decline in the dolphin population. Since 2004, we have documented avoidance behavior and other negative behavioral responses in dolphins exposed to tour boats and we suspect that dolphin tourism could be displacing dolphins from their preferred habitat of Dolphin Bay. Sound harsh? Well, we think so! That’s why we are on a mission to understand the impacts that dolphin watching boats are having on the long-term health of the Bocas dolphins.

The Dolphin-Tourist Dilemma

The colorful and bustling Bocas Town on the main island of Isla Colon is a haven for international tourists seeking surf, sun and adventure among the diverse breaks, jungles and reefs of the Bocas del Toro archipelago. Local tourist companies sell hundreds of tour packages to tens of hundreds of international tourists each year. One of the most popular attractions is a dolphin watching tour to Dolphin Bay where tourists are almost guaranteed intimate encounters with the area’s resident dolphins.  

The problem is that the Bocas dolphin population is estimated to be small (about 100-150 individuals) and many individuals remain in Dolphin Bay for life. These animals can be repeatedly exposed to tour boats over time and are at increased risk for cumulative effects of boat disturbance. Currently, many tour boat operators do not comply with national commercial whale watching guidelines and routinely engage in aggressive encounters with dolphins to please their dolphin-happy customers.  


For example, boat operators will encircle dolphins to entice them to surf the wake of their boats (YouTube video here). This is fun times for dolphin watchers but dangerous business for dolphins who have been seriously injured by boat propellers. Sadly, five calves have already been killed by boat collisions. But speed isn’t the only problem. Engine noise disrupts the acoustic communication of dolphins and impacts social behavior--this effect is especially dangerous for mothers with calves who rely heavily on sound to maintain contact with their babies.


Our Impact Plan:

What we plan to do and why:

  • Collect high resolution photographs of dolphin dorsal fins to build a photo-identification catalog of the population.

    This will help us estimate dolphin abundance in Dolphin Bay and establish a conservation management plan for the population 

  • Document dolphin sighting locations and movements with GPS technology.

    • This will help us learn more about dolphin habitat use so we can identify important protected areas for dolphins

  • Collect acoustic and behavioral data of individuals and groups to evaluate effects of dolphin-tour boat interactions.

    • Dolphins can be negatively impacted by engine noise and intrusive boat encounters; these data will help us determine the level of acoustic and behavioral disturbance within this population.

                         

  • Collect tissue biopsies of individuals to perform microsatellite and mitochondrial DNA analyses.

    • The Bocas dolphin population is small and possesses low genetic diversity; genetic studies will help us determine the sex of individuals and the genetic profile of the population to establish conservation management units. 

  • Implement the newest technology for aerial surveys: Conservation Drones! A video camera mounted on a small drone will allow us to view the subsurface dolphin behaviors from an aerial vantage point.

    • Dolphin behavior is very hard to study as dolphins spend most of their time beneath the surface of the water; aerial video observation is an exciting new research tool for learning more about subsurface dolphin behavior and dolphin-tour boat interactions.

    • Check out our Media Gallery for some amazing drone videos and scroll down for some fun facts about Conservation Drones!

Photo courtesy of  http://conservationdrone.org/

  • Engage the local community in conservation planning through creation of stakeholder forums to discuss strategies for dolphin conservation and best tourism practices.

    • Community participation in natural resource management and decision-making is key to successful tourism regulation compliance and long-term conservation success.

                   

  • Mentor Panamanian students in dolphin field research methods and activities.

    • Building local capacity for scientific research and natural resource management is important to successful conservation.

  • Publish research reports and scientific articles for access by community stakeholders as well as the larger scientific community.

    • Scientific publication of our results will contribute to the body of knowledge about disturbance effects in dolphins and help inform sustainable dolphin tourism initiatives in other developing coastal regions around the world.

               

  • Educate local community about dolphin ecology and conservation through school and community outreach initiatives

    • Education is key to creating awareness about dolphin conservation in Bocas del Toro and building community-based support for dolphin conservation.

 

  • Maintain a blog where we will regularly post images, videos, and narratives of our adventures studying dolphins in Bocas del Toro!

    • Blogging is fun, informative and engaging for our supporters!

What will result from this work?

This project will result in papers published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, scientific presentations and community events with the general public. The long-term objective of the Bocas Dolphin Project is to foster community ownership over dolphin conservation, cultivate sustainable tourism practices and enhance our scientific understanding of human impacts on wild dolphins to inform international conservation efforts using mainstay  marine mammal research methods AND cutting-edge research technology.

Our preliminary work this summer of 2014, funded by YOU, will provide a springboard for future studies, spanning several years, of the bottlenose dolphin community of Bocas del Toro. By funding this research, you are contributing to a long-term, interdisciplinary scientific and community project that will influence future management and conservation strategies for this unique ecological community and the diverse people whose socioeconomic needs depend on it.

What will the funds be used for?

Your generous funds will help support this summer field travel (5K), boat surveys (17K), community work and training of local Panamanian students (8K), Conservation Drones (10K) [see detailed description about Conservation Drones below!]
Total: 40K

What are Conservation Drones?

Conservation Drones are inexpensive, autonomous and operator-friendly unmanned aerial vehicles for surveying and mapping forests and biodiversity. Non-technical operators can program each mission by defining waypoints along a flight path using an open-source software (http://conservationdrones.org/mission-planner/).

Conservation Drones are able to fly pre-programmed missions autonomously for a total flight time of up to ~50 minutes and over a distance of ~25 km. Depending on the camera system installed, these drones can record videos at up to 1080 pixel resolution, and acquire aerial photographs of <10 cm pixel resolution. Aerial photographs can be stitched together to produce near real-time geo-referenced land use/cover maps of surveyed areas.

Conservation Drones have great potential for environmental and conservation applications, which include near real-time mapping of local land cover, monitoring of illegal forest activities and marine protected areas, and surveying of large terrestrial and marine animal species.

Cited from http://conservationdrones.org.

Check out our Media Gallery for more images and videos of Conservation Drones!

story:
Our mission and our goal is to bring clean water to Haiti and save the lives of thousands of children who are dying everyday from contaminated water. Without clean water, Port-au-Prince and the surrounding areas will continue to see the spread of bacterial diseases such as cholera, typhoid fever or the parasites that cause amoebic dysentery. People will not only continue to get sick they will continue to die. Even 4 years after the earthquake and 2 years after Hurricane Sandy, Haiti continues to see a staggering number of deaths amongst children. 80% of the deaths from this contaminated water are children under the age of 5 years old. The future of Haiti will cease to exist if the children continue to die. 

As we stated in the video we have been lucky enough to receive a donation of 5 clean water filters from RainCatcher.org. These filters alone have the ability to save hundreds of lives, but with your help during the time we are down there we can take so many more filters and save not just hundreds but try and help save thousands of lives. As it says on their website, "RainCatcher is a non-profit organization dedicated to healing communities by providing clean water for children in the developing world using affordable and sustainable solutions." 

That statement alone is a prime example of what we are trying to achieve and why we are so happy to have linked up with RainCatcher. Not only helping the children that desperately need it but doing it in an affordable and sustainable way. Allowing these communities to grow, stay healthy and educate others on the usefulness of the filters.


We are a small group, just regular guys, with no agenda beyond truly wanting to help those in need. 

Jason Coates: Is a world traveler who has traveled to 20 countries in the past 2 years and documented his travels on the social networking site Join Us Around the World.com. The site and Jason's mission is to connect travelers and build new friendships Around the World. Aside from his travels and love for videography and photography, Jason is passionate about world issues and helping those in need. In his home town of Denver Colorado he has organized many clothing and shoe drives for the homeless and after seeing many of the distressed and poverty stricken places of the world, Jason feels there is no better time than now to take those community efforts all over the globe…. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Jason responded with, "This project is important to me because I love people, and when I see someone in need I feel like I should do something about it. When there are innocent children dying and there is something that can be done to stop it, I can't sit back and not try and be apart of that change. I am passionate about this project because I love to film the world and I feel this is apart of the world that needs to be brought to light as much as any place on the globe." 

Derek Reinhardt: Is an extremely dedicated worker who has shined in many fields including: Construction, aviation mechanics, creative arts and entertainment and helping build startups from the ground floor. He is also a professional photographer who found what he loved by capturing life and emotion. He truly feels at home behind the lens and capturing the world he sees in front of him …. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Derek responded with, this project is important to me because I have always had a passion for helping people as well as a passion for photography and on a project like this I will be able to bring those two worlds together."

Jeremy Pape: A recent graduate of the University of Colorado and current business owner and filmmaker. As Jeremy states it, "The reason why I create and run my own business is so that I have an opportunity to facilitate positivity and assist in the achievement of dreams for the people around me. I feel the ability to tell stories in an interesting and new way gives me the ability to teach people how to live and love life for the new generation." ... When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Jeremy responded with, "I feel visually documenting a journey like this will help change lives through the story we tell and the education this will bring." 

Pat Flannigan: A graduate of Valencia college for film production Pat loves to bring you the world through film. He is passionate about travel and sharing his stories and the stories of others along the way. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Pat responded with, "This project is extremely important to me because it gives me a chance to use my passion for filmmaking to expose people to the needs of the less fortunate and provide something that so many of us take for granted."

Professional and dedicated documentation of this project will allow us to share it with the world and hopefully bring continued aid to those in need. 

WHAT YOUR DONATION SUPPORTS:

We are raising funds for our trip to Haiti as well as the cost to purchase additional filters. The more filters we take the more lives we can help save.

1) Round Trip Plane Tickets from Denver to Haiti

2) Hotel and Lodging

3) Food Costs

4) Transportation- Gas/Truck Rental in Haiti

5) Haitian Translator/Guide

6) Shots/Medication before departure

7) Additional supplies and buckets once we arrive in Haiti  

8) Post-Production Transcribing of all our interviews from Creole and French to English subtitles

9) Emergency funds while in a third world country 

10) But most importantly FILTERS! We would like to take as many as we can.

We can't thank you all enough for taking the time to watch our video and read about our mission. We would like to thank RainCatcher.org for their contribution to the project and everything they are doing around the world. Thank you all in advance for your help with this project. Let's go see the world together!

#CleanWaterAroundtheWorld

People will not only continue to get sick they will continue to die. Even 4 years after the earthquake and 2 years after Hurricane Sandy, Haiti continues to see a staggering number of deaths amongst children. 80% of the deaths from this contaminated water are children under the age of 5 years old. The future of Haiti will cease to exist if the children continue to die. As we stated in the video we have been lucky enough to receive a donation of 5 clean water filters from RainCatcher.org. These filters alone have the ability to save hundreds of lives, but with your help during the time we are down there we can take so many more filters and save not just hundreds but try and help save thousands of lives. As it says on their website, "RainCatcher is a non-profit organization dedicated to healing communities by providing clean water for children in the developing world using affordable and sustainable solutions." That statement alone is a prime example of what we are trying to achieve and why we are so happy to have linked up with RainCatcher. Not only helping the children that desperately need it but doing it in an affordable and sustainable way. Allowing these communities to grow, stay healthy and educate others on the usefulness of the filters.We are a small group, just regular guys, with no agenda beyond truly wanting to help those in need. Jason Coates: Is a world traveler who has traveled to 20 countries in the past 2 years and documented his travels on the social networking site Join Us Around the World.com. The site and Jason's mission is to connect travelers and build new friendships Around the World. Aside from his travels and love for videography and photography, Jason is passionate about world issues and helping those in need. In his home town of Denver Colorado he has organized many clothing and shoe drives for the homeless and after seeing many of the distressed and poverty stricken places of the world, Jason feels there is no better time than now to take those community efforts all over the globe…. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Jason responded with, "This project is important to me because I love people, and when I see someone in need I feel like I should do something about it. When there are innocent children dying and there is something that can be done to stop it, I can't sit back and not try and be apart of that change. I am passionate about this project because I love to film the world and I feel this is apart of the world that needs to be brought to light as much as any place on the globe." Derek Reinhardt: Is an extremely dedicated worker who has shined in many fields including: Construction, aviation mechanics, creative arts and entertainment and helping build startups from the ground floor. He is also a professional photographer who found what he loved by capturing life and emotion. He truly feels at home behind the lens and capturing the world he sees in front of him …. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Derek responded with, this project is important to me because I have always had a passion for helping people as well as a passion for photography and on a project like this I will be able to bring those two worlds together."Jeremy Pape: A recent graduate of the University of Colorado and current business owner and filmmaker. As Jeremy states it, "The reason why I create and run my own business is so that I have an opportunity to facilitate positivity and assist in the achievement of dreams for the people around me. I feel the ability to tell stories in an interesting and new way gives me the ability to teach people how to live and love life for the new generation." ... When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Jeremy responded with, "I feel visually documenting a journey like this will help change lives through the story we tell and the education this will bring." Pat Flannigan: A graduate of Valencia college for film production Pat loves to bring you the world through film. He is passionate about travel and sharing his stories and the stories of others along the way. When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Pat responded with, "This project is extremely important to me because it gives me a chance to use my passion for filmmaking to expose people to the needs of the less fortunate and provide something that so many of us take for granted."Professional and dedicated documentation of this project will allow us to share it with the world and hopefully bring continued aid to those in need. WHAT YOUR DONATION SUPPORTS:We are raising funds for our trip to Haiti as well as the cost to purchase additional filters. The more filters we take the more lives we can help save.1) Round Trip Plane Tickets from Denver to Haiti2) Hotel and Lodging3) Food Costs4) Transportation- Gas/Truck Rental in Haiti5) Haitian Translator/Guide6) Shots/Medication before departure7) Additional supplies and buckets once we arrive in Haiti  8) Post-Production Transcribing of all our interviews from Creole and French to English subtitles9) Emergency funds while in a third world country 10) But most importantly FILTERS! We would like to take as many as we can.We can't thank you all enough for taking the time to watch our video and read about our mission. We would like to thank RainCatcher.org for their contribution to the project and everything they are doing around the world. Thank you all in advance for your help with this project. Let's go see the world together!#CleanWaterAroundtheWorld

story:
Complaints about the esthetic look of solar modules (Photovoltaic) can be overcome by incorporating motifs and designs into the array. The task is to use Photovoltaic Modules as an artist's medium.

This project mosaic is of Arizona's Four Peaks Mountains with a moon, coyote, and saguaro. This 7 KW system produces 60% of the home’s electrical energy needs. The black solar modules are fitted with thick aluminum sheets to produce curves that form the artistic detail. Under panel L.E.D. lighting will back light the motif in the evenings.

Artist Installer


I am a sculptor and environmentalist. I have been painting and sculpting my whole life. Several years ago I started learning about Photovoltaic via Santa Monica College and doing volunteer installations with Grid Alternatives. Many of the residential solar installations have been placed on Habitat for Humanity homes. These all have been traditional solar installations. I want to expand the use of Solar Modules by illustrating the use of Solar Modules as a functional art medium.

Location

Friends Shereen and Ruvi have volunteered their Chandler Arizona home’s roof for this installation. This family of 4 home will provide the ideal rooftop for this installation. The home already uses energy efficient lighting, heating and air conditioning. The array will generate 60% of their family’s electrical needs.

Benefits

36 Kyocera KD140 and 9 LG275 Modules will eliminate 10 tons of carbon annually. This is equivalent to 298 trees cleaning the air. This installation will generate 14,900 KWatts of electricity annually and saving the homeowner with more than $3,000 in yearly electrical costs.  This Phoenix Area home enjoys the most sunshine in the United States and is an ideal location for the installation.

Costs

Calculations formed by National Renewable Energy Laboratory’s System Advisor Model SAM 2013.9.20. https://sam.nrel.gov/

45 Kyocera Modules      $5,420

Inverter                               $3,075

Racking & Electrical       $3,723

Installation Labor            $5,803

Art components              $4,500

Building Permits              $  900

Engineering Fees            $1,350
---------------------------=======

Total                                 $24,777.00

Premium Perk 

As a premium perk I will send you a bench that is one of my designs and handmade personally by me.  These benches are made from salvaged lumber that has been refinished.  They are very sturdy yet delicate in appearance, which makes them quite suitable for the home or garden.  The cost of shipping may apply for long distances.

story:
The Cause:

Protecting Haiti's coral reefs through “immersion learning."


The severely overfished reefs of Haiti are being overgrown by slimy algae because there are not enough fish to eat the algae. But there is hope because the biodiversity remains high – the imbalance can be cured naturally if the fish are allowed to grow to maturity and reproduce. Reef Check prides itself on implementing economically sustainable and ecologically sound solutions. Areas of the sea need to be set aside where fishing is banned to allow fish to return, grow and reproduce. They in turn will eat the algae and in a few years the coral reefs will return to their former glory. Given the large numbers of Haitian fishermen, incentives will be required to gain their support and participation for setting aside some coral reefs as Marine Managed Areas (MMAs). Fishermen could then also catch more fish outside these areas. But how to gain their support?

The key is the kids. In Haiti, over 95% of the people do not know how to swim, and there is no marine science taught in schools -- therefore they know very little about the underwater world off their coast. By training kids (6 to 16) to swim, snorkel and start to learn basic marine biology, we will start to change how Haitian families talk and think about the ocean. The kids come home and tell their parents about how reefs can repair themselves naturally and reef fish will return. We have done this at La Caleta marine park in neighboring Dominican Republic and the fish came back in 2 years. By getting kids excited about the ocean, we can gain the support of fishermen’s families to better manage this renewable resource resulting in more fish and more jobs.

In a few years, some of these students can enter Reef Check's EcoDiver Program, where we train university students to become citizen scientists so that they can monitor coral reefs, track their health and how that affects the health of their economy and their future. Starting with 600 applicants from Haiti’s top universities the 32 trainees are now PADI certified scuba divers and Reef Check EcoDivers.

Recently, the government declared two new marine parks and already two Reef Check EcoDivers have been hired to help manage them. Other graduates will join the tourism industry and create a more diverse economy that depends on seeing big fish not just eating them. But first we need to teach the kids to swim and get the fishermen on our side... and we need your help.

With your help we will expand the program to include children of fishermen living along the coast of Ft Liberte, in northern Haiti.


The Impact

Check out a video by the New York Times to fully understand the impact of this project: 

http://www.nytimes.com/video/world/americas/100000001030590/ruin-and-hope-on-haitis-reefs.html


What We Need

We seek funds to provide immersion learning for children of fishermen so that we begin now to develop the critically needed community support for two new marine parks that have been declared on paper this year, but are not yet being managed. We invite you to visit our work sites in Haiti and the DR and to meet the student EcoDivers in both countries.

For $5000 we can train 25 kids ages 6 to 16 in a week long training course that covers swimming, snorkeling and basic marine science done in their local language Creole. Until 2013, Haiti was the only country in the Caribbean without a marine park. A well-managed reef can provide up to 15 tons of food fish per year. Help us to save the reefs, educate the kids and create more fish and jobs in Haiti.


Who We Are

Reef Check is an international non-profit organization focused on marine conservation in over 90 countries. Our programs rely on over 10,000 volunteer citizen-scientists around the world – in other words Reef Check is about 99% volunteer driven and empowered.  
Our MISSION is to EMPOWER residents of local communities to PROTECT and rehabilitate reef ecosystems along the entire coast of California and in tropical countries worldwide. We do so through grassroots marine EDUCATION, RESEARCH and Conservation.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help get the word out about Haiti by sharing our campaign to your page. Or donate directly to the Reef Check Organization on our website here:http://www.reefcheck.org/


Please support us that we may support Haiti!

story:
Update: Thanks to the contributions received here I have been able to buy 12 new game cameras and fund a crew of undergraduates and myself to conduct preliminary research  through the summer of 2016. I am, however, excited to continue this campaign. If I can raise sufficient funds ($8000) I will be able to conduct this research full-time through the winter and summer of 2017 - which is necessary for me to robustly answer these questions. I am so grateful to all my supporters for their help.

In brief:

  • Wild introduced burros dig wells of more than a meter deep to reach subsurface water in the Sonoran desert.
  • Many species use these wells for drinking water
  • This behavior has never been described in the literature, likely due to prevailing negative attitudes towards introduced species
  • My research is motivated by the desire to understand these species as they are, without a priori categorization of them as 'pests'

Four years ago I was camping on a beautiful river in the Sonoran desert of Arizona. This river winds through a brutally gorgeous landscape that looks like melted wax; old multicolored volcanic debris, steep canyons, saguaros and cottonwoods. As a field biologist, I was becoming interested in how ecologists understand and describe invasive species. I was beginning to realize that to demonize a species because it doesn't belong may prevent us from seeing what it actually does. It was on this trip that I began seeing, after years of working and camping on this river without noticing, these strange features: wells. 

Three years later, I have documented the origin of these wells, and confirmed my suspicions: burros dig wells. Burro well-digging has never been described in the scientific literature. Burros are introduced species that are commonly described by the scientific community as "scourges". Nearly all primary scientific effect-studies about them focus on how burros overgraze and outcompete native species. Yet these studies have failed to yield generalizable understandings because of weak methodologies and their failure to consider the ecological context of apex predator control. This is the essentialist paradigm that this well-digging phenomena  forcefully brings into question. 

I am now doing my PhD research on this phenomena, which connects to a growing body of scientific thought that is shifting our paradigms about introduced/invasive species. As this paradigm changes, conservation biology may transition from a field focused in many ways on 'belonging' and 'nativity' to one focused on process and ecological context.

From my preliminary data, it appears that burros are significantly increasing water availability in the desert. I have found sites that are very arid, with limited and intermittent surface water, where burro-wells maintain access to subterranean water throughout the year. Furthermore, in certain contexts, these burro-wells appear to function as vegetation nurseries; significantly more cottonwood and willow seedlings germinated in abandoned burro-wells than in adjacent riverbank zones.


With a small grant from ASU I was able to buy several trail cameras and have documented 13 species using these wells, including bighorn sheep, and I am surely missing many smaller bodied species. In fact, javelina and cattle appear to use these wells at a greater frequency than even burros.

This research is revealing a more nuanced understanding of this introduced species. Not only is this relevant to the management of wild burros, but also to the paradigms which shape our understandings of ecological communities in general. I am currently unfunded during the summers, when this field work takes place. Any donation you can make will help me buy gasoline and field equipment (cameras, batteries). While I have set a humble benchmark for this fundraising site, if I were to be able to work on this project full time next summer, 2017, (~$8000) I would be able to gather more data to understand how this behavior, and burros in general, interact with their local ecosystems. Primarily, I need to map the distribution of this behavior, of these well-features, across the larger southwestern landscape to understand how common this phenomena is, and to what extent it influences the availability and persistence of water.

If you are interested in reading more about some of the new perspectives emerging in ecology and conservation, visit the papers below, or email me for the pdfs.

References

Carroll SP, Loye JE, Dingle H, Mathieson M, Famula TR, Zalucki MP. 2005. And the beak shall inherit – evolution in response to invasion. Ecology Letters 8:944-951.

Collier MJ. 2015. Novel ecosystems and social-ecological resilience. Landscape Ecology 30:1363-1369.

Wallach AD, Bekoff M, Nelson MP, Ramp D. 2015b. Promoting predators and compassionate conservation. Conservation Biology 0(0): 1-4.

Wallach AD, Carroll SP, Ripple WJ. 2015a. Novel trophic cascades: apex predators enable coexistence. TREE-1898: 1-8.

story:
Overview

Wild salmon in Clayoquot Sound are rapidly sliding towards extinction—only 2 Chinook salmon returned to spawn in Tofino Creek last year. We're working hard to save wild salmon!

Fish farms are having major impacts on wild salmon populations. But momentum is building to get salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound. We need you to help to make this happen.

Clayoquot Action is a longstanding defender of what makes this place so special. Our founders have over 35 years experience in local waters.

Support this campaign to help keep Clayoquot Sound wild and majestic. These are salmon forests. We are salmon people.

Photo: Sander Jain

 

What We Need & What You Get

Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) is our salmon farm watchdog program. During COVID the Department of Fisheries has cut monitoring, making this grassroots program more important than ever before. And now, Cermaq (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Corp.) has towed a new experimental fish farm into Millar Channel near Ahousat, posing new threats that must be monitored and exposed.

Retrieving farmed fish samples from Cermaq's Hydrolicer on a fish farm near Tofino

Our fish farm monitoring program, Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) gets out on the water near Tofino. We keep an eye on this polluting industry, which otherwise operates out of sight, out of mind. We've been able to expose stories which no-one would have heard about, such as mass die-offs, viral outbreaks, sea lice epidemics; and we get those stories in the news to build political pressure.

Our Going Viral project (powered up by our 2019 Indiegogo!) was able to expose the fact that all but one salmon farm tested in Clayoquot Sound was contaminated with the deadly Norwegian Piscine orthoreovirus (PRV).

We travel deep up Clayoquot Sound, year-round in all weather, to collect samples and monitor what's happening on the ground. This year, we'll be paying special attention to the new experimental farm, and how we can minimize its threat to wild salmon.

We've made the national news several times exposing fish farms awful environmental record
 

Your donation will power up CSI by putting gas in volunteers' boats, chartering boats when necessary, sending samples to the lab for testing, and helping with the costs of equipment and video production to help spread the word.

Donate generously and get great perks in return!
 

The Impact

Clayoquot Sound is the largest and most famous ancient rainforest left on Vancouver Island in British Columbia, Canada. The Clayoquot Summer blockades of 1993 which stopped the chainsaws were the largest act of civil disobedience in Canadian history.

'The War of the Woods' in Clayoquot Sound—Canada's largest-ever act of civil disobedience.

Yet all of this is being put at risk by open-net pen salmon farms. Wild salmon runs which used to return to spawn in the tens of thousands, now only return in tens. If wild salmon go the way of the dodo, wildlife will starve and so will the forests.

Clayoquot Salmon Investigation shines a spotlight on the local face of the global salmon farming industry. In past we have been successful in breaking media stories about Creative Salmon’s tainted bloodwater discharge into Tofino Harbour; as well as Cermaq’s mass die-off, a sea lion massacre, on-going sea lice epidemic (three years running), and their controversial chemical warfare to manage their sea lice crisis. We were able to pressure the BC government to investigate all pesticide use on fish farms in BC, as well as all blood water discharge from fish processing plants.

All of these stories in the news are turning people off salmon farming. A 2018 poll showed almost 75% of British Columbians want salmon farms removed from the ocean.

And now the momentum has begun! In 2018 Washington state banned salmon farms from their waters by 2022. British Columbia announced in 2018 that salmon farms will be removed from the Broughton Archipelago by 2022. Canada's government pledged in 2019 to transition from open-net pen salmon farms to closed containment by 2025. And now in 2020, B.C.’s First Nations Leadership Council (FNLC) is calling for an immediate end to marine-based salmon farming in the province.

Clayoquot Action is also calling for salmon farms to be removed from Clayoquot Sound immediately. Please join the movement to help make this happen!

 

Check out the perks! 

Beautiful Kyler Vos prints.

 

A 3 night stay at Long Beach Lodge on Cox Bay includes 3 day surf rental from Live to Surf!

 

Clayoquot Wolf limited edition giclee on canvas. (20" x 27")

 

 

What if we exceed our goal?

By joining Clayoquot Action’s Indiegogo community you will be helping to get salmon farms out of the oceans in British Columbia.

 If the goal of raising $11,000 is exceeded, here are a few items from the top of our to-do list: 

  • $5,000 will power up our campaign to ban pesticide use on salmon farms in Clayoquot Sound.
  • $15,000 will power up our work to help prevent a sea lice epidemic in 2021.
  • $45,000 will hire a full-time CSI field and researcher coordinator for a year to help get polluting salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound!

 

Who is Clayoquot Action?

Clayoquot Action stands for democratic rights, indigenous rights, and the rights of Mother Earth. Together with local volunteers and a small staff—backed online by people around the world—we run strategic, people-powered campaigns to help Clayoquot Sound remain one of the most beautiful places left on earth.

Clayoquot Action founders Bonny Glambeck and Dan Lewis were key organizers of the 1993 Clayoquot Summer protests. For over thirty years, they have been working to protect this awe-inspiring place from threats due to clearcut logging, industrial-scale mining, oil tankers, and salmon farming.

What is Clayoquot Sound?

Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Region, near Tofino BC, is the Last Great Rainforest on Vancouver Island—world famous for monumental cedars, bears, wolves and whales.

Clayoquot Action recognizes and supports the Indigenous rights and title of the Hesquiaht, Ahousaht, and Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations—stewards since time immemorial of the lands and waters now called Clayoquot Sound.

The nitrogen which fertilizes these magnificent rainforests comes from a marine source—in the bodies of wild salmon, when they return to their natal stream to spawn and die. Black bears, timber wolves, bald eagles and many other wildlife species feast on the salmon, spreading the nutrients far and wide.

Wild salmon are the lifeblood of these ancient forests and cultures, providing food, livelihoods and fertilizing the ecosystem which sustains life.

 

Want to learn more?

Check out SalmonPeople.ca and take the Wild Salmon Pledge. You'll be kept up to date on the latest developments, and you'll be the first to know when you can take specific actions to help protect wild salmon.

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow Clayoquot Action on social media. Please help us promote this campaign—share this page with your family and friends!

- Clayoquot Action on Instagram

- Clayoquot Action on Facebook

- Clayoquot Action on Twitter
story_txt:
Overview
Wild salmon in Clayoquot Sound are rapidly sliding towards extinction—only 2 Chinook salmon returned to spawn in Tofino Creek last year. We're working hard to save wild salmon!
Fish farms are having major impacts on wild salmon populations. But momentum is building to get salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound. We need you to help to make this happen.
Clayoquot Action is a longstanding defender of what makes this place so special. Our founders have over 35 years experience in local waters.
Support this campaign to help keep Clayoquot Sound wild and majestic. These are salmon forests. We are salmon people.

Photo: Sander Jain
 

What We Need & What You Get
Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) is our salmon farm watchdog program. During COVID the Department of Fisheries has cut monitoring, making this grassroots program more important than ever before. And now, Cermaq (a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Corp.) has towed a new experimental fish farm into Millar Channel near Ahousat, posing new threats that must be monitored and exposed.

Retrieving farmed fish samples from Cermaq's Hydrolicer on a fish farm near Tofino
Our fish farm monitoring program, Clayoquot Salmon Investigation (CSI) gets out on the water near Tofino. We keep an eye on this polluting industry, which otherwise operates out of sight, out of mind. We've been able to expose stories which no-one would have heard about, such as mass die-offs, viral outbreaks, sea lice epidemics; and we get those stories in the news to build political pressure.
Our Going Viral project (powered up by our 2019 Indiegogo!) was able to expose the fact that all but one salmon farm tested in Clayoquot Sound was contaminated with the deadly Norwegian Piscine orthoreovirus (PRV).
We travel deep up Clayoquot Sound, year-round in all weather, to collect samples and monitor what's happening on the ground. This year, we'll be paying special attention to the new experimental farm, and how we can minimize its threat to wild salmon.

We've made the national news several times exposing fish farms awful environmental record
 
Your donation will power up CSI by putting gas in volunteers' boats, chartering boats when necessary, sending samples to the lab for testing, and helping with the costs of equipment and video production to help spread the word.
Donate generously and get great perks in return! 

The Impact
Clayoquot Sound is the largest and most famous ancient rainforest left on Vancouver Island in British Columbia, Canada. The Clayoquot Summer blockades of 1993 which stopped the chainsaws were the largest act of civil disobedience in Canadian history.

'The War of the Woods' in Clayoquot Sound—Canada's largest-ever act of civil disobedience.
Yet all of this is being put at risk by open-net pen salmon farms. Wild salmon runs which used to return to spawn in the tens of thousands, now only return in tens. If wild salmon go the way of the dodo, wildlife will starve and so will the forests.
Clayoquot Salmon Investigation shines a spotlight on the local face of the global salmon farming industry. In past we have been successful in breaking media stories about Creative Salmon’s tainted bloodwater discharge into Tofino Harbour; as well as Cermaq’s mass die-off, a sea lion massacre, on-going sea lice epidemic (three years running), and their controversial chemical warfare to manage their sea lice crisis. We were able to pressure the BC government to investigate all pesticide use on fish farms in BC, as well as all blood water discharge from fish processing plants.
All of these stories in the news are turning people off salmon farming. A 2018 poll showed almost 75% of British Columbians want salmon farms removed from the ocean.
And now the momentum has begun! In 2018 Washington state banned salmon farms from their waters by 2022. British Columbia announced in 2018 that salmon farms will be removed from the Broughton Archipelago by 2022. Canada's government pledged in 2019 to transition from open-net pen salmon farms to closed containment by 2025. And now in 2020, B.C.’s First Nations Leadership Council (FNLC) is calling for an immediate end to marine-based salmon farming in the province.
Clayoquot Action is also calling for salmon farms to be removed from Clayoquot Sound immediately. Please join the movement to help make this happen!
 
Check out the perks! 
Beautiful Kyler Vos prints.


 
A 3 night stay at Long Beach Lodge on Cox Bay includes 3 day surf rental from Live to Surf!


 
Clayoquot Wolf limited edition giclee on canvas. (20" x 27")
 

 
What if we exceed our goal?

By joining Clayoquot Action’s Indiegogo community you will be helping to get salmon farms out of the oceans in British Columbia.
 If the goal of raising $11,000 is exceeded, here are a few items from the top of our to-do list: 

$5,000 will power up our campaign to ban pesticide use on salmon farms in Clayoquot Sound.
$15,000 will power up our work to help prevent a sea lice epidemic in 2021.
$45,000 will hire a full-time CSI field and researcher coordinator for a year to help get polluting salmon farms out of Clayoquot Sound!

 
Who is Clayoquot Action?
Clayoquot Action stands for democratic rights, indigenous rights, and the rights of Mother Earth. Together with local volunteers and a small staff—backed online by people around the world—we run strategic, people-powered campaigns to help Clayoquot Sound remain one of the most beautiful places left on earth.
Clayoquot Action founders Bonny Glambeck and Dan Lewis were key organizers of the 1993 Clayoquot Summer protests. For over thirty years, they have been working to protect this awe-inspiring place from threats due to clearcut logging, industrial-scale mining, oil tankers, and salmon farming.
What is Clayoquot Sound?
Clayoquot Sound UNESCO Biosphere Region, near Tofino BC, is the Last Great Rainforest on Vancouver Island—world famous for monumental cedars, bears, wolves and whales.
Clayoquot Action recognizes and supports the Indigenous rights and title of the Hesquiaht, Ahousaht, and Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations—stewards since time immemorial of the lands and waters now called Clayoquot Sound.
The nitrogen which fertilizes these magnificent rainforests comes from a marine source—in the bodies of wild salmon, when they return to their natal stream to spawn and die. Black bears, timber wolves, bald eagles and many other wildlife species feast on the salmon, spreading the nutrients far and wide.
Wild salmon are the lifeblood of these ancient forests and cultures, providing food, livelihoods and fertilizing the ecosystem which sustains life.

 
Want to learn more?
Check out SalmonPeople.ca and take the Wild Salmon Pledge. You'll be kept up to date on the latest developments, and you'll be the first to know when you can take specific actions to help protect wild salmon.

- Clayoquot Action on Facebook
- Clayoquot Action on Twitter

story:
We would like to firstly acknowledge that these lands are on the unceded and shared territories of the Cowlitz, Chehalis, and Nisqually peoples. These groups have inhabited this area since time immemorial, and deserve protection and respect for their ancestral lands. 

UPDATE

As of new years 2021 we have finalized our agreement to buy 20 acres of old growth forest from bark beaters. In our negotiations, lawyers fees have gone up and we are now seeking to raise an additional $4000 on go fund me so we can finalize the deal by the end of January. If you have the means to contribute please visit our go fund me here.

The Campaign 

Several weeks ago activists and community organizers discovered that a local logging company in the Deschutes watershed south of Olympia had plans to log in a stand of old growth forest containing trees upwards of 600 years old. After circulating a petition that has at last count received more than 4000 signatures, the local company, Bark Beaters LLC., agreed to give us the opportunity to protect the 20-acre old growth forest. They have given us one year to raise money for the legally binding 100-year protection of this ancient forest. 

Upon visiting the grove we found ancient Douglas fir trees upwards of 5 feet in diameter, the forest was filled with ancient red cedars, douglas firs, and large western hemlock trees. This 20-acre forest is one of the last remaining old growth forests in the Deschutes watershed that flows into Capital Lake in Olympia. The forest contains a vibrant canopy structure that provides habitat for endangered species such as the Marbled Murrelet and Spotted Owl, with an understory of rare plants thick with lichens and fungi. 

 

What We Need 

As a local logging company, Bark Beaters has been extremely willing to work with us to protect this forest, but we need your help. We need to raise $35,000 to purchase a timber lease from the company and to protect this forest for the next 100 years. By contributing to this campaign you will help us protect one of the last ancient forests in the Deschutes Watershed from clear-cut logging. Bark Beaters has agreed to sell us the timber lease for $35,000. Any extra funds will either be applied to obtaining more land surrounding this parcel to provide further buffer and habitat trees, or will be used in future conservation efforts. Our team is actively looking for similar lands in the greater Puget Sound ecoregion, and having available funds would make future acquisitions much easier. Please contribute as much as you can to help save this forest, and of course, spread the word!

 

Your Impact

We started this campaign with a few activists discovering that old growth logging has not yet come to an end, and we now, thanks to the generosity of Bark Beaters Lumber Company, have the incredible opportunity to save one of these last wild places. This forest is home to endangered species and has been growing here since the last Ice Age. Opportunities to save a place like this are once in a lifetime. Almost all of these areas are already gone and without action, all old growth forests left unprotected will soon disappear. By contributing to this campaign you are helping us create a more wild world. You are allowing these ancient trees to grow for another hundred years and allowing future generations the opportunity to see these forests and preserve them even longer into the future. You are also helping to store a tremendous amount of carbon dioxide, preserve rare and endangered plants and animals from extinction, and save trees that have seen the rise, and may see the fall of Western civilization.

 

Risks & Challenges

We need to raise $35,000 to protect this forest before July 2021, if we don't this forest will likely be clear-cut. So please help spread the word! Once we raise the needed funds we will be purchasing a 100-year timber lease to protect this forest. Initially, it will be owned and managed by Universal Wildlands SPC (a social purpose corporation created for the purpose of protecting wild places). Universal Wildlands will seek to find a nonprofit to donate this land too, however that may require additional fundraising. We want to make sure that whoever owns this timber lease does not use it. This is why we will be exceedingly careful in ensuring that its future owner is working for the trees, not for money. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

We realize that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Everyone can help spread the word, share this on social media, talk to your friends and family, and reach out to any tree-loving individual that you know to let them know that they can help save a forest! If you know any influencers or larger donors interested in supporting this project please get in touch! Thank you for helping us save this ancient forest!

 

 

Call 360-989-8067 to get involved.

story:
Support the 2015 I Sea Change Expedition!

Ahoy! My name is Orestis Herodotou and I'm part of the crew for the 5Gyres 2015 Sea Change Expedition. We're sailing from Bermuda to NYC to collect samples of plastic pollution in the Atlantic. Help us share what we learn and empower action around the world to keep our oceans healthy and end single use plastic waste!


The Expedition

We'll be aboard the Mystic, a 170 ft schooner tall ship. She's a beauty, but don't expect a leisure cruise. We'll be hard at work collecting data (plastic pieces!) with our special "manta" trawls, which are special nets designed to catch even the tiniest plastic particles. The measurements we take will further help scientists understand how our oceans and ocean wildlife are affected by plastic pollution, and make our models and estimates on the amount and location of the plastic more accurate. We've learned that plastic doesn't just float on top of the ocean, so we're also using vertical trawling to see how things change the deeper we go. For more info check out the gallery tab above or sail over to the expedition website for details and see who else is aboard!
Your donation helps support my spot on the trip!

Here's a video from the 2013 expedition (with fun music):



About Me


Hi! I'm Orestis. Some of my friends call me "Island Time". I live in the SF Bay Area and love to sail! I've been involved with several previous projects in the past like Project Kaisei, the Plastiki Expedition, and Spirit of the Sea, to raise awareness about ocean plastics and the dangerous impacts they are having our on marine ecosystems.
I really enjoy teaching sailing and taking people out on the water, especially if it's their first time. I've worked as a youth sailing instructor, teaching kids all the skills they need to sail their own boat, and also helping them learn about ocean environmental stewardship. 
I've been a proud member of the world renowned CAL Sailing Club for several years, which is a local cooperative, volunteer run club in Berkeley CA that makes sailing accessible for everyone.
I am very excited to be participating in the Sea Change Expedition. It has been dream of mine to be able to take part in some serious research efforts and help make a greater impact. 
My goal is to bring home an even deeper understanding of the issues surrounding plastic pollution, and help share with my local community by developing educational programs and citizen science projects that get more people involved with stopping plastic pollution. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, don't worry there are tons of things you can do to help out:

  • Find a way YOU can reduce and eliminate single use plastics from your lifestyle.
  • Help out at a local beach clean up. Or just go to the beach and enjoy yourself without leaving anything behind!
  • Follow the expedition on twitter @5gyres and @orestishero to learn about our research.
  • Encourage your friends, family, and community  to support legislation to ban microbeads! 
  • Click here to learn even more!!!

Thanks so much for your support!

Bonus video: "Wildman" - Pickin' at the Dock of the Bay

story:
I have an idea

My idea is to teach the homebrewing community that there's better ways to brew without polluting the air with those inefficient propane burners. Going green with brews doesn't mean green bottles... it's a whole lot more.

Getting it started

My cause is a difficult one to expose, so my idea needs some backing to get started. I'm opening a retail store selling craft beers and wine and homebrew equipment. I will have space to teach people, and this teaching will be offered at no cost to those wanting to learn. Some of the profits of the retail space will be used to increase exposure of environmentally friendly brewing practices and hopefully gain the eyes of big brewing companies. These companies dump hundreds of tons of materials that could be composted because they have no one to give it to. Actually they just have no one to pick it up.

In speaking with a local brewery I was told the problem is that it's expensive to haul the stuff to a farmer, or someone who needs that much compost, so there has to be an agreement between the two in order for them to make it worth while. Hopefully with start of my business I can help to promote this waste and turn it into something valuable.

The equipment and space cost money, a lot of money, and although the retail sales will pay the bills, it won't help to expose the impact that brewers have on the environment. 

Help!

Please help me get going and get the word out about making beer brewing an environmentally safe practice. You'll be funding a good cause and reducing the carbon footprint of brewers everywhere.

story:
I have been working in Ecuador as an ecologist, out on the high-elevation grasslands for ten years now. The biodiversity of the country drew me. The creativity and the passion of the people keep me.

Perhaps you've read about the "minga" in Me to We, by Craig and Marc Kielburger (Free the Children). Or have you seen the disappearing glaciers on the Andes in Al Gore's film, An Inconvenient Truth? Both are awe inspiring and real stories.

If you haven't heard of the Last Ice Merchant, read about Baltazar Ushca's inspiring life story via Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TheLastIceMerchant?fref=ts.

Go Tell it on the Mountain

Indigenous people I know well, friends of Baltazar, organized among 120 families in four communities to help themselves last year:

  • A community leader was given an opportunity by Ecuador's environment ministry to see sustainable water projects in Colombia.
  • Mariano Toazo came back inspired to help his friends. 
  • Families each dedicated one member daily to assist with manual channelization of Andean glacier melt water into a new reservoir to water their cattle.
  • All permission for their communities' share of the water was granted by the environment ministry; the project is legally sound.
  • Their goal was to improve a community pasture, to raise more funds via higher milk sales to nearby Riobamba, to offer more livestock production in their part of the foothills, to achieve a sustainable food source for their children; the project is socially sound.
  • They achieved their goal, almost; no one helped them ensure that the project is environmentally sound.

The Final Challenge

Enthusiasm cannot get them through their final financial planning:

  • Mariano's group was certain the environment ministry would guide them through the project, but it didn't happen.
  • Their channels are eroding the fine, volcanic soils; they see the problem and they know the environment ministry cares as much as they do. But sadly, financial resources in government cannot be steered to community projects.
  • I felt I could help and raised $5,000 from my retirement savings; the goal was 1000 m of PVC tubes and one valve to control water flow and seal it from eroding the delicate soils. I and others have the luxury of planning ahead.
  • Some in the poorer parts of the world plan for survival; they care about the earth, but cannot plan for the unforeseen problems. My friends didn't get into this bind on their own. Climate warming is drying their pastures and even threatening the glaciers that have up to now sustained life in the foothills.
  • Want to see more: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bl97vAVI3DE&amp...
  • I am hoping to count on my friends for the next $5,000 to safely carry the water the next 1000 m to Mariano's friends' pastures.
  • Protect the environment and the future for some wonderful families. 

Thank you.

Chimborazo is the mountain whose glacier we can thankfully still tap for its lifeblood water. Chimborazo comes from the native word for snow:

  • Chimborazo is known locally as the people's guardian.
  • Spread the message about this campaign.
  • Thank you for using Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hi! 

I am Natalie Swain, a senior at UC Berkeley and for the last two months I have been interning abroad at an NGO in Madrid, Spain called Asociación CONI. 

CONI's main goal is the international cooperation for development in Guatemala, through:

  • The native support within comprehensive development initiatives aimed at social promotion of disadvantaged population groups such as women, children, indigenous peoples, youth at risk, etc.
  • The creation and strengthening of local networks for training and promotion of human capital that is aimed at generating sustainable and independent development.


What is this campaign for?

In a few words:
In my last three weeks as an intern at CONI I want to raise money to donate  120 HELPS Gravity Water Filters in order to help equip the 120 families living in Chahilpec with access to year-round clean drinking water.

In a few more words:
CONI has been working with the community of Chahilpec since 2013 after the director of the school there reached out to CONI for help designing a comprehensive development program. 

The first step of the program was to equip the school with all the basic necessities such as furniture, notebooks, backpacks, blackboards, pens, etc., and now that we have provided them with those materials, the next step in the Strategic Plan is the provision of safe drinking water, both at school and at home. 

Currently the community is drinking rainwater, collected from the sheet metal roofs of their homes that are often oxidized, which leads to Chahilpec residents often drinking water which carries bacteria and would not be considered sanitary by any health standards.

There are 120 families who live in Chahilpec, and in order to bring clean drinking water to the whole community we must raise enough money to buy each family a  HELPS Gravity Water Filter for families to be able to filter the water they currently drink from the roofs of their homes.


How much money is needed?

We need $4,320 to purchase 120 HELPS Gravity Water Filters in order to provide clean drinking water for the entire Chahilpec Community.
  • Each Gravity Water Filter costs $36 USD.
  • There are 120 families who live with unsanitary drinking water in Chahilpec.
  • Therefore, $36 x 120 = $4,320 goal.


Our Reach Goal

  • If we reach our goal and raise $4,320 we will continue to campaign and raise an additional $3,275 to buy a complete potable water system for the Chahilpec School.
  • The system includes pipes to run the water across the school grounds, hand sinks for the children and faculty, and toilets with running water from the filtration system to replace their current outhouses.


History of Chahilpec + CONI

The Families of the Chahilpec Community 

The village of Chahilpec is a community of Mayans living  in a rural area of Guatemala. There are 29,525 communities like this in Guatemala, who live far removed from the rest of the country (to give you an idea, they do not even speak Spanish, they only speak the Mayan language of their ethnicity: Q'ekchí'). The Guatemalan government does not have sufficient means to provide for all its people, so these communities often do not have access to basic health and education services.

About 120 families live in the community of Chahilpec, with just about 300 children, and only 58 of these kids were enrolled in school in 2013. The school had no resources, materials, or proper equipment, so in most cases parents preferred to take their children to work with them versus leave them in school.

In 2013, the director of the Chahilpec School, Pablo William, contacted CONI to ask for help. He had heard about CONI through another ongoing project a few miles away in another community. During the second half of 2013 there were two CONI technician visits to the community to understand their needs, and work with the parent committee on a possible collaboration. As a result of these visits, CONI designed in collaboration with the community, a comprehensive development program, with a term of 5 to 10 years.The plan aims to tackle various aspects of the residents school and home lives, which are ordered from highest to lowest priority in accordance with the vision the parents have for the community: school equipment, drinking water at school and at home, kitchen equipment for the high school, improved stoves (for cooking fire) in homes, equipment and training to provide a community health clinic (primary care clinic / pharmacy), build a module for school classrooms, equip the library with materials, construction of recreational areas and school sports fields, adult pre-professional training, implementation of a microcredit program and a revolving fund for productive projects in the community.


Our Progress in Chahilpec So Far:

In 2014, CONI began work on the Chahilpec Strategic Plan. In February, CONI received a grant from the Roviralta Foundation for €8,000 to equip the school with furniture, notebooks, backpacks, blackboards, pens, etc. The new materials had an immediate effect on school enrollment. After seeing the improvements done to the school, parents began to enroll their children in droves and today there is now 121 kids enrolled in the Chahilpec School, up from the 58 children enrolled  in 2013.


What if you like the work CONI is doing, but don't have money to give?

There are other ways you can help! Please spread the word and share this campaign with your friends via email, Facebook, and Twitter. By helping us share our campaign, you can make a huge impact without ever reaching for your wallet!
