story:
Help us to save Indonesia’s endangered wildlife, restore its decimated forests and educate and support local people who live nearby.

One bird, one primate, one tree, one person at a time. We need your support to do it.

All over our beautiful country, native birds are being pushed to the brink of extinction, caught in sights of poachers and wildlife traders. Indonesia has the second-highest number of threatened birds in the world. The stories of these beautiful birds trapped and hunted, then sold on the black market, are gut-wrenching.

Add to that the fact that it’s estimated our country has lost more than 72% of its primary forest, and that deforestation is occurring each year at a rate of 2.4 million hectares – that is an area more than twice the size of Jamaica.

On top of that, wild populations of Indonesia’s orangutans – an endangered and protected species – have shrunk by half the in last decade.

It breaks our heart. And so we are out there every day doing something about it.

We are Friends of the National Parks Foundation, a small Indonesian non-profit running conservation projects designed to protect Indonesia’s endangered wildlife, restore its forests and support local communities. Our projects have been recognized by global organizations including the United Nations Development Programme and the Whitley Fund for Nature.

We’ve been operating for 17 years and have achieved some great things – such as saving one of the world’s rarest birds and Bali’s emblem bird, the Bali starling, from the brink of extinction in the wild, and transforming a remote island into a unique sanctuary for endangered birds.

Canadian Aboriginal artist and filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin once famously said:

“When the last tree is cut, the last fish is caught, and the last river is polluted; when to breathe the air is sickening, you will realise, too late, that wealth is not in bank accounts and that you can’t eat money.”

How very true.

But still the destruction of our planet and its biodiversity doesn’t stop.

Now we need your help.

Urgently Needed Today

We desperately need a truck to help run our programs on the tiny hilly island of Nusa Penida, just off the coast of Bali, Indonesia. The island is the home of our sanctuary for endangered birds, especially the precious Bali starling – the very bird we have helped to bring back from the brink of extinction.

We’ll turn this truck into a mobile classroom and a library. And it will be fitted out so we can use it to:

  • take seedlings across the island to help replant the forest
  • transport volunteers and our staff to project sites

  • and to the field for bird and turtle monitoring visits
  • bring villagers to our English club, conservation education classes and the courses we run teaching ways to make a living that are environmentally-friendly

We would simply be able to do so much more – quicker and better – on the 200km2 island with a multi-use classroom on wheels.

Right now we only have motorbikes. When we need something bigger we have to hire a vehicle. On remote Nusa Penida, which is 40 minutes by boat from Bali, that can be expensive. And if it happens to be a holiday or ceremonial day – there are many in Bali, religion is an integral part of daily life – then forget it.

About Us

Our projects respect the interdependence of wildlife, habitat and local communities and are holistic and sustainable.

We run projects in Bali and Kalimantan, including wildlife rehabilitation, the breeding and release of critically endangered birds, and reforestation. Our community development work includes environmental education, and teaching sustainable environmentally-friendly ways to make a living.

FNPF – which has been operating since 1997 – receives no government funding. We have won the support of donors from around the world, including the like of the Humane Society International (Australia), Boeing, US Fish and Wildlife Service, Australia’s Taronga Zoo’s Conservation …  

Check out some of our media coverage - we have featured in National Geographic, the Sydney Morning Herald,  Scientific American, and in-flight magazines by Jetstar among many, many others.

Conservation Haven On Nusa Penida

If we do say so ourselves we think our Nusa Penida bird sanctuary is pretty amazing. The project has received kudos and recognition for organizations around the world and it belongs to the Wildlife Land Trust’s network of sanctuaries.  On top of that each year 300 to 400 volunteers, from Indonesia and across the world, come to Nusa Penida to get involved in our programs. Some stay a few days, some stay for months.

The sanctuary – the first in Indonesia to be established in an inhabited area – was specifically set up to help save the Bali starling, one of world’s most endangered birds and the province’s emblem.  Today the sanctuary, which covers Nusa Penida and two small nearby islands is home to at least 100 Bali starlings. When the project was started in 2006 there were estimated to be fewer than 10 such birds surviving in the wild.

It’s all possible because we were able to persuade the island’s 46 villages to introduce traditional regulations – which govern day-to-day life – to protect the birds from poachers and wildlife traders. No mean feat in a country where endangered birds can fetch thousands of dollars on the black market.

We have set up a conservation center – which is currently upgrading to new premises - where we breed birds and also rehabilitate and release ex-captive endemic birds. We were very excited when our first lot of captive-bred Bali starling chicks were born at our center late last year - we plan to release some of the half dozen healthy new arrivals into the wild later on.

We have a nursery at the center, and have grown thousands of saplings to help restore the islands’ degraded forests. Each year we give away tens of thousands of saplings to the local community for free.

In return for the support of the community we run development projects, including a pilot farming project, conservation and English language classes, an education center, and provide scholarships for school students – ensuring more than 60 local students can attend high school or university each year. These projects not only improve community well-being, but enable local people to get involved in conservation.


We can do all of this work more effectively, efficiently and successfully with a mobile classroom using a multi-use vehicle.

Why Back Us

You are reading this because you care about wildlife, nature and the environment, just like us, and we love you for it. Every donated dollar counts, we appreciate whatever you can do to support us – each donation moves us closer to our goal.

We are hoping you will understand why we can’t give away big perks or bonuses – we are a non-profit, and we want the money raised to go to support conservation efforts in Indonesia. That’s what it is all about after all.

You will always have our eternal gratitude and every donor will receive a special thank you e-card from our team.

  • $10 – Satu - You have our gratefulness and we will email you a thank you e-card
  • $25 – Dua - A thank you e-card and a public "Thank You" on our Facebook page
  • $50 – Tiga - All of the above, and we’ll put your name and an acknowledgement of your support up on our website for the world to see
  • $100 – Empat - Everything above, plus if you are ever want to visit Nusa Penda and volunteer and stay with us we’ll give you a 25% discount on accommodation and our program
  • $1,000 – Lima - The whole shebang on this list, plus we’ll have your name sign printed onto the side of our mobile classroom – and we will send you a photo of it

We guarantee every cent we receive will go towards funding the purchase of the multi-use mobile classroom. If we raise more than we need this money will go directly into funding our vital conservation projects.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people aren’t in a position to contribute financially. That’s okay, but you can still help in other ways:

  • Tell your family, friends, colleagues, everyone you know, about our campaign
  • Tell them how just $1 would be greatly appreciated
  • Share our campaign in an email, on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, anywhere you can
  • Visit our website: www.fnpf.org
  • Sign up for our newsletter
  • Like us on Facebook
  • Follow us on Twitter or Pinterest
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools on this page

You never know someone your refer us to might just be able to donate. Every share makes a difference.

To wrap it up the way we started, we sign off with another great quote - this one from anthropologist Margaret Mead:

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever does".

That’s what we are doing every day. Come help us!
story_txt:
Help us to save Indonesia’s endangered wildlife, restore its decimated forests and educate and support local people who live nearby.
One bird, one primate, one tree, one person at a time. We need your support to do it.All over our beautiful country, native birds are being pushed to the brink of extinction, caught in sights of poachers and wildlife traders. Indonesia has the second-highest number of threatened birds in the world. The stories of these beautiful birds trapped and hunted, then sold on the black market, are gut-wrenching.Add to that the fact that it’s estimated our country has lost more than 72% of its primary forest, and that deforestation is occurring each year at a rate of 2.4 million hectares – that is an area more than twice the size of Jamaica.On top of that, wild populations of Indonesia’s orangutans – an endangered and protected species – have shrunk by half the in last decade.It breaks our heart. And so we are out there every day doing something about it.We are Friends of the National Parks Foundation, a small Indonesian non-profit running conservation projects designed to protect Indonesia’s endangered wildlife, restore its forests and support local communities. Our projects have been recognized by global organizations including the United Nations Development Programme and the Whitley Fund for Nature.We’ve been operating for 17 years and have achieved some great things – such as saving one of the world’s rarest birds and Bali’s emblem bird, the Bali starling, from the brink of extinction in the wild, and transforming a remote island into a unique sanctuary for endangered birds.Canadian Aboriginal artist and filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin once famously said:“When the last tree is cut, the last fish is caught, and the last river is polluted; when to breathe the air is sickening, you will realise, too late, that wealth is not in bank accounts and that you can’t eat money.”How very true.But still the destruction of our planet and its biodiversity doesn’t stop.Now we need your help.Urgently Needed TodayWe desperately need a truck to help run our programs on the tiny hilly island of Nusa Penida, just off the coast of Bali, Indonesia. The island is the home of our sanctuary for endangered birds, especially the precious Bali starling – the very bird we have helped to bring back from the brink of extinction.We’ll turn this truck into a mobile classroom and a library. And it will be fitted out so we can use it to:
take seedlings across the island to help replant the forest
transport volunteers and our staff to project sites

and to the field for bird and turtle monitoring visits
bring villagers to our English club, conservation education classes and the courses we run teaching ways to make a living that are environmentally-friendly
We would simply be able to do so much more – quicker and
better – on the 200km2 island with a multi-use classroom on wheels.
Right now we only have motorbikes. When we need something
bigger we have to hire a vehicle. On remote Nusa Penida, which is 40 minutes by
boat from Bali, that can be expensive. And if it happens to be a holiday or
ceremonial day – there are many in Bali, religion is an integral part of daily
life – then forget it.
About Us
Our projects respect the interdependence of wildlife, habitat and local
communities and are holistic and sustainable. 
We run projects in Bali and Kalimantan, including wildlife
rehabilitation, the breeding and release of critically endangered birds, and reforestation.
Our community development work includes environmental education, and teaching
sustainable environmentally-friendly ways to make a living.
FNPF – which has been operating since 1997 – receives no government
funding. We have won the support of donors from around the world, including the
like of the Humane Society International (Australia), Boeing, US Fish and
Wildlife Service, Australia’s Taronga Zoo’s Conservation …  Check out some of our media coverage - we have featured in National Geographic, the Sydney Morning Herald,  Scientific American, and in-flight magazines by Jetstar among many, many others.
Conservation
Haven On Nusa Penida
If we do say so ourselves we think our Nusa
Penida bird sanctuary is pretty amazing. The project has received kudos and
recognition for organizations around the world and it belongs to the Wildlife
Land Trust’s network of sanctuaries.  On top of that each year 300 to 400 volunteers, from
Indonesia and across the world, come to Nusa Penida to get involved in our
programs. Some stay a few days, some stay for months.
The sanctuary – the first in Indonesia to be
established in an inhabited area – was specifically set up to help save the
Bali starling, one of world’s most endangered birds and the province’s emblem.  Today the sanctuary, which covers Nusa Penida
and two small nearby islands is home to at least 100 Bali starlings. When the
project was started in 2006 there were estimated to be fewer than 10 such birds
surviving in the wild.
It’s all possible because we were able to
persuade the island’s 46 villages to introduce traditional regulations – which
govern day-to-day life – to protect the birds from poachers and wildlife
traders. No mean feat in a country where endangered birds can fetch thousands
of dollars on the black market.
We have set up a conservation center – which
is currently upgrading to new premises - where we breed birds and also rehabilitate
and release ex-captive endemic birds. We were very excited when our first lot of captive-bred Bali starling chicks were born at our center late last year - we plan to release some of the half dozen healthy new arrivals into the wild later on.We have a nursery at the center, and have
grown thousands of saplings to help restore the islands’ degraded forests. Each
year we give away tens of thousands of saplings to the local community for
free.
In return for the support of the community
we run development projects, including a pilot farming project, conservation and
English language classes, an education center, and provide scholarships for
school students – ensuring more than 60 local students can attend high school
or university each year. These projects not only improve community well-being,
but enable local people to get involved in conservation.We can do all of this work more effectively,
efficiently and successfully with a mobile classroom using a multi-use vehicle.
Why Back Us
You are reading this because you care about wildlife, nature
and the environment, just like us, and we love you for it. Every donated dollar
counts, we appreciate whatever you can do to support us – each donation moves
us closer to our goal.
We are hoping you will understand why we can’t give away big
perks or bonuses – we are a non-profit, and we want the money raised to go to
support conservation efforts in Indonesia. That’s what it is all about after
all.
You will always have our eternal gratitude and every donor
will receive a special thank you e-card from our team.


$10 – Satu - You have our gratefulness and we will
email you a thank you e-card

$25 – Dua - A thank you e-card and a public "Thank
You" on our Facebook page
$50 – Tiga - All of the above, and we’ll put your name
and an acknowledgement of your support up on our website for the world to see

$100 – Empat - Everything above, plus if you are ever
want to visit Nusa Penda and volunteer and stay with us we’ll give you a 25%
discount on accommodation and our program


$1,000 – Lima - The whole shebang on this list, plus
we’ll have your name sign printed onto the side of our mobile classroom – and
we will send you a photo of it


We guarantee every cent we receive will go towards funding
the purchase of the multi-use mobile classroom. If we raise more than we need
this money will go directly into funding our vital conservation projects.
Other Ways You Can
Help
We know some people aren’t in a position to contribute
financially. That’s okay, but you can still help in other ways:

Tell your family, friends, colleagues, everyone
you know, about our campaign


Tell them how just $1 would be greatly
appreciated

Share our campaign in an email, on Facebook,
Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr, anywhere you can

Visit our website: www.fnpf.org


Sign up for our newsletter


Like us on Facebook


Follow us on Twitter or Pinterest

Use the Indiegogo share tools on this page

You never know someone your refer us to might just be able
to donate. Every share makes a difference.To wrap it up the way we started, we sign off with another great quote - this one from anthropologist Margaret Mead:
"Never doubt that a small
group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only
thing that ever does".
That’s what we are doing every day. Come help us!

story:
THE ONLY WAY TO PROTECT REMAINING CORAL REEFS IS TO EMPOWER LOCAL PEOPLE  to become ‘enlightened’ stewards of their environment. Traditional societies were often responsible stewards, aware that their actions would affect future generations, but the modern world has undermined these traditions and, like tropical rainforests, tropical coral reefs are in rapid a downward spiral. 

I'm Norm, Australian, 20years in Indonesia. You'll find everything you need to know about me at: www.greenworldbali.com & www.baliecolodge.com 

For more than 20 years I've worked on the practical issues of achieving greater sustainability. My first reef conservation campaign was in the Whitsunday Islands on the Great Barrier Reef in the 90's. Anchor damage was the problem and we solved it with No-Anchor Zones marked by the same marker buoys we're now installing in Raja Ampat. 

The last 2 years I've been connecting with the Papuan people who live on Raja Ampat's truly unique islands. I've surveyed a lot of locations and our time to protect what's left is vey limited.  In Raja Ampat we are very fortunate to be able to work fast and over a very large area with the active network of locally-owned guesthouses called homestays. 

Papuans are sad about the deteriorating condition of their coral reefs and fisheries but until now they have felt powerless to stop the decline. The Government supports local people taking responsibility for protecting and managing their natural resources and, for the first time, this  LPA program empowers them to do just that. 

Once people are empowered to take their first steps towards greater sustainability they tend to continue down that path. Stopping fishing & anchoring are the first (big) steps in a process that will lead to greater long-term sustainability for Raja Ampat's extraordinary marine environment. 

During 2017, I gave my time and my family's boat to proving this program would work. With generous funding from an American donor, Bill Price, and in cooperation with the Homestay Association, we proved the concept.

We now have 17 widely-scattered Locally Protected Areas (LPA's) protected by local rules ('SASI') and clearly defined by marker buoys. If you decide to help us we'll be able to create another 50-60 Locally Protected Areas during 2018. 

We're using a business-like approach, meaning... For the greatest benefit to the environment, and tangible results for the donors, I'm making sure that the Raja Ampat LPA Program is very good value for money. 

Example: The new LPA at Beser Bay, with 10 marker buoys, cost US$3,500. This exceptionally beautiful protected area covers around 50hectares including extensive coral reefs, small islands, seagrass beds, mangroves and sandy lagoons.

The homestays inside the Beser Bay LPA are incentivized to continually enforce the no-fishing & no-anchoring rules because it's good for their ecotourism businesses. They want to protect their natural resources and, backed by local rules, this is their first chance to stop damaging activities. 

That’s $70 per hectare to stop all fishing & anchoring which, are two of the biggest threats.. with daily enforcement of the rules by empowered and incentivized local people. We don’t know of any other organization that can equal this value for money.

With the funds raised by this campaign we will protect some of the World's most diverse coral reef ecosystems.  We need your help now to save some of the best coral reefs left anywhere in the World.

It's tangible! Our Locally Protected Areas (LPA's) are clearly defined with signposted marker buoys. If you can make your way to Raja Ampat you'll be able to see the results for yourself. 

WE'VE PROVEN THE PROGRAM IS EFFECTIVE  and as funds become available we will expand it rapidly to create another 50-60​ Locally Protected Areas scattered around Raja Ampat. To achieve this goal our crowdfunding target is US$150,000

If we don't reach our entire goal the funds we do receive will still be used to create as many protected areas as we can with the available resources. 

WHERE THE MONEY GOES.. 

$1050 pays for a small LPA at a homestay with 3 marker buoys 

$1750 pays for a medium-sized LPA at a homestay with 5 marker buoys

$3,500 pays for one of our largest LPA's with 10 marker buoys ​

The locally-made fiberglass buoys cost $150each installed (go to our website www.greenworldbali.com for technical information). We hire local boats to place the buoys in deep water following the line of the reef.

Funds are required for transport & operations, hiring local boats & crews, community presentations, meetings & community/church contributions. We provide drinks and snacks at meetings and presentations and sometimes we give small contributions to the local Church. 

PERKS

This is an independent conservation program so we can't offer you products or flashy rewards but we do want to genuinely thank you and offer you something meaningful in return for your support.

If you're a small donor please remind yourself that you're contributing, in a very real way, to preserving our precious, and rapidly vanishing, coral reefs. Your small contribution makes a difference.  

If you're a larger donor, by all means promote your contribution, or include it in your CSR projects knowing that you're doing something practical, tangible and effective.  

$25  Junior Certificate of Support (for printing & framing)

$75  Certificate of Support (for printing & framing)

$75-$300  Certificate + beautiful hi res LPA Photos (for printing & framing) 

$350  Certificate + LPA Photos + your name on a marker buoy 

$1,050 pays for a small homestay project, 3buoys. Your name only on that project 

$1,750 pays for an average homestay project, 5buoys. Your name only on that project 

$2,800 pays for a big homestay project, 8buoys. Your name only on that project

$3,500 pays for one of our largest projects, 10buoys. Your name only on that project

WHY SHOULD YOU SUPPORT THIS CAMPAIGN? 

Raja Ampat is the prize gem of the 'Coral Triangle', it's a super-diverse tropical marine environment still surviving in relatively good shape. It has been protected from industrial-scale fishing but it is still suffers daily damage from unsustainable fishing & anchor damage, plus excessive numbers of divers, the Crown of Thorns Starfish and water pollution. Raja Ampat is now experiencing a development boom but, if we act quickly, we still have time. 

Conservation International has spent millions of dollars creating Marine Protected Areas (MPA's) in Raja Ampat but the reality is coral reefs continue to be damaged and over-exploited on a daily basis. Large scale fishing has been stopped but down at the local level where the daily damage is occurring unsustainable fishing continues completely unregulated so no-fishing zones are critical to rebuilding reef-fish stocks. 

Raja Ampat is a group of islands with virtually no roads so everybody, and everything, travels by boat. Liveaboard dive boats have a code of conduct for anchoring in deep water away from reefs but the many day-trip tour boats, private yachts, local cargo and passenger boats and local fishermen have no such code. Uncontrolled anchoring is destroying corals in Raja Ampat every day so no-anchor zones are critical to their preservation. 

Raja Ampat is now considered the best diving location in the World, partly at least, because most other places have been trashed. The dive industry and Conservation International enthusiastically promote Raja Ampat's gorgeous coral reefs, amazing biodiversity and stunning scenic beauty but make no mistake... Raja Ampat’s remaining coral reefs are not safe! 

Our priority is the daily threats that are emptying reefs of fish and destroying their glorious coral structure. Unrestricted fishing and the terrible damage done by anchors are two urgent threats that are stopped when locals declare a new LPA (Locally Protected Area). 

There are a number of threats to coral reefs so there’s no simple ‘magic bullet’ solution for their long-term survival. We've usually waited too long, by the time we've begun to act, the damage has already been done. If we really want to save coral reefs, first, we have to SAVE WHAT'S LEFT from further exploitation and damage. Once an area has effective protection local people can start working on the other problems.

OUR RESULTS SO FAR

During 2017 we facilitated the creation of 15 locally protected areas where the two major threats, fishing and anchors, are now banned. The LPA's are mostly ‘house reefs’ at locally-owned homestays (small guesthouses) but we’ve also protected a 1.6km (1mile) long tidal inlet which is an important reef shark nursery. 

In January 2018 the first dive resort joined the program, protecting its own house reef and providing the marker buoys for three adjacent homestays. Also in January, we installed marker buoys at our first community reef project protecting 1km of coral reef and adjacent mangroves.

There are now 17 Locally Protected Areas (LPA's) scattered around Raja Ampat and with your support we will continue the work protecting beautiful coral reefs before it's too late. 

THE RAJA AMPAT HOMESTAY ASSOCIATION

The Homestay Association network is critical to the people and natural environment of Raja Ampat. The Association has the greatest potential to bring urgently needed economic development to the islands and it is the only realistic way we can see to facilitate widespread environmental protection (by local people).

The Homestay Association recently won a significant UN Award but it remains a ‘work in progress’ that needs your business, so if you’re thinking of visiting Raja Ampat and you want to get a real feel for this extraordinary place, please consider the homestays. The locations are stunning, the accommodations are simple, the food is great. The Association has many lovely homestays shown on its excellent website: www.stayrajaampat.com 

ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF LOCALLY PROTECTED AREAS (LPA's)  

I use a practical approach to the way I pitch the program to local people and communities. It is obvious that a protected ‘house reef’ is good for a homestay ecotourism business (or resort) so that’s an easy sell, although local fishermen do require some convincing. 

The government doesn't regulate small-scale local fishermen so fisheries are suffering from ‘The Trajedy of the Commons’, whereby a lack of regulation means anybody can take anything, so reef fish catches have dramatically declined. It means a fisherman will take undersize fish or lobsters or anything else because.. ‘if I don’t take it, somebody else will’. 

We explain to fishermen that LPA's become much-needed nurseries for reef fish, improving their livelihood over time. Once a Locally Protected Area is declared local people are empowered, with backing from Government, to refuse entry to fishermen from other areas.

THE FUTURE

Empowering local people to take charge of their environment, giving them the right to refuse access to outsiders and to stop unsustainable exploitation by their own people, provides the necessary foundation for a sustainable future.

Once a Locally Protected Area is declared it becomes the responsibility of the homestay owners and the community. They are responsible for maintenance of the buoys and enforcement of the rules. The future belongs to local people.

REPORTING, KEEPING YOU POSTED... 

We will report regularly on Indiegogo and... 

Facebook: Norm Van't Hoff  

Instagram: protectrajaampat

Our website: www.greenworldbali.com 

We will post news on new LPA's as they’re created. We’ll post videos and photos as well as up to date information on our progress. 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The greatest risk we face now is the small size of the program but as it grows we expect it to become stronger. If we do all the planned locations this year we will spend 2019 following-up and supporting the Homestay Association to take ownership of the LPA Program. 

There are always challenges... Will the buoys be well-maintained? What happens if a boat hits a buoy? How long will the chains last? What happens if a buoy disappears? Will everybody abide by the rules? How do we get majority compliance? Can we monitor ecosystem changes after declaring the protected areas? Can the LPA Program be extended to address other threats coral reefs?

Solving these, and other, ongoing challenges is all about commitment and that's the whole point... The only people who are continually incentivized to deal with ongoing, day-to-day challenges, are the people who live on-site. Real protection & effective conservation has to be done by local people, applying local rules, to protect their local, natural resources. 

There are always a bunch of reasons why we can't act, but inaction, or inadequate action, has already cost us most of the World's coral reefs. We keep talking.. having endless meetings, seminars and doing research but on a global scale, science has not saved the reefs and the experts are often just chronicling the demise of our coral reefs. Governments and big NGO's talk a lot about empowering local people but in reality, it almost never happens. 

Working with local people we are taking action, right action, practical & effective action, right down here at the local level. We're protecting as many reefs as we can, as cheaply as we can, and as fast as we can. 

Based on experience around the World so far... It won't be governments or giant NGO's that save what's left of our coral reefs. If coral reefs are to be saved, it will be by local people who've been empowered to manage and protect their local reefs, for now, and for future generations. 

'BUSINESS AS USUAL' IS THE GREATEST DANGER TO CORAL REEFS  The sad reality is that all around the World coral reefs are dead and dying. Clearly, whatever we've done so far to save them, mostly, it hasn't worked. 

WE HAVE TO DO SOMETHING DIFFERENT, AND WE HAVE TO DO IT NOW! We are doing what few others will do, we are helping local people to take charge, and we're doing it fast! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute you can still help us by spreading the word and promoting this campaign to your friends and connections. 

THANK YOU

I want to personally thank you for taking an interest in what we're doing in Raja Ampat, and if you can donate, for your generous contribution to this very worthwhile program. 

Thank you,

Norm  

Raja Ampat, West Papua 

February 2018

The locations are stunning, the accommodations are simple, the food is great. The Association has many lovely homestays shown on its excellent website: www.stayrajaampat.com 
ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF LOCALLY PROTECTED AREAS (LPA's)  
I use a practical approach to the way I pitch the program to local people and communities. It is obvious that a protected ‘house reef’ is good for a homestay ecotourism business (or resort) so that’s an easy sell, although local fishermen do require some convincing. 
The government doesn't regulate small-scale local fishermen so fisheries are suffering from ‘The Trajedy of the Commons’, whereby a lack of regulation means anybody can take anything, so reef fish catches have dramatically declined. It means a fisherman will take undersize fish or lobsters or anything else because.. ‘if I don’t take it, somebody else will’. 
We explain to fishermen that LPA's become much-needed nurseries for reef fish, improving their livelihood over time. Once a Locally Protected Area is declared local people are empowered, with backing from Government, to refuse entry to fishermen from other areas.
THE FUTURE

Empowering local people to take charge of their environment, giving them the right to refuse access to outsiders and to stop unsustainable exploitation by their own people, provides the necessary foundation for a sustainable future.
Once a Locally Protected Area is declared it becomes the responsibility of the homestay owners and the community. They are responsible for maintenance of the buoys and enforcement of the rules. The future belongs to local people.
REPORTING, KEEPING YOU POSTED... 
We will report regularly on Indiegogo and... 
Facebook: Norm Van't Hoff  
Instagram: protectrajaampat
Our website: www.greenworldbali.com 
We will post news on new LPA's as they’re created. We’ll post videos and photos as well as up to date information on our progress. 
RISKS AND CHALLENGES
The greatest risk we face now is the small size of the program but as it grows we expect it to become stronger. If we do all the planned locations this year we will spend 2019 following-up and supporting the Homestay Association to take ownership of the LPA Program. 
There are always challenges... Will the buoys be well-maintained? What happens if a boat hits a buoy? How long will the chains last? What happens if a buoy disappears? Will everybody abide by the rules? How do we get majority compliance? Can we monitor ecosystem changes after declaring the protected areas? Can the LPA Program be extended to address other threats coral reefs?
Solving these, and other, ongoing challenges is all about commitment and that's the whole point... The only people who are continually incentivized to deal with ongoing, day-to-day challenges, are the people who live on-site. Real protection & effective conservation has to be done by local people, applying local rules, to protect their local, natural resources. 
There are always a bunch of reasons why we can't act, but inaction, or inadequate action, has already cost us most of the World's coral reefs. We keep talking.. having endless meetings, seminars and doing research but on a global scale, science has not saved the reefs and the experts are often just chronicling the demise of our coral reefs. Governments and big NGO's talk a lot about empowering local people but in reality, it almost never happens. 
Working with local people we are taking action, right action, practical & effective action, right down here at the local level. We're protecting as many reefs as we can, as cheaply as we can, and as fast as we can. 
Based on experience around the World so far... It won't be governments or giant NGO's that save what's left of our coral reefs. If coral reefs are to be saved, it will be by local people who've been empowered to manage and protect their local reefs, for now, and for future generations. 
'BUSINESS AS USUAL' IS THE GREATEST DANGER TO CORAL REEFS  The sad reality is that all around the World coral reefs are dead and dying. Clearly, whatever we've done so far to save them, mostly, it hasn't worked. 
WE HAVE TO DO SOMETHING DIFFERENT, AND WE HAVE TO DO IT NOW! We are doing what few others will do, we are helping local people to take charge, and we're doing it fast! 
Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute you can still help us by spreading the word and promoting this campaign to your friends and connections. 
THANK YOU
I want to personally thank you for taking an interest in what we're doing in Raja Ampat, and if you can donate, for your generous contribution to this very worthwhile program. Thank you,Norm  Raja Ampat, West Papua February 2018
campaign_city: Raja Ampat Islands, West Papua, Indonesia

story:
Who We Are

We are a group of students at the University of Tennessee looking to give back to our community by contributing time and money to the Sevier County Humane Society, to help lost and surrendered animals get the homes they deserve. We chose to help this non-profit because we all have a deep love for animals, have prior experience with Humane Societies by adopting animals of our own, and have felt a connection to help those affected by the tragic Gatlinburg wildfires.

The Sevier County Humane Society is a 501(c)3 non-profit and was founded in 1974 with the mission of helping abandoned, homeless, and surrendered animals, and is a no-kill shelter. After the wildfires, they treated and rehabilitated all of the hurt and burned animals that they received, and, out of 400 animals, the University of Tennessee Veterinaries only had to euthanize two cats who were beyond hope.

The Sevier County Humane Society operates primarily on donations and community support. All contributions are used to create a safe, healthy, and comfortable environment for their animals, especially after the tragic wildfires took away the shelter that many abandoned animals temporarily call home.

What We Need

Since the Gatlinburg wildfires, the Sevier County Humane Society has been temporarily located at the Sevier County Fairgrounds with limited resources and volunteers because the previous location had smoke damage and deemed unsafe to house the animals at the moment. Just recently, the Sevier County Humane Society was given short notice to leave the fair grounds and were forced to move back into their old shelter.

After the wildfires, the Sevier County Humane Society took in over 400 animals when people were unable to reach their homes because the City of Gatlinburg was evacuated and shut down. After the city was reopened, 97% of these animals were reclaimed.

The Sevier County Humane Society has done everything they can to keep their shelter running even though they have faced many obstacles. Having to relocate from the location they've had for years to a temporary location, being forced to leave a temporary location and move back to an unsafe shelter, and now they will have to build a temporary shelter and a brand new permanent shelter. This is where we need your help!

The new building is going to cost over a million dollars, but we want to get this project started! With your help, we are going to fund the building of one wall for a new shelter so that we can help these poor animals get the proper housing and supplies they need as quickly as possible. Every dollar that you donate will go to the well being animals during this stressful process of constantly changing envoirnments.

How It Helps

By making this tax-deductible donation, you are helping the Sevier County community take one step closer to being whole again. Months after the Gatlinburg wildfires, the Sevier County community is still picking up the pieces left behind by this tragedy.

By donating, you are not only helping the animals affected, but also the people of this city who are trying to rebuild and return to their lives.Your donation will go directly to help the animals currently at the SCHS become one step closer to a loving home, and it will also help the future generations of lost animals become adopted at a faster rate and decrease the number of strays and unwanted population.

With more funds, the Sevier County Humane Society will be able to help treat sick animals, spay and neuter stray and surrendered animals, and build a brand new shelter that will allow them to take in more animals than ever before!

Risks & Challenges

Since the wildfires took away everything from the Sevier County Humane Society, our goal is to help them get back on their feet as soon as we can. One of our main challenges is that the Sevier County Humane Society needs over a million dollars for their new shelter and has to build a temporary shelter before their permanent one, so every dollar that you donate to this wonderful campaign will help us get these animals out of their temporary location and into a brand new shelter!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate financially at this time, we ask you to please share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and any other social media platform to spread awareness. We also ask that you spread the word about our campaign by telling your friends and by using #projectbuildashelter.

If you have any questions about the Sevier County Humane Society, please call or message the Shelter Manager, Michaela Sorey, at (865) 307-5426. Also, if you have a question about Project Build a Shelter, please email our Lead Project Manager, Chloe Padilla, at clpadilla1973@gmail.com or call and message at (865) 705-6456. We would like to thank you in advance for your contribution to this wonderful cause!

story:
Divest the Vatican

Climate change is threatening to destroy our Pacific Islands, so we're travelling to the Vatican and calling on our religious leaders to divest from fossil fuels. Our faith is central to our culture and way of life, so now we're calling on our faith leaders in the Vatican to divest from fossil fuels. We're sending our Climate Warriors to deliver this urgent message to the Vatican in person. And we need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to step up the Divest the Vatican campaign and send the Warriors to the Pope's doorstep. We'll be travelling throughout the Pacific to listen and collect stories of how climate change is destroying the Pacific way of life, and we'll be weaving these stories into traditional mats. We will then carry these mats and stories with us to the Vatican to show what is at risk if our leaders there don't divest from fossil fuels.

We need $25,000 to cover all the costs of gathering stories from across the Pacific, and for flights and accommodation for the Warriors. The more we raise, the more stories we can share, and the more powerful our voice will be.

Contributing for the Pacific is a powerful gesture but we think you deserve more than just a thank you and that's why we've worked with our communities to produce a range of perks. 


The Pope's encyclical on the climate is evidence that the Vatican understands the need for action, now the Warriors have an opportunity to motivate the Vatican to stand by the Pope's powerful words, and divest from fossil fuels.


The Full Story

In 2014, the Pacific Climate Warriors blockaded the largest coal port in the world to send a direct message to the fossil fuel industry. This year, we will send a message to those investing in the climate crisis.

In October 2015, as the pope returns from his tour of the United States, a group of 12- 15 Pacific Climate Warriors will arrive in the Vatican, where they will undertake a peaceful demonstration, asking the Pope to divest the Vatican from fossil fuels. Using traditional women mats, the Pacific Climate warriors will demonstrate the grief and loss being experienced in the Pacific Islands at the hands of the Fossil Fuel industry, in a traditional and symbolic “Act of Contrition’ or “Fa’anoanoa’.

They will persevere until they feel their message has been communicated- building on the growing “Divest the Vatican” campaign. This tour will also be an opportunity for Pacific Islanders to tell their stories as moral witnesses to the impacts of climate change in their island homes.

Historically, the stories of Pacific Islanders have been told by outsiders, and very rarely by young Pacific Islanders. Through in- depth story telling training, we will support our organizers on the ground to document and share their stories, as told to and reported by, young Pacific Islanders. We will then release the stories through global media outlets and 350.org channels.

The Mat Weaving Project builds on the theme of demonstrating the action required to change the narrative for the Pacific Islands in the face of climate change: “We are not drowning, we are fighting”.

Who are the Pacific Climate Warriors?

Five years ago, a network of young Pacific Islanders began to form under the name of 350 Pacific, to join with the global climate change movement, 350.org.

Active in 15 of the Pacific Island Nations across the region, this network has grown through practicing a unique approach to organizing and mobilizing- placing faith and culture at the center of it all. Through building a solid foundation, 350 Pacific was then able to empower young people to understand the issues of climate change and their role in the solutions needed to protect and enrich their islands, cultures, and traditions.


Other Ways You Can Help

Many of you have supported the Climate Warriors in the past and have likely divested your personal assets already. We are eternally grateful and humbled by the support that we have received from across the globe. If you're keen to help out further then sometimes the best thing you can do is share this with your friends, email your networks and explain why this matters to you. We are a global community and without you, the Pacific Islands are in real trouble.

  • Email your friends and family about the campaign and encourage them to take part. 
  • Using the social media share buttons below increase the visibility of the campaign and can make all the difference.
  • Sign the Divest the Vatican petition.

story:
THE CHALLENGE

Millions of people lack basic access to clean water. Together, we can change that.


Imagine heat and sweat under the blazing sun of mid-Summer.

Imagine being the thirstiest you've ever been.

Now, imagine drinking a glass of dirty water from a drainage ditch.


That's the everyday reality for many people living in the remote parts of Nicaragua.

There is no substance more vital to life on this planet than water. Despite our vast advances in science and technology, it remains one of the few things for which there can be absolutely no compromise and no substitute. 

In Nicaragua alone, nearly 1.5 Million people have no access to clean water. 

Nicaraguans in remote villages are forced to drink from contaminated wells and polluted streams. 

Their only water sources are filled with deadly amoebas and bacteria.


THE PLAN

With your contributions, we propose the following:

1. Establishment of water packaging and distribution hubs in affected regions to get free, clean water to people as quickly as possible.

2. Hiring members of the local community to package and distribute clean drinking water to areas with the greatest immediate need.

3. Funding for the surveying and planning of sustainable, sanitary well-water systems in affected communities.

4. Use funding in excess of our goal for additional immediate and sustainable water solutions, and provide direct support for other local NGOs.


The project is simple.  

We deliver water to affected communities NOW.

We help build sustainable water infrastructure for the long term.


THE TEAM

We are team of local volunteers and international advocates who want to give thirsty people clean water.  We've partnered with the social advocates at Eck Miller Global Ltd. in Europe and Spellman Consulting in the USA to help spread the word about our campaign.

The small business owners on our team source fair-trade, Nicaraguan goods for export to the international market.  While promoting fair trade is good, we soon realized the need for trade is a distant second to the need for clean drinking water.

For example, the coffee plantations we deal with pay their workers a fair living wage. But, when the workers go home, they can't put that money into a glass and drink it. They have to draw their water from wells, streams and ditches... which are often contaminated with deadly parasites and bacteria.

After witnessing the living conditions of suffering people in remote regions, we decided to act.


With your help, we're going to help build sanitary water infrastructure in rural communities.  

At the same time, we'll be sending to our donors (YOU) fair-trade goods from Nicaragua.


THE PERKS

In return for your contribution, you will receive unique, artisanal items from Nicaragua.

From the hands of local artists, farmers and craftsmen, our donors will enjoy these beautifully made gifts as well as receive updates on project progress.


Our challenge to you:

Tell your friends, family, and colleagues about our campaign.  For every twenty-five $10 contributions you refer to our campaign, we'll send you a deluxe, double-woven hammock.

It's easy.  For your referrals to count, make a donation using your Indiegogo account.  After you contribute, you'll be given a link to the campaign to share with your contacts.  If they use the link to donate to the campaign, you get credit for a referral.

story:
Who we are and what we do:

We are a local NGO with the objective of reforesting 1 million hectares within Paraguay.Established in 2009, our organization includes 17 staff members, 214 active volunteers across 11 out of 17states.

We focus our work in educating children, training youth in the field and working alongside commodities producers to mitigate the effects of climate change by reforesting. We reach over 2.500 people per year through our education program and currently work with 400 commodities producers. Our work is done in partnership with volunteers, mostly from the United States, who live in rural and urban communities across the country.

  • We are one of the most well-known local environmental NGOs in Paraguay, socially and politically
  • We planted over 120,000 trees in 4 years with our network of volunteers  (over 57,000 trees planted in 2014 alone!).

  Our efforts are focused in the Atlantic Forest of Eastern Paraguay. Together with parts of Argentina and Brazil, these forests make up the Atlantic Forest eco-region. The Atlantic Forest has been named a Noah’s Arc in terms of biodiversity for the world. Unfortunately, less than 8% of forests are left in fragmented sections within the Paraguay Atlantic Forest. Paraguay has the second highest deforestation rate in the world, second only to Malaysia.


How you can help and what we need to succeed:

  Your generous donations are the life blood of these projects and we need your help to help us keep planting trees with local communities in order to help reverse the disastrous effects of deforestation. You have an opportunity to help fund impactful grass roots projects essential to adapting to climate change and reduce deforestation and its devastating consequences for Paraguay.

  • By hitting our goal of $12,000, we can plant an astonishing 40,000 trees in Paraguay!
  • 100% of your contributions go towards:
                   1. Purchasing of trees
                   2. Training materials 
                   3. Registration of the trees planted in our GPS map

  Our perks are meant to show our gratitude for your donations and the gratitude of the communities you help to plant trees and support their livelihoods. These perks include:

      Personalized thank you on Facebook, trees planted in your name and marked on       our GPS maps for you and all to see, personalized thank you videos and pictures       of plantations, thank you cards and even traditional handmade Paraguayan lace         work (ñanduti).

Even if we do not reach our goal of $12,000, whatever we do receive will still go 100% towards our reforestation projects.

The Gist

These projects are vital to our reforestation efforts and helping communities reverse the effects of deforestation, making trees valuable and irreplaceable resources. These projects add value to the environment and shift communities towards sustainable agriculture and sustainable living practices. Your donation will go 100% towards our tree planting projects.  Please donate and help us continue working at the grass roots level to adapt to, and combat the negative effects of climate change.

These projects add value to the environment and shift communities towards sustainable agriculture and sustainable living practices. Your donation will go 100% towards our tree planting projects.  Please donate and help us continue working at the grass roots level to adapt to, and combat the negative effects of climate change.

story:
THE GOAL:

The simple fact is that more than 2000 trees in the Villages of Brookfield and La Grange Park, Illinois have been destroyed due to the Emerald Ash Borer (EAB) beetle and the Brookfield-La Grange Park Lions Club needs your help to raise funds to replace them.  

It costs $450 to replace each tree and we want to make a significant start by supplying enough funds to help replace at least 100 trees!

  VISIT www.blplions.org to learn more about how Lions help...

HISTORY and DETAILS:

To raise awareness and gain support for the fundraising efforts to replace trees removed due to the Emerald Ash Borer (EAB) beetle, in the villages of Brookfield and La Grange Park, the local Lions Club is spearheading a community service fundraising project that coincides with the upcoming Lions Clubs International Centennial Celebration, designed to revitalize and restore our urban forest.

According to the Illinois Department of Agriculture, the Emerald Ash Borer (EAB), an Asian beetle first discovered in North America in the 1990’s is now aggressively affecting our tree stock.  These insects are green and little bigger than the size of a penny.  While the adults eat the leaves of Ash Trees causing minor damage, their larvae cause the real damage as they feed on the inner bark called the cambium layer.  This crucial layer that carries water and nutrients is permanently disrupted by the larval feeding.  61 of Illinois’ 102 counties have been affected by this menace.

THE SITUATION IN BROOKFIELD:

230 of the Ash Trees have already been removed with another 50-150 scheduled to be removed this year and more than 400-500 subject to future removal for a total of approximately 900 Ash Trees that will be removed.

THE SITUATION IN LA GRANGE PARK:

494 of the 1399 Ash Trees in the Village have been removed since January 2012 with 822 more trees subject to future removal – leaving only 83 Ash Trees that were treated in time – less than 6% of the original Ash Tree population.

The goal in both villages is to replenish our tree stock with a diverse and hardy population consisting of species such as: English Oak, American Horn Beam, Chanticleer Pear, Green Mountain Sugar Maple, Red Oak, Redmond American Linden, and Red Jewel Crab to the tune of $450 per tree.

WHAT THE EXPERTS HAVE TO SAY:

While residents and the BLP Lions Club obviously believe it is important to promote and aid in the reforestation efforts of our community, a myriad of references, professional associations, and governmental entities can elaborate on the varied value of trees, in general, and urban forests, specifically.  Trees impact everything from an individual’s perspective walking through a neighborhood to design elements creating shading for one’s home to ecological functionaries as atmospheric gas exchangers.

The Society of Municipal Arborists

(www.urban-foresrtry.com/assets/documents/bmp/ufbmpwhyhowv.2pdf ) state that trees:

·  Have a traffic calming influence, increase public safety, and enhance pedestrian and cycling activities

·  Benefit property values and tax bases by increasing real estate prices – resulting in higher tax bases (prospective buyers consistently rate treed communities higher) and retail shoppers tend to spend more dollars in treed and landscaped districts

·  Drainage and Flooding are eased by absorbing storm water in green spaces versus hardscape areas, resulting in fewer or smaller floods

·  Air Quality is increased because trees also absorb pollutants and carbon, reducing the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere – which costs far less than other solutions AND tree shade can also reduce ozone production and generation of CO2 through energy conservation

·  Health and Quality of Life are increased as trees and green space are found to foster more active lifestyles and reduce crime in neighborhoods 

·  Energy Savings are found as shade reduces cooling costs, trees protect from winter winds – thereby reducing heating costs, and protect against the “Urban Island Effect” by lowering temperatures across entire cities.

Moreover, the US Department of Agriculture (www.fs.fed.us/ucf/) confirms that “trees cool cities, save energy, improve air quality, strengthen quality of place and local economies, reduce storm runoff, improve social connections, complement smart growth, and create walkable communities.”  

Plainly, as stated by www.americanforests.org , “trees and urban forests are critical to the health and quality of life in our cities.” 

WHAT YOU CAN DO:

We are asking for your aid in improving the quality of life in our community, any amount you give will help to replace the trees.  Thank you.

Please note: Brookfield-LaGrange Park Lions Club is an IRS 501(C)4 not-for-profit organization.  Donations do not qualify as a charitable deduction.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Marc Yamaguchi, and I'm with the Homegrown National Park Rangers. We are bringing nature home to yards, alleys, balconies, schools, parks and unexpected spaces in different wards of Toronto, Canada. My project involves putting rain gardens in 10 front yards (including my own as the demonstration) so that we beautify our local streets and build in resilience to better cope with the effects of climate change. 

What We Need & What You Get

We will split our goal of raising $5000 in 10 ways in order to assist our "first movers" for taking the lead in transitioning to a more sustainable society. We will opt for "flexible funding" and ensure that if we fall short of our target, the resulting amount will still be equally divided among the participants.  

In order to set up a single 4' x 6' rain garden, we would typically need to spend:

landscape materials (bio-retention soil, plants, rocks): $300

disposal fee: $50

concept design: $150

labour (digging, unloading, planting): $550

HST: $125

Total: $1200 (approximately)

Consider this an invitation to interact with us on Saturday, June 6/15 from 9am to 12pm at 705 Sammon Avenue (my place) as the Park Rangers and a master gardener are on hand to answer questions and plant the first rain garden of the pilot. Light refreshments will be served.  Family friendly, and listed as one of the 100In1Day events under the Evergreen/ United Way banner.

Moreover, all crowdfunders will be given access to the website in which an edited version of the the day's event will be posted.  This video can serve as a DIY complement to the Toronto Region Conservation Authority (TRCA) materials provided earlier at the community workshop on residential landscaping.  TRCA materials will also be available to take home on June 6/15.


The Impact

Not only are we bringing back the birds, bees and butterflies, but the people get outside and gather in these ecosystems, also.  The pollinator-friendly plants will nurture and breathe biodiversity back into our neighbourhoods, especially helpful to those insect populations who've experienced dangerously rapid declines in their populations.

You are literally helping build for a better future with thriving communities across Toronto because we're moving beyond raising awareness to effect meaningful, transformative social change by connecting citizens to the environment.

Now, our endgame is to have this kind of project replicated across other wards so that this recognized Toronto Green Standard, Tier 2 climate change strategy becomes part of a city-wide roll out. The insurance companies no longer protect residents from flooding after the massive pay outs in 2013 and 2014 in Toronto and Calgary respectively.  

So, we have to look for solutions that deal with issues of overland flooding. We are also thinking proactively in light of a looming municipal mandatory stormwater charge.  Due to the permeable nature of the materials and water infiltration rates, residents who install rain gardens should be considered for a SWC discount. 

Beautiful and practical, by supporting "Rain Gardens of Danforth East Village - East York" you place urban development in the hands of ordinary citizens who want a say in how their environment should reflect the citizens' needs.


Risks & Challenges

Rain gardens function in conjunction with the downspout disconnect.  Properties must also have front lots that have grading down and away from their foundations. A landscaper would first need to assess the suitability of the grounds before proceeding to a concept design.  The price of the installation could be affected by complications arising to the waterflow across a property. In the instance in which home owners would take it upon themselves to build their own rain gardens, none should do so without calling in a locate.

Beyond the June 6/15 rain garden installation demonstration, the other 9 properties selected to participate would have their rain gardens installed over the summer up until the end of August, 2015.  Actual times would vary subject to the schedule of the landscaper and residents who would coordinate this among themselves. Plant materials would be subject to seasonal availability. Once residents provide proof of payment (paid invoice stamped), residents would be reimbursed for their 10% share of the crowd fund total.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Seed believes in making the world a better place.

We believe that its not too late to turn around our health crisis, and that there is a better way of living.

We are thought evokers, change makers, and catalysts of an empowered movement. We’ve created a platform where ideas, information, inspiration, and encouragement take place.

Founded through heart, hustle, and passion, The Seed is positively changing lives by showcasing how amazing a plant based lifestyle can be. 

Who we are

The Seed is a lifestyle company based in NYC, and our very specific mission is to promote a positive plant based lifestyle to vegans, vegetarians, and veg-curious individuals. We showcase brands and thought leaders that offer vegan products and services within the following industries: Health & Wellness, Food & Diet; Athletics; Family & Lifestyle; Beauty & Fashion; and Animal Compassion & Environment. 

For the second year in a row, The Seed presents our Positively Plant-Based event, an amazing experience in the heart of NYC's SoHo neighborhood.

Our past events

What We Need & What You Get

We are 100% dedicated to the plant based movement and hope to provide positive content with our speakers, presentations and films, but we need funding to make it happen. Your support will help us with the following: 

  • Adding more speakers and presenters (Travel expenses and accomodations)
  • Equipment Rentals (stage, sound system, tables & chairs, etc.)
  • Free livestream of keynote and presentations.

Last year's speakers

 

Volunteers - we are looking for a great team of enthusiastic volunteers to help with set-up and event-day logistics. Please contact pas@theseedexperience.com

Speakers & Presenters Testimonials

Brendan Brazier, Professional Athlete, thriveforward.com
"The Seed was undoubtedly one of the best events I've ever spoken at.”

Mariann Sullivan and Jasmin Singer, Founders of Our Hen House
“The Seed is the future of vegan, foodie, and social justice events.”

Rich Roll, Professional Athlete, richroll.com
“Everything about The Seed Experience was top notch!”

Attendee Testimonials

“Huge Thanks to The Seed for a hugely successful, wonderfully uplifting, simulating educational, fantastically fun, and extremely tasty event with tons of delicious, vegan gourmet food!!!  The speakers were some of the best in the world.  The films were outstanding and very moving.  Everything about the event was beautiful and first class.  Congratulations and thank you, thank you, thank you for this huge service to the NYC vegan community!” 
- David Greene from meetup.com

“I was thrilled to talk to Kathy Freston - and credit her with enabling my change from Vegetarian to Vegan 5 years ago. Also got a Chi reading from Dr. Sauberli for $10 which was a great bargain.”  
– Jill from meetup.com

story:
Our Environment is Changing

Years of resource mismanagement and growing levels of consumerism are taking their toll. 80% of what we produce is used once and then discarded. Turning things around will take nothing short of a complete shift in the supply chain from raw materials to disposal.

Lack of Information

The 2014 Greendex “consumer choice and environment” report states that, although environmental awareness and concern has increased among consumers, there has not been substantial change in consumer behaviour. The reason given: a need for better access to environmentally friendly choices and information.

About the GreenPages Directory

Green Pages Directory is a powerful and robust search tool that supports finding socially conscious, green solutions for our purchasing needs. The directory can:

  • Filter information about companies and their products and services based on listing type, sustainability, distance from market and environmental certification.
  • Allow businesses to use the site to find new ways to reduce consumption and improve their supply chain.
  • Allow organizations to communicate their environmental philosophies and standards directly to their customers through their profile page and the community forum. 
  • Allow end users to search or browse the certifications section of the site for information about accreditation organizations, their certifications and business listings that have achieved these standards. 

Green Pages Directory has been in development for three years, headed by a small team of entrepreneurs with proven expertise in business, sustainability and online media. 

We are North America's fastest growing online search directory for sustainable purchasing and healthier living – our site is already home to tens of thousands of listings around the world.

Our Values

  • Our Standards – We are committed to upholding a high level of service to ensure our platform makes a positive contribution to the marketplace, and to engage in continuous improvement.
  • We Believe in the Power of Good – We recognize the importance of positive incremental changes in our everyday lives, which, when combined, leads to substantial transformations on a global scale.
  • We Encourage Free Will With Transparency and Accountability – Our platform allows users to rank companies, products and services, and also allows businesses to respond, maintaining control over their information by being part of the conversation.
  • We Support Equal Access – Regardless of size, businesses have equal access to all our features and users. From the individual entrepreneur to the largest multinational, GreenPages Directory offers a power of depth and scale to bring about important changes to the sustainable marketplace.
  • Giving Back – Being on the leading edge takes commitment and dedication. In support of our community of conscientious innovators and entrepreneurs, we donate 10% of our advertising space to help these emerging companies introduce themselves to the marketplace.

Our Vision – Take the Next Step With Us

We can change the world, a step at a time. Take the next step with us. We’re asking for your help to provide the financing we need to continue to market and grow our listing and member base.

Our near term plans include launching the “eco-flyer” program, and the Green Pages Directory mobile app. 

The long-term plan is to build Green Pages Directory into a global database, making it the biggest and most widely used tool for environmental change in the world.

FAQ

What will my funds go towards?

The $100,000 contribution level will go towards continuing to market and grow our listing and member base, build our mobile app and launch our eco flyer program. Currently, we have 12,000 listing globally but we know that, with your support, we can grow our directory and community even more significantly in 2015 and 2016.

More importantly, your funds will help businesses and consumers around the world easily find information on the certified solutions, products and services that they need to live and operate more sustainably.

Our larger vision is to expand the GreenPages Directory into the largest database globally, helping to grow a healthy, clean and green economy worldwide. Each contribution is substantial to help us grow our database,  magnifying the positive effects our innovative platform has already had on citizens, organizations and our planet.

What has the GreenPages Directory achieved so far?

For the first time ever, our streamlined, sustainability-focused platform has made complex and in-depth information about sustainable products, services and practices easy to understand and use. We are also offering an open space for businesses of all sizes – from entrepreneurs to multinational corporations – to share best practices on creating a more sustainable economy in our community.  End-users can learn about the important issues facing industry, comment on listings and benefit from searching and browsing our database.

To date, we have built a directory with over 12,000 listings spanning all business sectors making our platform relevant for the entire economy. We have also built a network of key non-profit and NGO supporters in our community such as Nature Canada, the Pembina Institute, the Sierra Club and the Worldwatch Institute – all who share their industry knowledge to support more informed and progressive choices.

The comprehensiveness and depth of our listings is unparalleled in the world.  Most importantly, our directory is contributing towards helping businesses and consumers green our global supply chains and protect our oceans, ecosystems, drinking water and natural resources.

Can I donate from outside Canada?

Yes! Indiegogo only accepts international credit cards, not bank or debit cards. Unfortunately we can’t accept PayPal, so the way to donate internationally is with a credit card.

What payment methods do you accept?

Indiegogo accepts all major credit cards.

Can I make a contribution over $10,000?

Yes, as Indiegogo does not accept payments over $10,000, please contact info@greenpagesdirectory. We will assist you personally with the contribution transfer process.

What are some other ways that I can help?

Please share our Indiegogo campaign URL through your Facebook and Twitter accounts. If you or someone you know has an organization committed to sustainability, encourage them to create a listing in our global database.

What type of rewards will I receive by contributing to the GreenPages Directory campaign?

Please see below for the types of rewards we are offering to our contributors!



Please Note: Distribution of rewards are subject to availability and fulfillment of the $100,000 funding level.

Is shipping included?

Yes. 

Does international shipping cost extra?

Yes, but Indiegogo doesn't allow us to add any extra shipping to the perks, so it is included in the suggested donation price.

I have more questions. Who do I ask?

Please email info@greenpagesdirectory.net and we will be happy to get back to you as soon as we can.

OUR TEAM

Connie Linder, MBA

Founder & President

Connie is an entrepreneur and business strategist with a special interest in sustainability and innovative startups. She founded GreenPages Directory to make tangible her commitment to increase public awareness of available innovative solutions and make sustainable products and services more widely accessible.

Recognized as one of Canada's top leaders and sustainability professionals, Connie has received numerous awards, including the TECHGREEN Award from the Applied Science Technologists & Technicians of BC (2014), the Women of Worth Sustainable Living Award (2013), a Queen's Diamond Jubilee Medal (2012), the Minerva Leadership Award (2012), the BC Innovation Council's New Ventures Award (2011) and named one of Canada's Top 100 Most Powerful Women as a Trailblazer/Trendsetter (2011).

Connie has an MBA from the University of British Columbia, and securities and insurance licenses from the Canadian Securities Institute. She is also a certified personal development counsellor and she studied business in Sweden, Germany and at the renowned HEC Paris.

Jarrod Goddard

Chief Technology Officer (CTO) 

Jarrod is an online entrepreneur who specializes in best practices for using the Internet for business growth. As GreenPages' CTO, Jarrod is responsible for the company's technical development.

Jarrod has a background in website development, database design and mobile applications, along with experience in online marketing, social media and search engine optimization.

Jarrod has been recognized for his technological expertise with the Technology Innovator of the Year (2012) Award, Kamloops Chamber of Commerce Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award (2010) and the EDDY Award for Technology (2004).

Ala Aoukaty, Ph.D. 

Director of Content & Research

Ala is a research scientist, immunologist and biochemist with a Ph.D. in immunology and biochemistry from UIO Faculty of Medicine and post-doctoral training at UBC's Faculty of Medicine where he worked as a research scientist and group leader.

Ala works to bring relevant certifications and innovation to GreenPages Directory and is committed to maintaining high quality content that is easily accessible to end-users.

He has received fellowships and grants from the Michael Smith Foundation, Canadian Diabetes Association, Bertram Hoffmeister, MRC, NCS, UNIFOR and NRC, and is the author of over 50 scientific publications and abstracts in respected science journals.

Olga Orda

Community Outreach Director 

Olga is a career communicator with experience in strategic communications and public relations. She is the founder of PitchPen®, a social media and technology platform serving more than 200 consultants across North America, and co-founder of a software and mobile app development firm.

At GreenPages Directory she liaises with our advocacy and community group members to ensure that relevant and timely articles and discussions are brought forward for discussion.

Olga was named one of the Globe Forum's "Emerging Environmental Leaders" and is a Canadian Youth Business Foundation Entrepreneur. She holds an MA in Communication and Culture from the University of Calgary and a BA in Communications from Simon Fraser University.
