story:
I am Richard Waldo and Conservation and Alternative Energy Research, Inc. (CAER) has been a Dream and Goal of mine for over 18 years. I studied Environmental Engineering and Physics at Humboldt State University hoping to make a difference in the planet and the lives of people! I found myself in Corporate America focused strictly on profit and the bottom line… Then I became the bottom line, I was downsized!! Disgusted with Corporate America I sought my original ideals and goals thus CAER was born. Two years and every dime we had went into research on how we can change the energy industry. How can we reduce our dependency on heavy polluting fuels, recycle waste into fuel and reuse the byproducts that came out of that process? Well we did it and our first BioFuels Project is ready for its launch! Your donation will change how we as a fuel dependent society structure our fuel system and take the control out of the big corporations and put it into the hands of the local economies and communities!!

Our Project is centered on recycling and reusing what we are currently wasting and creating a synergistic approach that is focused on balance, and not strictly profit! Everywhere we went for investors they wanted control over our company mission and demanded high profit margins, which went against our company vision.  We want to lower prices in the market, and give back to the local communities!! We at CAER feel it is our responsibility to find better alternatives to what we are doing to our environment and YOUR donation is critical to keeping the integrity of this project.  We are bringing back the balance of business, for the community and the planet!! Once we complete this project we can help others implement this process in any wine region, and any country in the world!! Together we can take some control away from BIG OIL give it to the communities that will benefit from environmentally friendly fuel!!

  

We are seeking $1,000,000.00 in startup funding for this project. We have trimmed and refined the process so that we can get the project done for much less than originally estimated.  CAER will take 30,000 tons of biomass that can be diverted from the landfill, or areas of farms that are a dumping ground for this biomass to slowly decay. This biomass will be recycled into high end compost, and much needed Biofuel for the local area. The compost will be used to reinfuse the soil for local farms and the fuel to provide relief from high priced petroleum products. This synergistic approach is what CAER, Inc. is all about. This project will save valuable space in the landfill, create a boost to farmers’ crop yields, and produce Biofuel that is clean and less expensive than our current petroleum option. We will need seed separators that can deal with wine press waste. Seed presses to extract the oil. Tractors and compost turners are needed for the processing of the skins and stems into compost. Finally mobile industrial grade biodiesel processors will be purchased to produce 250,000 gallons of biodiesel in the first year. There will need to be land and substructure that can handle trucks for dumping off the waste material and loaders to move it around. We will need a covered main processing building and an office for administration work.

 

Sounds great right? There is one catch: YOU! Your participation is critical to the success of this project. We can do so much together in giving back to the local economy and community, but separately we create waste!

We have included incentives that are familiar and perhaps unique as well. Some are things like Bumper Stickers, Shirts and Coffee Mugs that let people know you are a Green Thinker, as well as, a contributor to our future independence of petroleum oil and Big Oil Companies!! Other incentives are unique like fuel coupons for when the plant is in operation! Or a paid trip to the grand opening of the project to meet all the Winery Owners that have contributed to the project!! Since we have trimmed the initial cost to complete the project, we have created incentive that will be well worth your donation. We know that doing the right thing is great but getting a little something extra, is always fun as well!!!

With your contribution to the project we can start the process of converting all of California to a sustainable biodiesel alternative, but it won’t stop there!! This process will work in any wine region, anywhere in the world! We will share this process openly for all to use and benefit from. Our policy of OPEN SOURCE FIRST is at the heart of what we do!! Everything we develop will be OPEN SOURCE Technology so all may benefit. We are in dire straits in the world, and we must do things very differently if we are to overcome them!! Working together we can do just that!

"WE CAN CREATE SOLUTIONS FOR TOMORROW, TODAY!"

 

Additional Information:

The Problem: Most biofuel processing plants utilize


restaurant waste cook oil, soybean oil, or algae based oil.
These processes can be limited, or too expensive due to the
chemical composition of the oil and inconsistency of the
oil. Cooking oil for instance, can be over cooked and
difficult to process in addition the cooking oil may contain
animal fats, or other contaminants that require further
filtering to process the oil. Chemically processing the
cooking oil requires titration of each batch and the use of
large volumes of chemical reactants to separate the esters
in the oil thus making it very costly to process.
The alternative is using clean or virgin oil like soybean
oil. This reduces the need to titrate each batch to process
but there is a significant impact and competition with the
food industry. This can cause the cost of the getting the
soybean oil to be very high. Algae farming and
processing into biofuel is also very costly due to the difficulty in
harvesting algae and processing it into oil, as well as, a low oil
yield.

 

The Solution: CAER, Inc. has identified an untouched,
clean and consistent source of Biomass that can be
processed into oil. The oil derived is chemically consistent for
processing and a stable source of oil for the production of
Biodiesel. With this virgin source of oil the processing cost is
predictable, thus keeping the costs low ensuring a competitive
Biodiesel price point. CAER, Inc. is also diverting 30,000
tons of biomass away from the landfill thus reducing the
production of greenhouse gasses and extending the landfill
life. CAER, Inc. has also created an expansion program that
will allow fallow land to be reclaimed for the production of
a nonfood baring seed plant. Oil from this seed can be used
to allow a further break of the dependency on petroleum.
CAER, Inc. will use a seed baring plant that has high oil yield,
but no impact on the food competition thus solving the
issue of impacting the food industry.

 

Bumper Sticker

This can cause the cost of the getting the soybean oil to be very high. Algae farming and processing into biofuel is also very costly due to the difficulty in harvesting algae and processing it into oil, as well as, a low oil yield.
 
The Solution: CAER, Inc. has identified an untouched, clean and consistent source of Biomass that can be processed into oil. The oil derived is chemically consistent for processing and a stable source of oil for the production of Biodiesel. With this virgin source of oil the processing cost is predictable, thus keeping the costs low ensuring a competitive Biodiesel price point. CAER, Inc. is also diverting 30,000 tons of biomass away from the landfill thus reducing the production of greenhouse gasses and extending the landfill life. CAER, Inc. has also created an expansion program that will allow fallow land to be reclaimed for the production of a nonfood baring seed plant. Oil from this seed can be used to allow a further break of the dependency on petroleum. CAER, Inc. will use a seed baring plant that has high oil yield, but no impact on the food competition thus solving the issue of impacting the food industry.
 
Bumper Sticker

story:
Our Story

Recently there was a massive flood in my father in laws town, that killed about 400 people.  Thankfully he survied, however we can't say the same for his lifetime home, or many of his neighbors.  


The Impact

The impact on the entire town has been unbelievably tragic.  We are very thank full that our father is alive, that is the most important thing, however we are reaching out to help him recover, and his community recover.  He has lost nearly everything in this flood.


What We Need & What You Get

Please donate what you can, and please share this with anyone who might be able to help.  We realize that this is the holiday season, but even $5 dollars would make a significant impact for him and the community.

story:
Update: Tare Market has reached our fundraising goal of $15,000! Thank you so much.

Because we crushed our crowdfunding goal and hit our first stretch goal of an additional $1,500, we have set a second stretch goal for another $1,500 to help us strengthen our offerings in the health and beauty section of our space. This is an area that our customer base has been asking for. At Tare Market, we really want to meet people where they are at and not shame anyone who creates waste. We believe that the more people involved in this movement, the bigger our impact will be.

This additional $1,500 will help us bring zero waste makeup into our space, including mascara, blush, eye shadow, lipstick, foundation, and more. We are sourcing these items from zero waste and low waste manufactures who offer their items in bulk, glass, or refillable compacts. Help us get there by donating today!

Introducing Tare Market, Minnesota's first zero waste store!

Born out of a need for a local resource to help people reduce their waste and overall carbon footprint, we are excited to open our permanent location in South Minneapolis to better serve our community.

At Tare Market, customers can bring their own containers (or borrow some from us), to shop our robust bulk selection. We will offer shelf stable foods, health and beauty items, and household sustainable living products (e.g. reusable straws, bulk cleaners, and compostable dish brushes). All items at Tare Market will be free of non-recycled plastic, and as local and organic as possible. We strive to find the high quality products that are good for you and for the planet, and work with vendors to reduce upstream waste as well. Tare Market will also offer classes and events for members of the community to come together and learn strategies to improve the health of our planet.

...because we are not okay with images like these and we know you aren't either.

Did you know that every plastic toothbrush you have ever used is sitting in a landfill, not decomposing? Yep. And that even most of the food we throw away doesn't break down (see the story about the 25 year old petrified guacamole).

Most of the trash in a landfill does not decompose because it is covered, compacted, and not exposed to oxygen. Instead, trash becomes preserved under tons and tons of other trash. This process causes landfills to off-gas large amounts of methane, a greenhouse gas 30 times more potent than carbon dioxide, and contributes to the contamination of surrounding soil and groundwater.

Imagine, instead, that your toothbrush came in a paper sleeve and was made of bamboo. The bamboo could be thrown in your backyard compost bin, along with your food scraps, and the paper sleeve could be recycled. By using a toothbrush made from natural materials, you avoid putting any waste into the landfill, saving communities of it's negative ramifications. Plus, you can make nutrient-rich compost to feed your garden and plants!

Shopping at Tare Market makes living a low waste lifestyle easy! We vet all of the products we carry (and their producers!) so you know you are only buying high quality products that are good for the environment and for you. While some of our products come in compostable or recyclable (plastic-free) wrapping, we are continuing to find ways to offer as many products as possible in bulk or with absolutely no packaging! To shop our bulk selection of goods, simply bring your own bags and containers, or borrow our returnable jars, tare them, and fill up on as much or as little as you want.

The founders of Tare Market, Kate and Amber, wanted to live more sustainably by creating less waste, but felt that they had limited options in the Twin Cities. While they would find eco-friendly resources here and there, a place they could go that fulfilled most or all of their waste-free needs did not exist. At community events, they continuously heard from locals that they wanted greater access to food and products that were good for them AND package-free.

In the summer of 2018, Kate and Amber decided to start Tare Market. They began by holding pop-ups around the Twin Cities and were floored by the overwhelmingly positive response from community members. Requests for a brick and mortar store where people could shop waste-free on a regular basis were frequent! After six months of concept-testing Tare Market, Amber and Kate are ready to take the next step and open a permanent retail space in Minneapolis. 

Vote with you dollars for a  system that doesn't create waste and helps move the world towards a brighter, greener future. By backing this campaign, you are doing just that!

In addition to our personal investments and a loan, we are hoping to raise $15,000 to help us bring package-free shopping to the Twin Cities. The funds will be used to purchase 100 bulk bins, inventory, nut and coffee grinders, and a refrigerator for our brick and mortar space. If we reach that, we have set flex goals so we can provide even more zero waste resources! Every little bit helps us (and the planet!) and we appreciate anything you can give. 

We have some amazing perks for you for donating! You can chose to pick-up your reward at our launch party (exact date TBD) in South Minneapolis or have us ship your item(s).

The Rewards:

Here are just a few examples of our rewards! Check out all of the rewards on the right side of this webpage.

$20 - Zero Waste Vegan E-Cookbook - Download a copy of @tinyyellowbungalow's brand new e-guide "The Zero Waste Vegan Cookbook". This one of a kind digital cookbook includes a month’s worth of healthy, low waste, and plant based recipes!

$65 - Zero Waste Coffee Experience - Join local coffee roaster SK Coffee at their roastery in LynLake. There, you'll experience and learn about coffee roasting, tasting, and how SK Coffee is aspiring to be zero waste. Take home 340 grams of coffee in your Tare Market cloth bag or bring your own jar to fill with beans. Date of event to be determined by purchaser(s) and SK Coffee.

$99 - Zero Waste Market Kit - This kit provides you with tools to help you reduce waste while shopping your local market. It’s also a great starter kit for the new zero waster, and makes a great gift for friends and family interested in living more sustainably!

Zero waste markets have started popping up all over the world, but the U.S. has very few, and none that exactly fit the Tare Market model. We would be the first store of our kind in the U.S., and the very first package/waste free store in Minnesota. Of course, with any new idea or venture there is risk, so we have tried to mitigate that risk by popping-up around the Twin Cities to test out our business model. Since our first pop-up in August 2018, Tare Market has reached over 1,000 customers, and counting, and successfully launched our online shop. We have had an overwhelmingly positive response from consumers, asking for more zero waste options and more access. We believe that this model with be successful here in the Twin Cities.

To further support or model and expand our reach, Tare Market plans to continue to pop-up several times a year in new areas of the Twin Cities to grow the zero waste movement locally. We feel that these pop-ups will create a community across the Twin Cities of committed and motivated individuals. 

Tare Market will offer educational classes for the Twin Cities community, with high-quality speakers. Classes will include speakers, DIY activities, meeting space for book clubs, and more. 

We so appreciate you and your support, even if it is not monetary! Here are some other ways that you can help launch Tare Market:

  • Please share this campaign with as many people as you can! Post it on social media and email or chat with your friends and family about it.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the love!
  • Contact us (taremarketmn@gmail.com) to volunteer at some promotional events to get the word out in the Twin Cities.

story:
The election of Donald Trump as president of the United States already is having a profound effect on U.S. climate policy. Meet the scientists, economists, engineers, and policy experts who persuaded Trump that man-made global warming is not a crisis, and therefore Barack Obama’s war on fossil fuels must be ended.

The 12th International Conference on Climate Change – carrying the theme “Resetting U.S. Climate Policy” – takes place on Thursday and Friday, March 23–24 at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Washington, DC. It will feature the courageous men and women who spoke the truth about climate change during the height of the global warming scare. Now, many of them are advising the new administration or joining it in senior positions.

ICCC-12 is hosted by The Heartland Institute, “the world’s most prominent think tank supporting skepticism toward man-made climate change” (The Economist). Since 2008, more than 4,000 people have attended one or more ICCCs. These conferences, which have had a profound impact on supporting sensible public policy on climate and energy, are expensive to put on. Can you please donate today to help make sure it is a success?

This year’s ICCC focuses less on the science than previous meetings because climate realists have established beyond reasonable doubt that the human impact on climate is likely to be very small and beneficial rather than harmful. Realists have proven that most scientists now share this opinion, except those who have made careers out of finding a human impact and exaggerating it.

The task now is to explain the benefits of ending Obama’s war on fossil fuels and what policy changes are needed to do this. ICCC-12 will feature in-depth, expert discussions about the economics of energy policy and the benefits and costs of fossil fuels.

We are hoping to raise $20,000 for the conference from this Indiegogo campaign, to help offset expenses that are likely to total some $370,000. Contributions are tax deductible. To help us reach our goal, please contribute to this campaign, or go to The Heartland Institute’s website at and make a contribution at this link.

The past eleven International Conferences on Climate Change were unqualified successes. The conferences were extensively covered by the international media and allowed more than 200 experts to share information and ideas regarding the latest science, economics, and politics related to the global warming debate. More than 4,000 people have attended an ICCC. Videos of the presentations are available online here.

story:
My name is Leandra Taylor; I’m the Coordinator for the Merge Coalition in Albuquerque, New Mexico. I wanted to share with you why I believe in the Emerging Leaders Program—and why I believe it needs your support.

 

2016 Emerging Leader Leandra Taylor.

I’m an Army brat. I grew up behind the tall, iron gates that border the perimeter of Fort Carson Army Base in Colorado Springs. Nature was my escape and my place of solace and happiness—but nature meant exploring the flowers and weeds in the Base’s Iron Horse Park, where my dad, his pants wrinkled from a day's work, dried sweat fanning out in white ripples on his tan shirt and the smell of his Degree deodorant preceding him, would take me and my brother to play. I can still remember the dry, feathery texture of dandelion seeds on my tongue as I tasted the desiccated flower—it was like eating a spider web—and gawking at the Rockies beyond the gate in their magnificent glory. I never imaged that I might one day reach their summits.

My first “real” outdoor experience came on my first weekend in Albuquerque. After graduating from Baylor University with a B.S. in Environmental Science, I’d moved to New Mexico to work as a data management assistant for the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service. Friends had invited me to hike La Luz Trail to the crest of the Sandia Mountains. The 14-mile hike was both physically challenging—the altitude was killing me; I had to take a break every few switchbacks—and exhilarating. I’ll never forget the tawny brown gravel of the trail, the thorny cholla plants that crowded its edges, or the breathtaking views from the top, the scaly towers of the Sandia peaks ringing the purple sky.

I’ll also never forget the stares. Apparently, I, too, was a sight to see, an African-American woman out hiking amid the desert foliage.

“I’ll be sure to always hike with a white friend,” I said to my partners after yet another hiker gawked at me. “Maybe people won’t be so suspicious.”

In the middle of the beautiful vistas, I’d never felt more at home. But as hiker after hiker stared at me, I also didn’t feel welcome.

After the hike, I posted pictures of my trip. My family and friends were astonished. They couldn’t believe I’d been hiking, either.

What I’d experienced on the hike was awe, and joy; though I didn’t realize it at the time, hikes like that would also become a place for healing. But the most extraordinary thing was the reactions—of the other hikers, and of my family and friends. People of color don’t hike!

With that one hike, a passion was born in me, a desire to get people of color into the outdoors and change the narrative of who’s outside. The reason my family reacted the way they did, the reason the other hikers stared, was because we’re not used to seeing people of color outside. Think about it: when was the last time you saw a photo of an African-American woman hiking in the pages of your favorite outdoor magazine?

After that hike, I decided I would be that black face outside. I would be that black voice demanding space in the outdoors, sparking conversations about inclusion—or more accurately about being invited, but not feeling included.

But I didn’t understand how hard the work would be. Though I was slowly emerging as a leader in the conservation movement, conversations about the lack of diversity, especially racial diversity, in the outdoors were wearing me out. I often felt as though I were fighting to validate my presence outside. The work was exhausting.

The Emerging Leaders Program took place around the height of the Black Lives Matter movement. For three days in advance of SHIFT, 33 other young people like myself gathered in Jackson, WY, to discuss outdoor recreation and our public lands. Though we represented many different perspectives and backgrounds, we were united by our love for being outside, and for protecting the places in which we liked to play.  

Emerging Leaders Program Lead Facilitator Colby Mitchell with program participants at the Jackson campus of the Teton Science Schools. The program trains participants to lead the conversations at the annual SHIFT Festival in Jackson Hole.

An integral part of The Emerging Leaders Program, and of SHIFT, is storytelling: creating a space of mutual respect for one another by sharing the stories of how we’ve come to fall in love with these places, and why we believe they need to be protected. Late one dark, magical evening, on one of the first nights of the program, I sat in a circle at the Teton Science Schools with my fellow Emerging Leaders. The room was cozy with warmth, as if a fire were burning in the room, as we shared our stories about what had inspired us to get into this field.

The conversations were electric with passion, and the breadth of stories blew my mind. One leader, a woman whose quiet grace belied her strength, began by saying that while she understood the conservation movement, she didn’t identify with it.

“I fought to keep a new industrial factory from being built in my community and killing my neighbors, my family, my friends,” she said. “Nobody listened.”

“If conservationists don’t care about my community, why should I care about public lands?”

She was fighting for basic rights for her community. The program for her was not about protecting public lands; it was an opportunity to network and grow as a leader so that she could be a powerful voice for her community.

Her words shook me. The conservation and environmental justice movements are often viewed as separate issues. Now I understood how important the relationship between them actually is.

As an army brat, I’d often lacked a sense of place; the transient lifestyle makes it difficult to truly connect to people. So I was surprised when two fellow Emerging Leaders shared stories about their childhoods—they, too, were army brats, with struggles and emotions similar to mine. After the storytelling circle had ended, we talked. Before my dad boarded the bus to deploy to Iraq, he’d promised me and my brothers we’d go to Iron Horse Park when he returned. My new friends understood he’d said that to comfort us. Crying and bonding over the stories we shared, we realized the bond we’d just discovered would never be broken.

On the third day of the program we transferred to SHIFT, where we were featured as panelists, panel hosts, moderators. As we shared our stories and experiences with the “veterans” of outdoor recreation and conservation, they listened. Individually and collectively, our voices rippled through the SHIFT conference, setting the tone for the changes we wanted to see.

As I contributed to the conversations, I felt heard as I’d never been heard before. I went from being empowered to in power, networking and seeking paths to achieve the changes I want to see in my communities and around the nation.

Leandra Taylor speaks at the Center for the Arts as part of the 2016 SHIFT Festival.

The Emerging Leaders Program needs your support. It provides developing leaders like me the opportunity to challenge themselves with new conversations, with people from across the nation, with different perspectives and experiences. It creates a space for young people like me to find a supporting family of peers and mentors. And it changes the experiences for SHIFT participants, so that the me of twenty years from now doesn’t have to go with white friends when she wants to hike in the mountains above Albuquerque.

As young stewards breaking into the conservation world, we’re so grateful for having had the opportunity to experience The Emerging Leaders Program. Your contribution to the program will help insure the next generation of leaders protecting America’s public lands represents our country in all its diversity.

​On behalf of the Emerging Leaders Program,

Thank you. 

 

 

The 2016 Emerging Leaders receive a standing ovation on stage at the 2016 SHIFT Festival.

After that hike, I decided I would be that black face outside. I would be that black voice demanding space in the outdoors, sparking conversations about inclusion—or more accurately about being invited, but not feeling included.
But I didn’t understand how hard the work would be. Though I was slowly emerging as a leader in the conservation movement, conversations about the lack of diversity, especially racial diversity, in the outdoors were wearing me out. I often felt as though I were fighting to validate my presence outside. The work was exhausting.
The Emerging Leaders Program took place around the height of the Black Lives Matter movement. For three days in advance of SHIFT, 33 other young people like myself gathered in Jackson, WY, to discuss outdoor recreation and our public lands. Though we represented many different perspectives and backgrounds, we were united by our love for being outside, and for protecting the places in which we liked to play.  

Emerging Leaders Program Lead Facilitator Colby Mitchell with program participants at the Jackson campus of the Teton Science Schools. The program trains participants to lead the conversations at the annual SHIFT Festival in Jackson Hole.
An integral part of The Emerging Leaders Program, and of SHIFT, is storytelling: creating a space of mutual respect for one another by sharing the stories of how we’ve come to fall in love with these places, and why we believe they need to be protected. Late one dark, magical evening, on one of the first nights of the program, I sat in a circle at the Teton Science Schools with my fellow Emerging Leaders. The room was cozy with warmth, as if a fire were burning in the room, as we shared our stories about what had inspired us to get into this field.
The conversations were electric with passion, and the breadth of stories blew my mind. One leader, a woman whose quiet grace belied her strength, began by saying that while she understood the conservation movement, she didn’t identify with it.
“I fought to keep a new industrial factory from being built in my community and killing my neighbors, my family, my friends,” she said. “Nobody listened.”
“If conservationists don’t care about my community, why should I care about public lands?”
She was fighting for basic rights for her community. The program for her was not about protecting public lands; it was an opportunity to network and grow as a leader so that she could be a powerful voice for her community.
Her words shook me. The conservation and environmental justice movements are often viewed as separate issues. Now I understood how important the relationship between them actually is.
As an army brat, I’d often lacked a sense of place; the transient lifestyle makes it difficult to truly connect to people. So I was surprised when two fellow Emerging Leaders shared stories about their childhoods—they, too, were army brats, with struggles and emotions similar to mine. After the storytelling circle had ended, we talked. Before my dad boarded the bus to deploy to Iraq, he’d promised me and my brothers we’d go to Iron Horse Park when he returned. My new friends understood he’d said that to comfort us. Crying and bonding over the stories we shared, we realized the bond we’d just discovered would never be broken.
On the third day of the program we transferred to SHIFT, where we were featured as panelists, panel hosts, moderators. As we shared our stories and experiences with the “veterans” of outdoor recreation and conservation, they listened. Individually and collectively, our voices rippled through the SHIFT conference, setting the tone for the changes we wanted to see.
As I contributed to the conversations, I felt heard as I’d never been heard before. I went from being empowered to in power, networking and seeking paths to achieve the changes I want to see in my communities and around the nation.

Leandra Taylor speaks at the Center for the Arts as part of the 2016 SHIFT Festival.
The Emerging Leaders Program needs your support. It provides developing leaders like me the opportunity to challenge themselves with new conversations, with people from across the nation, with different perspectives and experiences. It creates a space for young people like me to find a supporting family of peers and mentors. And it changes the experiences for SHIFT participants, so that the me of twenty years from now doesn’t have to go with white friends when she wants to hike in the mountains above Albuquerque.
As young stewards breaking into the conservation world, we’re so grateful for having had the opportunity to experience The Emerging Leaders Program. Your contribution to the program will help insure the next generation of leaders protecting America’s public lands represents our country in all its diversity.
​On behalf of the Emerging Leaders Program,
Thank you. 
 
 
The 2016 Emerging Leaders receive a standing ovation on stage at the 2016 SHIFT Festival.

story:
The Problem:

The family Coffee farms in the Los Santos region of Costa Rica produce some of the finest coffees in the world. But the consequences of common agricultural practices is the destruction of top soil, deforestation, and erosion!!


Our Response:

We founded Santos Projects and Tours in 2003, it was the final project of two business-tourism students at Cartago Community College in Cartago, Costa Rica. Santos Tours arranges and supervises high school and college students as short-term, home-stay guests in 6 key communities to introduce project-based green technologies â€“ Some of our projects include building ecostoves, compost toilets, ecobricks (using plastic bottles stuffed with plastic bags to create construction bricks), and furthering international awareness of the ecological concerns in this beautiful region of Costa Rica.

Slowly, we are transforming the mentality and sustainability of our coffee culture communities to be more environmentally conscious.


Our Next Step:

To further our commitment to sustainability and increase our demonstration of the value and viability of green practices, we want to bring certified biodiesel technology to our farmers to further increase their ability to preserve their livelihood for future generations. We lead by example.

With your help we intend to provide the first example of practical biodiesel transportation in these communities.

Our roots in this region, and the trust we have earned through our volunteer projects gives us tremendous exposure and credibility. We are ready to take the next step by demonstrating the possibility of carbon-neutral communities.

Our plan is to purchase a reliable Chevy express Diesel or similar 15 passenger 4x4 and convert it to biodiesel. We will use it to transport our student volunteer groups to and from their projects and between these mountainous communities. We would also use this demonstration vehicle in our additional eco-tourism projects throughout this beautiful region.

Our volunteers partner company, International Student Volunteers, (www.isvonline.org) has already demonstrated their belief and confidence in our abilities by providing us with the biodiesel production technology, whereby we are able to transform previously discarded oil from small restaurants into what is definitely the cheapest and cleanest fuel source available. We will be able to demonstrate carbon-neutral transportation as a legitimate, reliable, and viable alternative for our farmers â€“ they will save money, and sustain and better preserve their way of life for a better future for us all.

 

The Impact:

We are striving to transform these culturally rooted farming practices and introduce new, ecologically friendly methods of farming and transportation. Our biodiesel fuel comes from small restaurants recycled oil that would otherwise be thrown away. The truck is our way of putting our money where our mouth is. How can we be a green, environmentally conscious tourism company without carbon neutral transportation? By using a biodiesel vehicle we can influence the volunteers that take part in our tours, as well as impact the farmers who, little by little, are going to see the benefits of biodiesel transportation and machinery, and hopefully chose to convert to this method.


 What We Need & What You Get:

We are hoping to buy a late model chevy express van 4x4 in the U.S. and ship it down to Costa Rica. The reason we are looking in the U.S. and not locally is because it is the cheapest option to avoid high taxes and fees in Costa Rica. Our estimate is $10,000 for all the costs and fees of purchasing and shipping the truck, plus conversion into a biodiesel machine. If we are lucky enough to receive more money than that, the extra will go to maintenance.

 We believe that we can do something big for the world. First by transforming the practices of this small village into a more ecologically conscious, and then by spreading the influence to bigger towns. Using and promoting biodiesel machinery is just one step towards realizing this goal of greener communities in Costa Rica! Please visit our website for more information


http://www.santostour.net/biodiesel_project/

story:
A 14-month bicycle tour to the Amazon of the Oceans

My name is Elena Couce, and as many people do, I truly fell in love with the oceans when I started scuba diving. I was driven to learn all I could about them, and now I work as a coral reef scientist at the University of Bristol, trying to understand how climate change is affecting our oceans. In the last few years I have spent thousands of hours conducting research on a computer. Now I feel it is time to leave the computer behind and begin field research and exploration, in order to understand how things really are in the oceans and to share these insights with others.

On January 16th 2014 I will begin a 14-month expedition cycling along the coast of a tropical region in Southeast Asia known as The Coral Triangle. With the help of other researchers and adventurers I will be documenting the extraordinary biodiversity region that is the underwater equivalent of the Amazon. It harbours more species than any other marine environment on the planet, including 76% of all coral types and more than 3000 species of fish. And, like the Amazon and other natural wonders of the world, the Coral Triangle is under grave threat.

I will cycle through the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands to document the state of their coral reefs and of the communities that depend on it; to share my academic knowledge and learn from local people and organisations; to engage with local and western schools to share our findings, raise awareness and instil into as many children as possible a sense of wonder about our oceans and the amazing creatures that live in it.

During my tour I will visit marine reserves and conservation projects in the coast, carry out interviews with conservationists, scientists and local people to find out what is happening, go snorkelling and scuba diving, and take photos and videos --both in and out of the water-- to share my journey with the world, through my website and blog.

I won't always be alone. Several people will join me as I go along at different times in the route. There is also a support team back home, working to make the most of this opportunity to raise awareness for marine conservation. It includes people who work in science engagement and education (who will help make it possible for schools to follow the trip), people who work in the media field, a professional photographer, and even an artist, among others.

Raising awareness and helping conserve our oceans

Scientists, NGOs and government officials working in the Coral Triangle region have written to us expressing their support, and we have been getting many offers to host me as I go along the route, so we can tell the world the conservation work they are doing. They all want to get the message out, tell the stories of the lands and waters they protect, of the life in them, and the work that still needs to be done.

We will also raise money to help with marine conservation in the area. We have chosen WWF as our main charity, with the money raised going towards their Coral Triangle Program. We also intend to promote other conservation projects that we will visit as we go along and raise money for them.

We are asking for your help to make our project come true

So far I have been covering the expenses from my own savings, and all the team members are volunteering their time. But the project has grown well beyond what I initially intended and I need your help to make it come true. £6,000 will go a long way in helping finance some of the most urgent matters. In particular:

  • Getting a second bike and basic kit, to be borrowed by the other participants that will be joining the adventure at different times. For many of them this represents the difference between being able to afford it or not!
  • Purchasing a HD video camera, small enough to carry around on a bike and able to be used both in and out of the water.
  • Some of the cost of the essential kit, such as the bike, panniers, sleeping hammock and camping material that I will need.
  • Make it possible to reach areas that are harder to get to.
  • Make the project safer, by being able to hire local guides in particularly tricky parts of the route that are far from the normal touristic routes

As thank you for your help:

We have prepared several exclusive Cycling the Coral Triangle (CCT) presents to show our thanks for your contribution.

For contributions of £50 or more we have prepared a very special CCT pendant, featuring a high-quality 20mm Swarovski stone in dark blue, symbolising the ocean, together with a bicycle charm in Tibetan silver, suspended from 100% natural hemp cords in brown tonalities, symbolising the land. There are two different versions you can choose from (we just can't decide which one we like best!):


For contributions of £100 or more, we will also send a CCT cotton t-shirt, with a design similar to this:

I am also an avid underwater and outdoor photographer, and have had several photos published (one of them won an award!) All the underwater photos on this page were taken by me. Starting at £100, our perks include printed HD photos taken during the journey. For contributions above £500 the photo will be printed on a 16"x24" high quality photo canvas!

Help us get the word out!

Even if you cannot afford to contribute with money, we'd really love to have you join in our adventure:

  • Follow our trip on the blog and tell your friends about it
  • If you are passionate about the oceans, write to tell us about it and let us share it on the web!

Thanks for your support.

story:
The Green Driving Challenge

Introducing The Green Driving Challenge – an eco-driving game that makes it fun and easy to reduce your carbon footprint. 

The objective is to get better mileage than your car’s city and highway mileage ratings. It’s like a Fitbit for your car that helps you save money and protect the environment. Players are rewarded for accomplishments such as saving their first $10 on gas, averting 500 pounds of CO2, and reducing fuel consumption by 10%.

Once you’ve plugged an On Board Diagnostics (OBD) scanner into your car’s data port, you can turn on your mobile device and head out on the road. The GDC app does the hard work for you. It collects driving data from your trips, crunches the numbers and yields personal, easy-to-read information. 

The Green Driving Challenge is safe, responsive, engaging, and downright habit-forming. Most users will be delighted to watch their carbon footprints shrink, and as a bonus, they'll save between $150 and $300 on gas per year.

Check out this great review at Automoblog.net to learn more about how it works. 

Eco-Driving

So, what is eco-driving? Vehicle maintenance and anticipation, paying close attention to the roadway environment and to other vehicles are at its core. When possible, eco-drivers time their trips to avoid traffic congestion, avoid unnecessary idling and rapid acceleration, and try to maintain reasonable and consistent speeds. It’s not difficult! The trick is to keep at it, and most players will reduce fuel use by 5 to 25%.

By playing the game, you'll learn why most truck drivers and millions of people all over the world are already eco-driving.


How it Works

After you initially plug in the OBD scanner into your vehicle’s OBD port, using the GDC app is as easy as 1, 2, 3.

First, press connect on the GDC app before you start a trip; second, hit the road; and, third, go to the website and check out your results.

The app uploads the trip data, evaluates the numbers and gives players crucial driving information, from dollars saved to improved MPG to carbon dioxide reductions.

It’s fun to get better gas mileage than your car’s MPG ratings. Players also can choose whether to join or form a team and whether to compete head-to-head against selected players. 

Although GDC is played while driving, it is safe. One of the tenets of eco-driving is to pay close attention to the road, so the app does not allow players to check their progress during the trip. 


Our Goal

As of May 25, ten drivers have provided data from 1,648 trips covering 38,147 miles. They averted 3,974 pounds of CO2 emissions and saved $538 by using less gas. As we gather data, we are polishing the prototype, building a team, and searching for others equally passionate about arresting climate change.

Your support will help us improve the game, refine the Android app, and begin developing an iOS version.   

Funding Goal: $3,000

  • Web development of head-to-head competition 
  • Pilot testing the game
  • Analyze the data to improve individual coaching

Thanks to the generosity of our supporters, we've met our funding goal. We still have lots of work to do, so now it's time to stretch.

Stretch Goal: $3,000

* Adding team features, such as a “Free Agent” pool of players willing to join a team

* Adding a shopping cart to simplify the signup process

* Development of eco-driving infographics


Risks & Challenges

Data. We need millions of miles of driving data from many different cars and drivers to help us calibrate measurement tools and set game rewards. More data will help us understand differences in driving styles, improve eco-driving feedback, and learn what inspires drivers to to record every trip. 

Feedback. Driver feedback is crucial to improving the app. We’ll try to answers questions such as:

  • What features do players like the most? 
  • What proportion of players want to join or form teams?
  • What proportion of players want to compete head-to-head with other drivers?
  • How often will players want updates? 
  • What functions should we add to the website?
Communication. Because GDC is unique, it can be challenging to describe — it’s an app, a service, and a game. We need to persuade people that GDC makes it easy to improve fuel economy and reduce carbon emissions. Another key to attracting users is communicating that eco-driving with GDC makes driving less stressful.

How You Can Help

Eco-driving is a huge untapped resource for fighting climate change. 
We're ready to put GDC to the test, but we need your feedback and financial support to get us to the starting line. Please join us as we begin this exciting journey.
Support the campaign! Choose a reward level that speaks to you...our t-shirts are super soft, by the way.
Spread the word! Even if you can't part with cash right now, sharing the campaign with friends and family would be a huge help. 
And if you're online, connect with us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram! 


The Team

Scott Osberg and his partner, Sarah Stiles, founded MyClubEco, LLC with the  mission of slowing climate change.  With Scott's background in traffic safety research, they began building the Green Driving Challenge with the hope of seriously reducing vehicle emissions.

Scott and Sarah now have a team helping them to turn their ideals into action. Rebecca Hinch,  began as a test driver in 2014 and is now a full-time employee.  In the past year, three University of Virginia students, Sam Moore, Cameron Blandford, and Jake Mathews have contributed as well.

story:
Short Summary

Chief Mickey Stickman is alarmed over the changes he sees in the Yukon River king salmon. The fish are smaller and fewer than before, putting his community’s food supply and traditional practices at risk. Indigenous communities across the Arctic are sounding this alarm; if the salmon are in trouble, we could be too.

Chief Stickman has rallied Arctic indigenous communities from Canada, USA, Norway, Finland and Russia to work with Western scientists to design a study that would explore:

  • how salmon—an important food source—is changing across the Arctic,
  • what implications these changes have on communities and the environment, and;
  • what we can learn from Indigenous perspectives on ecosystem health and freshwater systems.

Funding is needed for an October 2015 workshop that will bring Indigenous community members from the Yukon, Tena and Kamchatka Rivers together to share knowledge and concerns of Indigenous communities across the Arctic. 

The project will be reported to the Arctic Council, the preeminent international body for cooperation in the Arctic.

Any money raised beyond our goal for the October workshop will be used to fund subsequent workshops and meetings.

 

Chief Mickey Stickmen fishing for Yukon River king salmon in his open air boat. 


What We Need

We are asking for $75,000 in funding to support a first workshop to be held in October 2015 in Fairbanks, Alaska. 

The project is a three step process working towards co-producing a “Salmon Peoples of Arctic Rivers” assessment that brings scientific and traditional knowledge together to identify how freshwater ecosystems are changing, how this affects communities and what actions can be done to protect salmon and communities. 

The October 2015 workshop will:

  • Bring together 24 traditional knowledge holders and community representatives from across the Arctic
  • Create space for communities to share wisdom, oral histories, observations, stories, prophecy and other information about salmon and changes in their communities
  • Gather knowledge and observations on changes in salmon populations and how this affects their communities
  • Develop questions for the scientific research community
  • Develop common goals for an Arctic-wide assessment
  • Develop an understanding of how their traditional knowledge will be used in such an assessment
  • Survey participants on the design and effectiveness of the workshop to inform future workshop design
  • Host a dialogue amongst indigenous peoples, creating an important first step in the process of co-producing an assessment using both traditional and scientific knowledge.

Specifically funding will support:

Economy air travel and hotel accommodation for 24 village elders, subsistence fishermen and other knowledge holders and participants from communities to attend workshops $47,180.

  • Four participants from: Arctic Athabaskan Council $4,280, Saami Council $11,080, Aleut International Association $5,580, Inuit Circumpolar Council $5,580, RAIPON $16,380, Gwichin Council International $4,280.

Staff and administrative costs $10,200

  • Background research, recruiting participants, agenda development, facilitating the discussion at the workshop to align with current research on the relationship between traditional knowledge and science, and producing meeting transcripts and analysis $3,000
  • Travel for technical advisor and student intern: $2,100
  • Student labour (indigenous and non-indigenous students) including designing and conducting participant survey to gauge workshop success, data collection on site, meeting set up and preparations, transcribing 10+ hours of materials, document management: $4,200

Logistics costs $16,620

  • Honoraria and per diem for attendees: $7,320
  • Translation and interpretation services at workshops: $3,000
  • Catering: $1,500
  • Room rental: $800
  • Facilitation at workshop: $4,000

This is the first of three two-day workshops for this project. The other two workshops, to be held in 2016 and 2017, will bring traditional knowledge holders and scientists together to further develop the design of a final assessment. Any money raised beyond our goal for the October meeting will be used to fund the subsequent meetings.

This first stage is especially important because it engages communities and traditional knowledge holders from the outset of a study— laying the ground-work for an assessment that is co-produced by both traditional knowledge and western science. It is the first of many steps to find policy solutions that support how communities prepare and adjust for effects of climate change.

The Impact

Project results will be shared with the Arctic Council, a high level intergovernmental forum to promote cooperation, coordination and interaction among the eight Arctic nations, with the involvement of Arctic Indigenous communities and other Arctic inhabitants on common Arctic issues, in particular issues of sustainable development and environmental protection in the Arctic.

Indigenous peoples will have lessons not only for the Arctic’s scientific community, but also for all Arctic fishermen, Arctic communities, industry operating in the Arctic, and Arctic governance systems including national, regional and local governments.

The project will detail changes in the following river systems:

  • Yukon/Kuskokwim (Canada and USA; territories used by Athabaskan, Gwich’in and some Inuit)
  • Kamchatka River (Russia; territories used by Koryak, Itelmen, Even, Evenki Aleut and Chukchis)
  • Deatnu/Teno River (Finland and Norway; territories used by Saami)
The project has real opportunity to influence management decisions (such as fishing practices, regulatory measures, legislation, and conservation) both locally, regionally and nationally across the Arctic

Who is behind this?

The project is led by Chief Mickey Stickman of the Arctic Athabaskan Council and is informed by a project steering committee consisting of the following people and organizations that represent indigenous peoples of the Arctic and are Permanent Participants of the Arctic Council: 

Annette Watson, Arctic Athabaskan Council technical advisor

Gunn-Britt Retter, Saami Council 

Victoria Sharakhmatova, Russian Association of Indigenous Peoples of the North 

Jim Gamble, Aleut International Association

Carolina Behe, Inuit Circumpolar Council, Alaska

Tom Barry, Conservation of Arctic Flora and Fauna Secretariat

This project is also important because it engages communities and traditional knowledge holders from the outset of a study— laying the ground-work for an assessment that is co-produced by both traditional knowledge and western science.

     


The Full Story

In the vast Alaskan wilderness Chief Mickey Stickman, 66, sits, listening to the Yukon River lap at the edge of his boat while he drags in his fishing line. Disappointment waits on the other end. 

“I’m really afraid,” he says, “Really, really afraid. For so long the fish here, they gave us life. Now the real worry is that we will go hungry.”

The prize catch is the Yukon River king salmon, a large, nutritious fish that contains many of the micronutrients essential for a healthy diet. But this fish—at least as they knew it—has virtually disappeared from these waters.

Once weighing up to 100 lbs. each, the remaining Yukon River king salmon are less than half the size they once were, leading fishermen along the river in to establish a complete fishing ban in 2013, in the hopes that the fish numbers and size rebound.

“It’s incredible,” says Chief Stickman. “We went from having such a supply year after year after year. We had it all the time. For it to go from that to all of a sudden nothing, well, it was real scary. I just thought to myself, ‘man, we have to do something or our children won’t have Yukon River kings!’”

Salmonids face an uncertain future. Recent headlines (see here, here and here) confirm what Chief Stickman and other fishermen already know: that rising temperatures are causing trouble for salmon populations and “if the fish aren’t right,” says Chief Stickman, “then there is a chain reaction. It isn’t good for our environment.” Indeed, the Yukon (USA/Canada) is not the only river system facing such a crisis: Indigenous peoples along the Tena River (Norway/Finland) and the Kamchatka River (Russia) have expressed similar concerns.

The scientific community is also worried. IUCN says salmon are one of the species that will be most affected by climate change, and the species have made it to their “climate change hit list”.  The Arctic Council’s Conservation of Arctic Flora and Fauna's Arctic Biodiversity Assessment says rising temperatures, especially in with other stressors such as contaminant exposure, can harm salmon diversity and numbers.

In the meantime, communities along Arctic rivers are left to fill the hole in their diets. To get an idea of how big that hole is, consider that Yukon River subsistence fishermen caught 55,000 Yukon River king salmon per year over the past 20 years, feeding an estimated 30,000 people annually along this one river.

The importance of this fish as a food source cannot be understated: in the remote Arctic wilderness, nutritious food alternatives are expensive and quality varies. But importantly, subsistence fishing doesn’t just feed; it connects people to their culture and communities.

“Fishing is an important activity for me,” says Chief Stickman. “I’m out there with my nephew and it makes you feel really good that you are continuing on the traditions. And when you share with the community you know that you are helping, and you feel good about yourself. You know your life will go on. For these reasons, fish is more valuable than gold.

Armed with knowledge, passion, and similar stories from across the Arctic, Chief Stickman rallied other Arctic indigenous representatives to come together, combine their traditional knowledge and wisdom with science to find out what is what is happening to salmon across the Arctic, and what they can do to respond.

“The important thing is that this is a natural renewable resource,” says Chief Stickman. “If you take care of it, well, it will come back.”

story:
Geniusॐ

GeniusOM Compactor 

 ZERO WASTE 

 

April 11, 2017

RAI 2, Radio Italian Television,

Luca Falace, GeniusOm

RAI 2, Radio Italian Television, Luca Falace, GeniusOm. Television program "The Facts Your" Giancarlo Magalli RAI 2, Tuesday, April 11, 2017. Luca Falace and Giancarlo Magalli, GeniusOm, Patent Office Rai 2. 

RAI 2, Radio Italian Television, Luca Falace, GeniusOm. Television program "The Facts Your" Giancarlo Magalli RAI 2, Tuesday, April 11, 2017. Luca Falace and Giancarlo Magalli, GeniusOm, Patent Office Rai 2. 

RAI 2, Radio Italian Television, Luca Falace, GeniusOm. Television program "The Facts Your" Giancarlo Magalli RAI 2, Tuesday, April 11, 2017. Luca Falace and Giancarlo Magalli, GeniusOm, Patent Office Rai 2. 

VIDEO, RAI 2, Radio Italian Television, Luca Falace, GeniusOm: 

 

GENIUSOM COMPACTOR

SOLVES THE PROBLEM OF WASTE ALL OVER THE PLANET EARTH

 

1) The compactor geniusom compacts the 80% of the volume of all the public urban waste, solving the problem at the origin of the world's municipal waste.

2) The compactor geniusom is the only machine in the world that a single command can shrink by 80% and differentiate all the municipal waste: organic, moist, plastic, paper, undifferentiated, metal and glass.

3) The patented compactor geniusom mechanism can be manufactured to any size and and therefore endless types of geniusom compactors can be built with the same mechanism to fit into any home site, private or public in any place where the human being is, offering a new essential service all over the world.

4)The machinery has different sections for each type of waste and it compacts each one, making it possible to throw waste away once two weeks rather than on daily bases.

5) The costs of the compactor are low and therefore it becomes easy to distribute it throughout the global market, becoming an indispensable good for civilization.

 

GeniusOM | Geniusॐ Compactor | ZERO WASTE​

Video 00:50 seconds  

 

Video 01:26 minutes

 
Mechanism of the Machine 
 
Video 01:46 minutes  
 

Video 02:10 minutes  

 

GeniusOM | Geniusॐ Compactor | Full Video 

Video 04:44 minutes  

 

 

GENIUS-OM COMPACTOR

GeniusOm is a start-up which has patented the solution for the disposal of rubbish: a device able to compact most type of waste. Its appearance is similar to most household appliances making it suitable for schools, hospitals, airports, planes and ships.

The machine has been conceived to sort waste in different categories: paper, metals, undifferentiated and wet waste.

There are three available models at the moment suitable for domestic, condominiums and hospital employment, which will all be using the same patented mechanism.

The domestic version is the same size of a common household appliance. The machinery has different section for each type of waste and compacts each one, making it possible to throw waste away once a week rather than on a daily bases.

Special filters for wet waste are also provided. Moreover, the company is planning a generator able to transform organic waste into energy.

 

ZERO WASTE

The GENIUSOM machinery was developed for domestic and urban use. It reduces significantly the amount of urban waste, making the disposal and separate collection of wet, plastic, metal and paper waste possible.

 

PATENT COMPACTOR THREE

TYPES OF GENIUSOM COMPACTOR

The device can be used in both a domestic and public environment. The downsizing of different waste is done by the same machinery.

Due to its reduced handy and technological size it can be considered just like any other household appliance and therefore essential for public and domestic comfort.

The size of the two modesl  for public use varies depending on its employment, in schools, hospitals, restaurants, hotels and condominiums.

 

COMPANY DESCRIPTION

AND TARGET MARKET

GeniusOm was funded to provide a real solution to the disposal of community waste. Its objective is to develop, produce and sell a selection of compactors for the separate collection of waste.

The devices will have a great price/performance ratio. Even if the prototype is still to be produced, the main project and the specification of the product are completed.

The company commends a team of engineers, experts in measuring and control systems and in the production of industrial machineries.

The key to the success of GeniusOm is in the ability of the team to handle and create a wide variety of innovative products and to subsequently sell it with a good price/quality ratio to a wide market.

The co-founders of GeniusOm are valued experts, whose experience will generate a synergy in support of modern society.

 

A RADICAL SOLUTION TO THE VOLUME

AND SEPARATE COLLECTION OF WASTE

OPERATING PRINCIPAL OF THE MACHINARY

Compressing machinery powered by compressed air, for domestic and community waste, with a unique press air-operated.

The power derives from an air compressor, made of a surface with five, variable, sections joint to a pneumatic piston, which when activated allows the compression of all the waste found in the sections of the device.

The result is a  compacting of urban and domestic waste and a separate collection of wet waste, plastic, paper, metals and even glass in a separate section. The compressed waste is collected separately at the bottom of the device.

 

FIELD OF BUSINESS AND PRODUCTS

The main field of business of GeniusOm consists in the production and selling of waste compactor.

The company’s aim is to be become part of the household appliances market with an innovative solution for separate waste collection.

Thanks to its patented project, GeniusOm will produce a domestic compactor and a bigger version appropriate for public places such as hospitals, hotels, restaurants, schools, universities, etc.

 

COMPETITION

The models proposed by competitors have some clear disadvantages, first of all they are rotating compactors, that provide the transition and compression of waste via opposite cylinders, positioned in the top part of the device. The sensor is activated by the machinery when it detects waste or hand-operated, but the most important detail is the ability of the device to compress just one residue at a time.

Moreover these models have a single narrow slot in for waste making its employment highly uncomfortable for the user. At the moment the market is composed by companies that produce and sell:

Hand operated compactors, which can be placed on a wall, envisage the user to compress a whole bag of waste at a time by placing it under the lever, this is a cheap but clearly inconvenient solution.

Single compressing bins which make the purchase of various units, for different refuse, compelling and do not, however, compress a large quantity of waste.

Single section, electric compactors which do not solve the separate waste collection problem.
Prototype models of separate waste collection compactors, which we consider our direct competitors, which are pricey solutions and do not guarantee the compression of all types of waste.

 

GENIUSOM UNIQUE COMPACTOR

FOR ALL WASTE

This innovative device, represents a practical solution and a radical change to the problem of domestic and community waste solving the problem at its source.

The machinery, by compacting all kinds of community waste, solves the problem of waste disposal at its origin.

Our product, allows the compression of all waste and can really represent a revolution in the way community waste is handled.

It represents the ultimate and concrete solution to high amounts of refuse and separate waste collection.

THE GENIUSOM MACHINERY WAS INVENTED FOR DOMESTIC AND URBAN USE

THE MACHINE HAS BEEN CONCEIVED TO SORT WASTE IN DIFFERENT CATEGORIES:

PAPER, METALS, UNDIFFERENTIATED AND WET WASTE.

THERE ARE THREE AVAILABLE MODELS SUITABLE FOR

DOMESTIC USE, CONDOMINIUMS, SCHOOLS, UNIVERSITIES,

HOSPITALS, RESTAURANTS, HOTELS, MALLS, STATIONS,

PORTS, AIRPORTS, PLANES AND SHIPS.

ALL THE MODELS USE THE SAME PATENTED MECHANISM

THE MACHINERY, BY COMPACTING ALL KINDS OF COMMUNITY

WASTE, SOLVES THE PROBLEM OF WASTE DISPOSAL AT ITS ORIGIN.

THIS INNOVATIVE DEVICE, REPRESENTS A PRACTICAL SOLUTION AND A RADICAL CHANGE TO THE PROBLEM OF DOMESTIC AND COMMUNITY WASTE SOLVING THE PROBLEM AT ITS SOURCE.

 fig.1

fig.2
 

ZERO WASTE

GENIUSOM UNIQUE COMPACTOR

FOR ALL WASTE.

 

STORY

GeniusOM Compactor,

Luca Falace's Invention and Patent

 

COSTS INCURRED BY LUCA FALACE FROM THE YEAR 2013 TO THE YEAR 2016

AND FOR HIS INVENTION GENIUSOM COMPACTOR PROJECT

Investment total cost of 53,000 euros incurred only by Luca Falace: patent fees, events, contacts, marketing, company ', processing drawings and documents, prototype simulation, project presentations, marketing, participation in events, participation and personal presence in awards and awarded prizes, etc.

 

GENIUSOM COMPACTOR

Certification and Summary

 

THE YEAR 2014

 

For all these reasons the Geniusom Patent has received considerable and important awards

in the Green Economy field:

 

 

 

GENIUSOM PRIZE ECOMONDO 2014

WITH THE ACCESSION OF

THE PRESIDENT OF

THE ITALIAN REPUBLIC

AWARD FOR

SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT

GeniusOM Compactor, Luca Falace's Invention and Patent

Geniusom Prize Ecomondo 2014

 

THE YEAR 2015

 

FINANCING FUNDS

NOW APPROVED

GENIUSOM COMPACTOR,

SHARK TANK ITALY, CHANNEL ITALIA1

 

Italian television network MEDIASET, CHANNEL ITALIA1, on the 4th of june, 2015.

GeniusOM Compactor, Luca Falace's Invention and Patent

Shark Tank Italy, Mediaset, channel Italia1​, 2015

The financing of 250 thousand Euros, to finance the industrial prototype of the compactor geniusom, was never receved by me. The 99% of the competitors winners, whose project was approved during the television programme SHARK TANK ITALY 2015, weren’t financed by the the financers, hosted on the programme, because of the lack of money. This television programme was on the air on the important, serious and professional Italian television network MEDIASET, CHANNEL ITALIA1, on the 4th of june, 2015.

GeniusOM Compactor, Luca Falace's Invention and Patent

Shark Tank Italy, Mediaset, channel Italia1​, 2015

 

THE YEAR 2016

 

COMPACTOR PATENT CERTIFICATION

GENIUSOM COMPACTOR, LUCA FALACE'S INVENTION AND PATENT

PATENT COMPACTOR
THREE TYPES OF GENIUSOM COMPACTOR

The device can be used in both a domestic and public environment. The downsizing of different waste is done by the same machinery. Due to its reduced handy and technological size it can be considered just like any other household appliance and therefore essential for public and domestic comfort. The size of the two models for public use varies depending on its employment, in schools, hospitals, restaurants, hotels and condominiums.

 

THE PATENT CERTIFICATE

ABSTRACT OF THE PATENT


CLAIMS

1. Compressed air machinery with a compressed air press whose floor is equipped with a plurality of five and it is fixed to a pneumatic piston [a] which in its compression action enables the top press to compress any waste present in the five different sections of the machinery, in order to be collected separately in the light air containers available at the bottom of the machine.

2. Compressed air machinery characterized by the fact that the compressed-air piston enables the top of the press, to make inside of the five modules, or the five sections in which the five major municipal waste are present :organic-wet , glass, plastic, metal, paper, the waste collection with the reduction of the eighty percent of the original volume of all major municipal waste.

3. Machinery according to claim 2 characterized by the fact that the portion of rectilinear motion of the press, which goes to compress on municipal waste contained in modules, acts in a differentiated manner in the related compartments at the end of the compression proces

4. Machinery according to claim 3 allows the differentiation of compressed waste deposited with a reduction of the eighty percent of the original volume.

5. Machinery according to claims 1 to 4, characterized by the fact that the device which allows the action of ignition may be variable: with one or more pistons up to five, as many as the section modules of differentiation, with a single switch or individual switches for how many modules housing the waste, with a single foot, or a foot for each form of waste. This depends on the industrialization of machinery; for household or public use, or for practical and economic variants, as regards the production of machinery.

6. Machinery according to claims 1 and 4, characterized by the fact that after the user has introduced each differentiated waste in the appropriate container by means of a small door, the press can work only when all five doors are closed hermetically.

7. Machinery according to claims 1,3,4 characterized by the fact that when the compression process is over, it reduces the size eighty percent of the volume of waste in each module. The compressor waste is conveyed in the individual sections, before their extraction. At the base of each module there is a removable drip tray for emptying the accumulated liquids . In this container it is conveyed the fluid resulting from the compression of the waste ,especially the organic one, and all the others in a smaller quantity: glass, plastic, metal, cardboard. Regarding the section, in particular the form of organic waste-wet, at the base of this form of machinery, there is a drip tray greater than all the others.

8. Machinery according to claims 1 to 7, characterized by the fact that the deposit of the four waste: glass, plastic, metal, cardboard can lie in the conteiner until this is filled and ready tobe emptied.

9. Machinery according to claims 1 to 8, characterized by the fact that all the sections that collect wet waste are subject, at each compression, simultaneously to a sterilization action of the compressed matter.

10. Machinery according to claims 1 to 9 characterized by the fact that the modules present in the machinery have a dedicated small door and a specific inclination downwards, to allow the compressed material, to be collected in any container plasticized in emptying phase.

The request is made on indiegogo internationally: EURO 250 thousand industrial realization of geniusom prototype, a sum that serves for the realization of the industrial prototype (Prototype Engineering Machine) of the geniusom compactor. This request is being made to work at the geniusom project, approved by awards, accolades and fame at a national level, so that people can know as well as understand the importance of the project, also realize what could be a global business by solving the problem at the origin of the waste urban public.

 

EXAMPLES OF MARKET

​SUMMARY 

GENIUSOM COMPACTOR

ZERO WASTE

1) The compactor geniusom compacts the 80% of the volume of all the public urban waste, solving the problem at the origin of the world's municipal waste.

2) The compactor geniusom is the only machine in the world that a single command can shrink by 80% and differentiate all the municipal waste: organic, moist, plastic, paper, undifferentiated, metal and glass.

3) The patented compactor geniusom mechanism can be manufactured to any size and and therefore endless types of geniusom compactors can be built with the same mechanism to fit into any home site, private or public in any place where the human being is, offering a new essential service all over the world.

4)The machinery has different sections for each type of waste and it compacts each one, making it possible to throw waste away once two weeks rather than on daily bases.5) The costs of the compactor are low and therefore it becomes easy to distribute it throughout the global market, becoming an indispensable good for civilization.

  • The price of a domestic compactor:

about $ 350 (buildings, offices, boats, schedules flights trains, restaurants, bars, hotels, hospitals, universities, etc.)

  • The price of the compactor for large private or public buildings:

about $ 1,700 (condos, shopping centers, ports, airports, railways, large structures, parks etc.)

GeniusOM | Geniusॐ Compactor | ZERO WASTE​
