story:
Do your have your own quiet place in a park, by the water or in a nature reserve?  A place that you frequently visit to breathe, wind down and recharge? Maybe it’s under a tree in the park close to work or up on that mountain ridge not far from your home or in the still part of the trail along the river. Most people can, if they start being aware of the value of silence, find small or big green spaces with relative silence and stillness. Some of these places are close to home or work, some are further away. But, no matter where they are, these places can have an enormous impact on our well-being, health and ability to focus and function as a human being.  And importantly, green, quiet spaces in or close to cities and communities are also important for the biodiversity, sustainability and appeal of our cities and communities.  

We are all today flooded with information and entertainment; for decades we have lived in an ever expanding age of information. But maybe we are, as the Swedish Future Trend firm Kairos Future has suggested, now moving into  “the age of concentration”. To thrive in the world today we need to be able to focus and focus is connected to inner and outer silence. The increasing interest in meditation, mindfulness and the need to find time for recovery and stillness indicates that maybe the “age of concentration” is not that far away. 


THE ORIGINAL. More than 15 years ago, in 1998, the original Guide to Silence was published. The purpose was twofold. 

The first  was to show the way and let more people experience the extraordinary silence and wilderness of the Swedish mountains. The second (but not secondary) purpose was to provide a guide to inner silence, stillness and new perspectives. The Guide to Silence is a guide book without facts - you won’t find the name of the mountains, lakes or trees. Instead it’s a guide to increased awareness and presence, to lower levels of stress.  It is a guide to being in nature and experiencing nature fully. But, the book’s audience wasn’t limited to only those lucky enough to hike in the Swedish mountains. The beautiful photography from one of Sweden’s most well known nature photographers, Bo Kristiansson, which accompanies  the short text makes the Guide to Silence a compelling work also from the sofa. To just read the book in a calm setting can lower stress levels and provide new perspectives. Thus the Guide to Silence has found an audience  around the world and we have sent guidebooks across Europe, the U.S. as well as to China.  You will find a limited edition of the original Guide to Silence included in our perks. 

A taste of Guide to Silence.  Below you find the introductory chapter in English, start and stop the movie to read. 


A taste of Wegweiser in die Stille.  Below you find the introductory chapter in German, start and stop the movie to read. 


A taste of Guide till tystnaden.  Below you find the introductory chapter in Swedish, start and stop the movie to read. 


THE RESTART. In 2013 the Guide to Silence project restarted, and the focus is now green spaces close to or in cities that offer relative silence and stillness. The remote silent wilderness areas you might go to once or twice a year are valuable. But the green relative silent spaces we can access daily have a different and more frequent value. One important part of the project is now to work with local communities, park services, counties and national organizations to identify, describe, increase access to and protect these places and walks that offer relative silence and valuable nature experiences.  This work started 2013 in the northern part of Stockholm and is now growing to other parts of the city and beyond the Swedish borders. The aim is to spread the Guide to Silence concept internationally and this Indiegogo campaign is an important first step towards this goal.  A Guide to Silence for the world's cities and towns will enable people to find new dimensions of their home town. But the Guide to Silence will also be a resource for the tourist or business traveler who needs a break, a different perspective and a moment of stillness when away from home.

THE BIG PURPOSE AND GOAL. The overall goal of the Guide to Silence project is to produce guidebooks for cities around the world - which will enable and inspire people to find and just be in relatively quiet natural surroundings - which is positive for well-being, health and ability to focus and function as humans - which can encourage cities, agencies and landowners to care for, protect and develop the relative quiet green space that exists.


THE SPECIFIC GOAL OF THIS INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN...

…is to produce and publish THE EXPLORERS GUIDE TO SILENCE. This is an innovative expansion of the original guide, this time with a threefold purpose.

The first purpose is to expand from the original guide with suggestions, tips and ideas on themes that provide new dimensions for your walk or visit in nature. These are some of the 15 themes:  “outer silence and inner limits”, “inner silence and focus”, “awareness, presence and absence”, “seeing without labels”, “different perspectives”, “acceptance and disturbance”, “in the now and goals” and “the cultivation of awe”. Being in nature has provided a form of meditation and mindfulness training long before these concepts where invented. We want to simplify, demystify and give more people the opportunity to find new energy and perspective on everyday life.  A still, quiet place in nature can help us find the inner stillness.  

The second purpose is to help you find and identify your own place, space in nature that offers relative silence and stillness. This could be in a park, by the water, or in a nature reserve. You may have favorite places close to home or work but what happens when you travel?  How can we find places in the world where we can experience stillness and connect to nature?  The Explorers Guide to Silence will show you how the silence of a green space are affected by obvious things as roads and other human activities, but also how less obvious things as trees, a creek, an elevated spot, a dense greenery,the moss on the ground and the weather can affect the silence. The Explorers Guide will invite you to find a different path or just leave your normal path in search for places of silence and new experiences of nature.How can we ensure that these places are protected so the relative silence and stillness we experience  can also be experienced by future generations?  It can be a place that ought to be noticed precisely because of its silence.  But importantly finding your own quiet place should be about experiencing, not measuring. Nature is never totally quiet, the sound of the wind, running water or birdsongs are part of the natural soundscape.

The third purpose is connected to the power of spreading ideas and creating change. The green relative silent spaces in a large city or a small community are important for both human well-being/health and biodiversity.  The Explorers Guide to Silence will help people to experience and identify the value of silent green spaces in their own neighborhoods all over the world. Some of these silent places in nature you might want to keep to yourself other places are very public and should be shared. At the same time as The Explorers Guide is published, a web platform will be launched so we can begin to grow a community of people who are willing to share ‘their’ places as well as their experiences.  This is also away to increase the value of silent still green areas and can help us protect them for future generations. 

Note. But just like the original Guide - this is also a guide to inner silence and thus it is also a guide that you can sit down with in a comfy chair, read a paragraph, take a deep breath and find an inner stillness.

FACTS ABOUT THE EXPLORERS GUIDE 

  • Launch: The Explorers Guide to Silence will be launched in the end of September 2014 in English and Swedish. The first edition will be offered as an e-book with an accompanying audio extension (the audio part of the book will include ideas and instructions that are great to listen to as a start of a walk or on your way to your silent place). 
  • The funding: The funds collected in this Indiegogo campaign will be used for final text production, photos, maps, audio production and layout. 



DETAILS/SPECIFICATION OF PERKS.

  • The original Guide to Silence.  128 pages, 10 chapters. Text: Ulf Bohman. Photography: Bo Kristiansson. Printed in three languages. Swedish title: Guide till tystnaden. German title: Wegweiser in Die Stille. 
  • The Explorers Guide to Silence 2014. 150 pages, 15 chapters. Text: Ulf Bohman. Maps and photos from different sources. Audio companion with 15 introductions to themes and suggestions for walks or visits in nature. 
  • The silence of the city. Exploration of the silent (most silent) green spaces of different cities. Using the available knowledge and experience of the nature and soundscape in the city, we will explore the silence. You might be surprised at how silent a big city can be. Included in this half day event (8 am to 1 pm) is coffee/tea in morning and an outdoor lunch. You will need to dress appropriately to be outside.  Stockholm, Sweden (Aug 10th).
  • In the foot steps of Hammarskjöld - the big silence/nature experience. (late June 2015). This is a chance to experience one of the most isolated and beautiful places in Scandinavia. This area was half a century ago, one of the favorite places for the late UN Director General Dag Hammarskjöld. Lake Sårjåsjaure and the Sulitelma mountain range have a lot to offer, silence, glaciers, blue lakes, flowers and impressive peaks. But in many ways it's the total experience offered that leaves the biggest impression.  We will begin in Jokkmokk, Lapland, Sweden on the morning of day one. A bus will take us to Kvikkjokk, where we will board a helicopter. The following days will be planned accordning to the weather, with accomodation either in huts or tents and on the evening of day 3 we will stay in Bodö, Norway. All meals, boarding and transport from Kvikkjokk to Bodö included. NOTE: Cost of travel to Kvikkjokk and from Bodö, Norway is not included. We will hike all three days and you therefore need good hiking boots, outdoor clothing and have a basic fitness level. 


INTERESTING LINKS & MORE

Finding Europe's Quiet Areas, report from the European Environment Agency, April 2014. Quote from the report: "These so called quiet areas may be found, not only in rural areas, but also inside our busiest cities. They are not only where people recreate, but also where they live and work, so how can they be identified and preserved in order to protect environmental health and well-being?" 

  • http://www.eea.europa.eu/highlights/finding-europe2019s-quiet-areas
  • http://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/good-practice-guide-on-quiet-areas
The age of concentration. Report "What’s On 2014" from Kairos Future.  

  • http://www.kairosfuture.com/publications/reports/2014-start-looking-for-the-signs-of-spring/

The IKUNN symbol. The small squirrel became the symbol on the original Guide to Silence. IKUNN is the word for squirrel in the local swedish dialect (Jamtska) in the county of Jämtland.
story_txt:
Do your have your own quiet place in a park, by the water or in a nature reserve?  A place that you frequently visit to breathe, wind down and recharge? Maybe it’s under a tree in the park close to work or up on that mountain ridge not far from your home or in the still part of the trail along the river. Most people can, if they start being aware of the value of silence, find small or big green spaces with relative silence and stillness. Some of these places are close to home or work, some are further away. But, no matter where they are, these places can have an enormous impact on our well-being, health and ability to focus and function as a human being.  And importantly, green, quiet spaces in or close to cities and communities are also important for the biodiversity, sustainability and appeal of our cities and communities.  
We are all today flooded with information and entertainment; for decades we have lived in an ever expanding age of information. But maybe we are, as the Swedish Future Trend firm Kairos Future has suggested, now moving into  “the age of concentration”. To thrive in the world today we need to be able to focus and focus is connected to inner and outer silence. The increasing interest in meditation, mindfulness and the need to find time for recovery and stillness indicates that maybe the “age of concentration” is not that far away. THE ORIGINAL. More than 15 years ago, in 1998, the original Guide to Silence was published. The purpose was twofold. The first  was to show the way and let more people experience the extraordinary silence and wilderness of the Swedish mountains. The second (but not secondary) purpose was to provide a guide to inner silence, stillness and new perspectives. The Guide to Silence is a guide book without facts - you won’t find the name of the mountains, lakes or trees. Instead it’s a guide to increased awareness and presence, to lower levels of stress.  It is a guide to being in nature and experiencing nature fully. But, the book’s audience wasn’t limited to only those lucky enough to hike in the Swedish mountains. The beautiful photography from one of Sweden’s most well known nature photographers, Bo Kristiansson, which accompanies  the short text makes the Guide to Silence a compelling work also from the sofa. To just read the book in a calm setting can lower stress levels and provide new perspectives. Thus the Guide to Silence has found an audience  around the world and we have sent guidebooks across Europe, the U.S. as well as to China.  You will find a limited edition of the original Guide to Silence included in our perks. 

A taste of Guide to Silence.  Below you find the introductory chapter in English, start and stop the movie to read. 


A taste of Wegweiser in die Stille.  Below you find the introductory chapter in German, start and stop the movie to read. 


A taste of Guide till tystnaden.  Below you find the introductory chapter in Swedish, start and stop the movie to read. 


THE RESTART. In 2013 the Guide to Silence project restarted, and the focus is now green spaces close to or in cities that offer relative silence and stillness. The remote silent wilderness areas you might go to once or twice a year are valuable. But the green relative silent spaces we can access daily have a different and more frequent value. One important part of the project is now to work with local communities, park services, counties and national organizations to identify, describe, increase access to and protect these places and walks that offer relative silence and valuable nature experiences.  This work started 2013 in the northern part of Stockholm and is now growing to other parts of the city and beyond the Swedish borders. The aim is to spread the Guide to Silence concept internationally and this Indiegogo campaign is an important first step towards this goal.  A Guide to Silence for the world's cities and towns will enable people to find new dimensions of their home town. But the Guide to Silence will also be a resource for the tourist or business traveler who needs a break, a different perspective and a moment of stillness when away from home.

THE BIG PURPOSE AND GOAL. The overall goal of the Guide to Silence project is to produce guidebooks for cities around the world - which will enable and inspire people to find and just be in relatively quiet natural surroundings - which is positive for well-being, health and ability to focus and function as humans - which can encourage cities, agencies and landowners to care for, protect and develop the relative quiet green space that exists.THE SPECIFIC GOAL OF THIS INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN...
…is to produce and publish THE EXPLORERS GUIDE TO SILENCE. This is an innovative expansion of the original guide, this time with a threefold purpose.The first purpose is to expand from the original guide with suggestions, tips and ideas on themes that provide new dimensions for your walk or visit in nature. These are some of the 15 themes:  “outer silence and inner limits”, “inner silence and focus”, “awareness, presence and absence”, “seeing without labels”, “different perspectives”, “acceptance and disturbance”, “in the now and goals” and “the cultivation of awe”. Being in nature has provided a form of meditation and mindfulness training long before these concepts where invented. We want to simplify, demystify and give more people the opportunity to find new energy and perspective on everyday life.  A still, quiet place in nature can help us find the inner stillness.  
The second purpose is to help you find and identify your own place, space in nature that offers relative silence and stillness. This could be in a park, by the water, or in a nature reserve. You may have favorite places close to home or work but what happens when you travel?  How can we find places in the world where we can experience stillness and connect to nature?  The Explorers Guide to Silence will show you how the silence of a green space are affected by obvious things as roads and other human activities, but also how less obvious things as trees, a creek, an elevated spot, a dense greenery,the moss on the ground and the weather can affect the silence. The Explorers Guide will invite you to find a different path or just leave your normal path in search for places of silence and new experiences of nature.How can we ensure that these places are protected so the relative silence and stillness we experience  can also be experienced by future generations?  It can be a place that ought to be noticed precisely because of its silence.  But importantly finding your own quiet place should be about experiencing, not measuring. Nature is never totally quiet, the sound of the wind, running water or birdsongs are part of the natural soundscape.
The third purpose is connected to the power of spreading ideas and creating change. The green relative silent spaces in a large city or a small community are important for both human well-being/health and biodiversity.  The Explorers Guide to Silence will help people to experience and identify the value of silent green spaces in their own neighborhoods all over the world. Some of these silent places in nature you might want to keep to yourself other places are very public and should be shared. At the same time as The Explorers Guide is published, a web platform will be launched so we can begin to grow a community of people who are willing to share ‘their’ places as well as their experiences.  This is also away to increase the value of silent still green areas and can help us protect them for future generations. 
Note. But just like the original Guide - this is also a guide to inner silence and thus it is also a guide that you can sit down with in a comfy chair, read a paragraph, take a deep breath and find an inner stillness.FACTS ABOUT THE EXPLORERS GUIDE 


Launch: The Explorers Guide to Silence will be launched in the end of September 2014 in English and Swedish. The first edition will be offered as an e-book with an accompanying audio extension (the audio part of the book will include ideas and instructions that are great to listen to as a start of a walk or on your way to your silent place). 


The funding: The funds collected in this Indiegogo campaign will be used for final text production, photos, maps, audio production and layout. 

DETAILS/SPECIFICATION OF PERKS.


The original Guide to Silence.  128 pages, 10 chapters. Text: Ulf Bohman. Photography: Bo Kristiansson. Printed in three languages. Swedish title: Guide till tystnaden. German title: Wegweiser in Die Stille. 


The Explorers Guide to Silence 2014. 150 pages, 15 chapters. Text: Ulf Bohman. Maps and photos from different sources. Audio companion with 15 introductions to themes and suggestions for walks or visits in nature. 


The silence of the city. Exploration of the silent (most silent) green spaces of different cities. Using the available knowledge and experience of the nature and soundscape in the city, we will explore the silence. You might be surprised at how silent a big city can be. Included in this half day event (8 am to 1 pm) is coffee/tea in morning and an outdoor lunch. You will need to dress appropriately to be outside.  Stockholm, Sweden (Aug 10th).


In the foot steps of Hammarskjöld - the big silence/nature experience. (late June 2015). This is a chance to experience one of the most isolated and beautiful places in Scandinavia. This area was half a century ago, one of the favorite places for the late UN Director General Dag Hammarskjöld. Lake Sårjåsjaure and the Sulitelma mountain range have a lot to offer, silence, glaciers, blue lakes, flowers and impressive peaks. But in many ways it's the total experience offered that leaves the biggest impression.  We will begin in Jokkmokk, Lapland, Sweden on the morning of day one. A bus will take us to Kvikkjokk, where we will board a helicopter. The following days will be planned accordning to the weather, with accomodation either in huts or tents and on the evening of day 3 we will stay in Bodö, Norway. All meals, boarding and transport from Kvikkjokk to Bodö included. NOTE: Cost of travel to Kvikkjokk and from Bodö, Norway is not included. We will hike all three days and you therefore need good hiking boots, outdoor clothing and have a basic fitness level. 


INTERESTING LINKS & MORE
Finding Europe's Quiet Areas, report from the European Environment Agency, April 2014. Quote from the report: "These so called quiet areas may be found, not only in rural areas, but also inside our busiest cities. They are not only where people recreate, but also where they live and work, so how can they be identified and preserved in order to protect environmental health and well-being?" 

http://www.eea.europa.eu/highlights/finding-europe2019s-quiet-areas

http://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/good-practice-guide-on-quiet-areas
The age of concentration. Report "What’s On 2014" from Kairos Future.  
http://www.kairosfuture.com/publications/reports/2014-start-looking-for-the-signs-of-spring/

story:
About the Project.

In April 2014 I helped back Open Source Beehives here on Indiegogo and since that time I have been interested in beekeeping. However I wasn't able to start last year, I'm hoping to change that this year. 

Why keep bees and study Colony Collapse Disorder(CCD)?

There are a number of reasons to keep bees and study CCD. But I feel that as more people keep bees and help study CCD, we will be able to bring more light and change to finding a solution to the problem. 
But why is it a problem in the first place? It is because bees help pollinate a number of our crops. Without that pollination comes a smaller harvest, and less food for us to eat. 
Like apples? Gone. Lemon and limes? Gone. Your morning coffee? Gone. Any many more things without the help of bees. 
We all need to help study this and find away to fix it, or we are going to be without a lot of things that we enjoy on a daily basis.
More on CCD.

How you can help.

By backing this project you will be helping me be able to start beekeeping, studying bees, and CCD. As I start beekeeping I plan to keep a  blog about my experience and help add to different citizen scientist  studies on bees and CCD.  I also plan on creating a Facebook page for this project. I will be twitting updates as well from @Rasmussen_Bees.
Your pledge will help me get all the different supplies that I need to start beekeeping. Mainly the bees and their hive.

story:
DEAR FOLKS:  I DO LOTs OF SOLO {BY MY-SELF --- JUST ME} LONG-DISTANCE WALK-ING:  FOLKs WHO KNOW ME SAY THAT I'V WALK'D ACROSS THE USA SEVERAL TIMEs, AND I ALWAYS CORRECT THEM:  I NEVER WALK'D THE ENTIRE DISTANCE, BUT ALWAYS RECEIVED ***SOME*** HELP FROM MOTORIZED-VEHICLES:  EITHER BY ACCEPT-ING RIDES WHICH WERE OFFER'D TO ME BY PASS-ING MOTORISTs, OR BY ACTUAL-LY STICK-ING OUT MY THUMB ... PLUS, I'V BEEN ON SEVERAL ORGANIZED WALKs, WITH OTHER PEOPLE, WHICH WENT ALL THE WAY ACROSS THE USA, AND SEVERAL SHORT-ER ONEs ... IT's ALWAYS MORE-FUN, AND MUCH-EASY-ER, WITH OTHER PEOPLE ...

THIS WALK,  ("THE GREAT WALK FOR CLIMATE ACTION"), IS, (LIKE), THE BEST-ORGANIZED WALK I'V EVER BEEN ON ... IT STARTED IN L.A., CA, ON  1-MARCH-2014 ... I LEFT OAKLAND, CA ON 7-MARCH-2014 AND CAUGHT-UP WITH THE OTHER WALKERs NEAR PARKER, ARIZONA, APPROX. 3.5 WEEKs LATER ... I HAD HOPED TO CONTINUE ALL THE WAY TO WASHINGTON, DC, BUT LEARN'D THAT EVERY WALKER IS EXPECTED TO CONTRIBUTE MONEY TO HELP PAY EXPENSEs (FOR FOOD, GASOLINE FOR SUPPORT-VEHICLEs, ETC ) ... THIS IS WHY I'M ASK-ING U TO SEND ME SOME $$$, IF U CAN ...

THERE ARE CURRENT-LY APPROX. 35 OTHER WALKERs:  MANY MADE IT CLEAR TO ME THAT THEY WANT ME TO RE-JOIN THE WALK + CONTINUE:  ONE OF THEM SAY'D THAT HE WILL MATCH WHAT-EVER I CONTRIBUTE, DOLLAR-FOR-DOLLAR ... 2 OTHER WALKERs HAVE PUT SOME MONEY IN-TO MY ACCOUNT ... AND I WAS NOT THE ONLY WALKER WHO LEFT TO FUND-RAISE:  2 OTHERs LEFT AFTER WE GOT TO PHOENIX, AZ, TO FUND-RAISE, AND HOPE TO RE-JOIN ...

I TOLD EVERY-BODY THAT I PLAN TO RE-JOIN IN JULY, WHEN THE WALK WILL BE GO-ING THRU NEBRASKA;  SO THIS GIVEs ME PLENTY OF TIME TO FUND-RAISE .....

SINCERE-LY,  MARK CREEK-WATER DORAZIO,  CROSS-USA WALKER

MORE INFO RE THE WALK IS AT  www.CLIMATEMARCH.org 

AND     www.FACEBOOK.com/CLIMATEMARCH
